choices: Gary Wilson, a docter
Frank Hughes, an accountant
Betty Winters, a fastfood worker
Eric Dressil, a prisoner
Shannon Hawking, an author
1.content: Its been 5 days since it all happened...the end of the world. Only 5 people along with maybe a few other survivors are left in the city of Bitterwood. You will take the role of one of the 5 survivors and try to keep them alive. Choose wisely...
1.title: It begins...

choices: The hospital downtown where he used to work
The subway station
The mall
The nature preserve
His home thats about 3 miles west of the city
11.content: Good choice. Where will Gary be starting?
11.title: Gary Wilson, a docter

choices: Quicky runs up to the elevator and pushes the button to call it to this floor
Runs down the remaining hallway that doesn't seem to have any zombies in it
Fights the zombies
111.content: Gary Wilson had been making his rounds late one night at the local hospital when it happened. A patient he was supposed to operate on had gone missing, a little girl with stomach cancer. He thought she was simply afraid, like any child would be, and ran off to hide somewhere. Sadly she was found a short time later in another patients room covered in blood and with glowing red eyes. She had ripped the tounge out of an elderly man, causing him to drown in his own blood. When the nurse who had found her screamed she jumped onto her and used her new claws to tear off her face. Soon after the nurse got back up and joined the little girl in her violent killing spree. After an hour had passed 80% of the patients and 67% of the hospital staff were dead or zombiefied. Five days after this incident Gary Wilson was the only one known to have survived...so far. Gary had made it through most of the hospital without being killed by sheer luck, and was almost to the car garage. Once there he could get in his car and drive the hell away from this place. He knew that the zombies had spread to the outside, but there may also be other survivers out there who need his help. Gary hoped that with enough people they could all escape the city and maybe find help on the outside. Gary opened the doors that led to the hallway with the elevator at the end. He slowly made his way down the hall, holding a bloody scalpel in his left hand. It wasn't much, but in a docters hands it could be deadly. Just as he made it to the elevator a zombie appeared from around the corner. It was a young woman whose clothes were tattered and bloodstained. She moved slowly towards Gary, limping a bit as if her left leg was broken. "Good thing its only a level 1." Gary said as she moved closer. He quickly ran towards her and prepaired to strike. Unfortunately, just seconds before his scalpel made contact, she let out a loud wail. "Oh fuck!" Gary screamed as the scalpel pirced her right eye. "A siren!" No sooner had her body falled to the ground then at least half a dozen zombies appeared in the doorway behind him and in the hallway off to his side. Gary...
111.title: No mercy hospital

choices: Gary deals with the level 2 right away
Gary runs into the open door on his right and tries to find a better weapon
Gary tries to avoid the zombies altogether and run past them to the car garage
1111.content: Wasting no time, Gary ran over to the elevator and pushed the button to call it to this floor. The zombies slowly made their way towards the elevator and Gary with their hellish red eyes glowing and their arms outstretched. "Damn it, hurry up!" Gary yelled as he shoved an approaching zombie away. The elevator was making too much noise and soon every zombie within earshot would be making its way over here. Two of the nearby zombies grabed Gary and tried to pull him to the ground, but as they were only level 1 he was able to overpower them and managed to stab one in the chest with his scalpel and knocked both of them to the floor. As the zombies were begining to get back up and surround the unarmed docter the elevator arrived with a ding sound. Gary quickly got inside and closed the doors as the zombies reached out and tried to grab him one last time as he disappeared behind the doors. "Shit...that was too close..." Gary gasped as he leaned agenst the elevators wall. The breif trip to the next floor allowed him to catch his breath, but he would have to get out of here before he could rest. Once again the doors to the elevator opened and Gary walked out into the hallway that led to the car garage. The hallway was empty and all of the doors were closed. "They must all be trying to get into the elevator on the floor I was just on." Gary said to himself. "I guess all that noise was a good thing." He followed the hallway around a corner and made it down the second part of the hallway without incident. His luck finally ran out when he turned around the final corner and was met with the stare of 3 zombies. The first two were just level 1, but the third was a level 2. They all noticed him before he had the chace to retreat and began moving towards him. He could outrun the level one's easily, but the level two was coming at him too fast for him to escape from it. The door to the car garage is just behind them, all Gary has to do now is find a way past them.
1111.title: Only 3 left...

11111.content: Gary had no weapon, but knew if he could take out the level two he would have no problem getting past the level ones. He quickly caught both of the monsters hands as it tried to cut him down where he stood. The level two couldn't get to Gary, but it took all of his strength just to keep the zombie from getting out of his hold. It seemed speed wasn't the monster's only advantage. Soon, the two weaker level one zombies reached the struggling duo and pulled Gary to the floor. Before he could even push them away he found himself laying in a puddle of his own blood as the heart in his torn open chest slowly stopped beating.
11111.title: Nothing to get all torn up about...

choices: Gary quickly looks for something to patch himself up with
Gary ignores his wound for the time being and deals with the last 2 zombies
11112.content: For a brief moment Gary thought he would die as the level 2 prepared to slash him with its claws, but saw an opened door to his right and made a desperate jump towards it. The level 2 zombie's claws barely scratched his legs as he landed in the doorway of the room. He quickly got to his feet and pushed the door closed just as the zombie made another strike. Its hand was caught in the door with its razor-sharp claws just a few inches away from Gary's face. The door remained firmly shut as the level two struggled to push it open from outside, but Gary knew as soon as the two level one's reached them they would easily overpower him and get in. He had about a minute to find a weapon to defend himself with. He looked around the room for anything that he could use. On the ground 3 feet away was a bloody pipe that must have been torn from somewhere in the building and used to fight the undead before he had gotten here. It wasn't very large and might not be effective against a level two, but it was all Gary could see. Gary let go of the door and quickly grabbed the pipe. The level 2 entered the room and charged at him as he swung the metal pipe as hard as he could towards its face. It was over before Gary could even tell what had happened. The level 2's claws had sunk deep into his left shoulder, but he had scored a killing blow with his pipe. The zombie was bleeding onto its arm from a large wound on its forehead, the only thing keeping it from falling to the floor was its grip on its would-be prey. Gary pulled the claws from his shoulder and grabbed the spot where he had been struck. The injury itself was fairly small, but deep. His own blood began running down his shoulder and onto his arm. Outside Gary could hear the remaining level one zombies draw closer...
11112.title: Killing blow

choices: He tries to get to his car
He escapes out the main entrance while he has the chance
111121.content: Gary closed the door back before he did anything else. It may not keep the level one's out for long, but it would buy him some time. After he had secured the door he walked over towards a cabinet leaning over a counter with a sink. "I hope this what I think it is..." He said to himself as he opened it. Just as he suspected there were some bandages and rubbing alcohol on the bottom shelf. He could hardly believe his luck... not only had he found a reliable weapon, but also had the good fortune to take refuge in a doctors office not unlike his own. He took off his coat and applied the rubbing alcohol to the wound. It wouldn't stop bleeding right away, but at least it wouldn't become infected. He wrapped the wound carefully and put his coat back on just as the level one's outside began banging on the door. He had finish dressing his wound just in time. He put the bandages and the rubbing alcohol into his pockets and picked up his pipe. He threw the door open and made short work of the level one's, they never even saw him coming. After leaving his foes smashed bodies to decorate the hallway he walked onwards towards the parking garage. He braced himself for whatever was behind the door in front of him and opened it. He had indeed reached his destination, yet something was wrong. Upon checking a nearby sign he found out just what he had overlooked. He was on level 1-D. His car had been parked on level 2-D, one level up. "Dammit..." He cursed as he took another quick look around. The were few cars on this level and, even better, no zombies. He could just walk out the main entrance to his right and continue on foot... or head to his left and try to get to his car.
111121.title: The exit is right there...

choices: Gary has no choice... he must leave them to their fate...
Gary tries to create a distraction
1111212.content:
Gary didn't want to leave his car here and continue on foot, but deep down he knew it was the better option. If many of those things were upstairs he would be ripped to pieces before he could even get to his car. He walked out of the hospital without looking back and stepped out onto the sidewalk. Amazingly, there were no zombies in sight, strange considering that the hospital had been full of them. "They must be grouping together somewhere..." Gary said aloud. "Or, maybe they're starting to die out." He noted as he looked down the abandoned streets in front of him. Either way, Gary wasn't accomplishing anything just standing there. He walked down the sidewalk slowly and kept an eye out for any movement. When he got to the end of the street he was on he could see where all the zombies had gone. Up ahead there had been a large car wreck that cut off one of the roads, further down it past most of the wreckage was a school bus that was laying on its side. A mob of the undead were surrounding it like a group of metalheads at a rock concert with their favorite band playing. Gary wondered why as he ducked behind a car and tried to sneak by unnoticed.


Just as he was out of the zombies line of sight and able to continue on he stopped dead in his tracks. A woman screamed in fear and horror... along with what sounded like a young child. The sound had come from the direction of the bus. "Of course." Gary whispered. "There must be people in there." He walked back and peered out from behind the wall. The zombies were still swarming around the outside and Gary swore he saw someone move inside one of the windows. "Shit..." Gary groaned as he counted up the number of zombies he'd have to face to get to them. "...18, 19, 20, ..." 21 in all, 5 were level two and one looked like a Vampire. Soon they'd be able to get inside, Gary needed to act as soon as possible. He couldn't sneak up on them, they were far away enough that even if he used cover they would notice him before he could get to the trapped people and overwhelm him. Trying to come up with ideas Gary heard the woman scream again, this time slightly louder...
1111212.title: Alone?

choices: Some weapons
Some emergency supplies
11112122.content:
Gary had helped people all his life, that was something that would never change even in the madhouse the world around him had slowly become. For a moment he considered throwing his pipe through the window of a nearby building and climbing over the wrecked vehicles to get to them, but soon came up with a better plan. On the ground next to a turned over Ford was a sizable chuck of broken concrete that would serve as an excellent nose maker. Gary picked it up and tossed it with all his might over the heads of the zombies and was pleased to see it crash through the window of a grocery store a little further down that same street. The level 2's and the Vampire quickly moved to investigate the noise while the lowly level 1's began shambling along behind them. As soon as he was sure all their attention was focused on the store, Gary quickly climbed over the impressive wreckage and silently made his way over to the bus. To his surprise, the door flew open and a young woman climbed out along with her young child.


Before Gary could say anything she silently gestured for him to follow her into the nearby building behind the bus. He nodded in agreement and opened the door for his two new companions as he looked over at the store one final time. The zombies were still distracted and didn't even notice the doctor and their prey vanish from sight. The inside of the building was fairly dark with no power and few windows to let in sunlight. Luckily, the young woman, who introduced herself as Courtney, had a working flashlight. She explained that she and her son Robert had taken refuge in the bus while running from the undead two days ago, only to find it surround when they attempted to leave. "Thank god you came along mister, I was so scared... and my poor son has been through so much... He... lost his daddy on the day this whole thing started, my husband Keith sacrificed himself so we could get away..." Gary felt a sharp pain in his chest when he heard this. "What a devoted father, he must have truly cared for his family. Please... accept my condolences, I've lost quite a few people myself. In fact... I may be the only doctor left alive in this whole city thanks to what those monsters did to the hospital..."


"You're... a doctor?" The woman asked as she wiped a few tears from her eyes. "Yes, and I'd be glad to help you and anyone else who needs my aid. After all, its my sworn duty." Gary said with a smile. "So lets get through this together, as long as I'm here I'll heal you both to the best of my medical ability if the need arises." The woman smiled as she opened a door that led to a room with a boarded up window. "Thank you, we're both okay now, just a few scratches. We'll make it through this, right Robert?" The boy didn't say a word, but nodded his head slowly in confirmation. "Why did you come to this room in particular?" Gary asked as he looked around the heavily damaged room, of which the only notable quality was the large R in a circle spray painted on one of the walls. Courtney lowered her head a bit in embarrassment and mumbled a bit as she spoke. "Well... this may seem silly, but... this guy I met told me about how survivors were marking places as re-supply spots... See, people who can't carry any more stuff leave it behind and some of them mark the location for other people to find... at least that's what the man told me..."


Gary had a little trouble buying this idea, just who did they expect to find all of their stuff if they left it in places like this? "How exactly did you know to come to this one room? I didn't see anything outside to tip you off..." He asked as he opened a dresser sitting just below the R symbol. "W-well, the guy seemed to be telling the truth... and he gave me this..." She pulled out a crumpled sheet of notebook paper that crudely mapped the surrounding area with several spots marked with brief instructions next to them. Sure enough, this apartment building was marked with the words "Room seven" scribbled under it in blue ink. Gary let out a sigh as he closed the empty dresser drawer and handed the piece of paper back to Courtney. "You... really think people would be so selfless?" She was silent for a moment before replying in a firm tone: "I do." Impressed by her faith in humanity Gary helped her and her son search the room for anything of value. When they were finally done they had obtained...
11112122.title: Human kindness

choices: Check out the local Arby's for some food
Look for some food in the nearby supermarket
111121221.content:
It took a while to look over the whole room, but when they were finally done the trio hand found some good weapons. Along with a riot shield that was hidden under the bed was a large cardboard box filled with four handguns and a few extra clips in a plastic bag. "Wow, I guess you were right..." Gary said as he looked over the contents of the box. "But since they didn't leave any food we'll have to move on soon..." He handed Courtney the riot shield and one of the hand guns. "You take these and I'll take two of the handguns for myself, the last one we'll leave here for someone else." Courtney nodded and handed Robert the riot shield while she made sure the gun was fully loaded. "Hey mister, how come I don't get a gun? Are we really just gonna leave it here?" Robert groaned as Gary, without even bothering to turn around simply shook his head in confirmation. "Yes, along with two of the extra clips, other people will need it and..." He stood back up and turned to Courtney as he sat the box on a nearby table. "I'm sure your mother wouldn't want a kid your age handling a gun, right?" Courtney smiled. "No, but I appreciate him wanting to help." She replied as she took back the shield while Gary handed Robert the bag with the few extra clips that they'd take with them. "Aw man, I gotta carry our stuff too...?" Robert groaned again as he crossed his arms.


"Don't worry, sweetie. I know you must think the whole world is against you right now, but we'll get through this together. I promise." Courtney said as Gary looked out the rooms only window to check for zombies. "The alleyway next to us is clear, let's hurry up and move while we have the chance." He said as he made sure both of his own guns were fully loaded. Courtney moved Robert in front of her and told him to follow Gary while she made sure no zombies snuck up behind them. "No matter what, follow the doctor, okay?" She said as Gary quickly shattered the broken window as quietly as possible. "Now let's move, hurry!" With that the trio moved out into the alley and began walking behind several buildings as they kept an eye out for zombies. Fortunately, nothing had heard them leave the room and they made it to the next street without incident. There were four zombies in front of a nearby car and a fifth and sixth zombie standing outside a movie theater further up the road. "Slow down, some of them are up ahead..." Gary whispered as he took aim with his guns. By the time the zombies noticed the survivors presence half of them were already dead and the rest soon followed. When it was clear Gary gestured for his companions to stay put for a minute while he scouted the area. When he returned a short time later he told them about all of the stores and restaurants he had seen. After going over each place he found the trio decided to...
111121221.title: Handguns and hunger

choices: "A movie theater, popcorn and candy is hardly a delicacy, but it'll have to do."
"A supermarket, sould be plenty of stuff there."
1111212211.content:
The three survivours were careful to not attract any attention as they walked up to the front door. "We need to get a quick bite to eat and then get out of here before one of those things comes along." Gary said quietly as he gently pushed open the broken glass door. After his two compainions were in Gary took one last look around before closing the door and following them inside. There was a little blood on the windows and a few of them were broken, but the bushes ouside obscured most of the interrior, which would hopefully allow them to enjoy an uninterroupted meal. "Can you cook?" Gary asked Courtney as she and Robert sat down at a table. "Of course... can't you doctor?" She replied with a small laugh. "Ha... no, my wife's the chef... the last time I tried cooking I nearly caused a fire..." Gary said with a weak laugh. He paused for a moment when he thought of his wife, whom he still didn't know was alright. For all he knew she could be face down in some ditch with blood running down... he quickly pushed the thought from his mind. "Your wife, doctor... is she... do you know if she's okay...?" Courtney asked when she noticed him lingering on the mention of his wife. "I'm not sure... God, I hope she is..." Gary said as his voiced quivered a bit. "Oh, I, I'm so sorry...! Please, I shouldn't have said anything...!" Courtney said as her voice rose a bit louder then she meant it too. "Its okay... I'm sure she's fine..." Gary replied as he took a seat opposite from Courtney and Robert. "I... I guess I better get cooking..." Courtney said as she excused herself to the kitchen. Gary sat his guns on the table and looked out the window. He couldn't see much of the street past the bushes, but it was still clear... for now.


A few seconds passed before Courtney returned carrying a tray with a frown on her face. "The power... its out here too. We'll either have to eat our food cold or move to somewhere else." She said as she sat the tray she was carrying down on the table. "There's plenty of water, but not much food other then bun's and condiments..." Gary sighed as he took one of the waters and had a good long sip. The last time he had had a drink was at one of the hospitals water fountains and if this young woman was to be believed both her and her child must have gone days without water. "Boy, that sure is refreshing..." Gary said as he sat his empty cup back down on the table. "You poor folks must be partched after your ordeal with the bus..." Robert simply mumbled as he sat his first cup down and began drinking his second. "Not too fast dear, I know you're thirsty, but I don't want you throwing up." Courtney said as she took a sip from her own water. "So, um, doctor... what should we do... my poor baby hasn't had anything to eat since we were forced to leave our home... and that was days ago..." Gary took another look out at the still empty streets before turning back to Courtney. "I saw a few places that probably still have food when we cleared the street... not too far from here is..."
1111212211.title: A quick refresher

11113.content: Gary actually began running at the level 2 and did a roll just as it made a swipe at him with its claws. "Ha, I'm faster then I look...!" Gary called as he shoved aside the weak level ones and placed his hand on the knob of the door. Before he could turn it, however, he felt a sharp pain in his back and fell to the floor. Apparently, the level two had been faster then it looked as well. Gary struggled as best he could, but quickly succumbed when the zombie slit his throat.
11113.title: The quick and the dead...

choices: Make a mad dash to his car
Run back through the door and out into the other hallways
Kill the zombie that saw him and then hide among the cars
1112.content: Gary ran past the elevator down the short hallway that didn't have zombies in it. This hallway happened to lead to the stairs and was now the only hope Gary had of escape. He rushed down the steps as the shambling hordes behind him slowly followed. He had been on the 4th floor and was now making his way to the 2nd, from there he could enter the car garage through a shortcut and hopefully avoid most of the zombies still there. Along his desent he ran into one zombie...a small child who he simply shoved aside as he ran. He reached floor 2 in only a few minutes and looked out the windows on the doors that led to more hallways. There were only 2 zombies out there, but one was a vampire. "Good thing I'm not going that way." Gary said as he turned around and opened the door to the car garage. This door didn't have any windows so Gary had to be ready to act fast. He had decided that if there was a large horde of them he'd go back to the doors that led to the second floor and figure another way out. As the door swung open Gary immediately surveyed his surroundings. There were several zombies scattered about along with a small group in the far corner. As far as Gary could tell they were all level ones. He spied his car two rows down with only one zombie, a fat man who was about thirty (and much too small to be a sumo), standing near it. Just as he was about to act one of the zombies spotted him and began moving towards him. What should he do?
1112.title: Taking the stairs

choices: His house
A friend's house
11121.content: Gary made a mad dash to his car and managed to get to it. He quickly took out his keys and unlocked his car, but he was caught by a Level One Zombie. "Fuck! Im screwed." He said. But somehow he managed to push off the zombie and quickly got in his car, he drove to a place. What place is he driving to?
11121.title: He makes a very mad rush to his car.

choices: He decides to just hurry along the bridge and get home
He checks the ammo store for supplies
111211.content: Gary pulled out of the hospital and onto the empty street outside. He then turned west and headed towards his house. As he drove he noticed a few zombies walking or crawling along the road and sidewalk. He normaly wasn't a violent person, but these things were not human, not anymore. Gary went out of his way to run down what zombies he could without risking damaging his car, and couldn't help but feel satisfied as he heard their bones snap and break as he drove. He was almost to the bridge that crossed the river that ran through the city when he was forced to stop. The entire road in front of him was blocked by huge chunks of steel and debris from nearby buildings. There was no way to go around it ether, if he wanted to cross the bridge and get to his home he would have to get out and walk. Gary reached under his seat and grabed the gun that he kept there and stepped out of his car. He took a quick look around to check for zombies. There were none nearby, but he knew it was only a matter of time before they showed up. As he walked towards the blockade in front of the bridge he checked his gun, six shots, he would be safe for now. The pile of the destroyed buildings was far larger up close and looked quite strange. It appered as if...something...had ripped the buildings apart. Gary decided that he better be quick in getting home. He climbed over the pile fairly easily and could now continue across the bridge. Just as he was about to move on, however, he saw a store up ahead that sold guns and ammo. He could hurry across the bridge to his house or he could take a few minutes to check for any weapons that might have been left behind.
111211.title: Blockade

choices: Check the back room
Take what you have and get to the bridge
1112112.content: Gary decided that even if he only found a few more rounds of ammo for his handgun then this little detour would be worth it. He walked over to the store and tried opening the door. Locked. Fortunately, the window of the shop was broken and Gary was able to climb inside without cutting himself. Once inside he called out to see if anyone else was there. No answer. "Guess they won't mind if I take anything then." Gary said as he moved past the empty shelves. "Well, if there's anything left to take that is..." He walked over to the counter and looked down at the glass display case. There was a hunting rifle laying beneath the broken glass that was covered with a little blood. Gary picked it up and checked it for ammo. It was empty. Gary decided to take it anyway in case he came across some ammo. As he slowly walked behind the counter he was met with the sight of a man laying face down in a puddle of his own blood. His head was reduced to hamburger his limbs were twisted in odd shapes. "Christ..." Gary said as he bent down to check the body. The man had some keys in his back pocket. "These must be for the store." Gary said as he took them. He tried to open the cash register with them. The first two keys did nothing, but the third opened it. Inside was several 5, 10, 20, 50, and 100 dollar bills along with hundreds of coins. Gary didn't care about the money, but was both happy and surprised to find 2 shotgun shells hidden under the money. Gary put both the shells in his back pocket and looked up to see a level one zombie outside staring at him. He decided to shoot the zombie with his handgun. All it took was one bullet and the level one fell to the ground with a hole in his head above the left eye. Gary knew he couldn't stay here much longer without having to deal with more zombies, but he hadn't checked the back room yet...
1112112.title: Can you spare some supplies?

choices: Gary fights them
Gary tries to escape out the back door
11121121.content: Gary decided to take the time to check the back room, it might lead to his death, but he couldn't stand missing out on what might be inside. He turned the knob on the door and was surprised to find it wasn't locked. He opened the door and walked into the small room, making sure to close the door behind him. Inside there were a few more shelves laying on their sides on the floor, a few boxes strung all over the room, and a metal door that must lead outside. Gary wasted no time checking the many boxes and looking behind the shelves. He found 3 more bullets for his handgun, a bullet for his hunting rifle, 4 more shotgun shells, and a few extra bullets for other types of guns Gary didn't know about. He pocketed all the bullets except for the ones for his handgun, he loaded one into the gun and put the remaing two in his front shirt pocket for easy access. He also loaded his one hunting rifle bullet in the gun so it would be ready. "I guess one shot for this thing is better then no shots. I'll just have to make sure I don't waste it." Carrying his hunting rifle in one hand and his handgun in the other made opening the door more difficult, but Gary managed to open it. He was just about to climb back out the front window when he came face to face with not one, not two, but three zombies! Two of them were just level ones, but the third had red goo dripping from its mouth. The goo was too off color to be blood, not that Gary had time to notice as he quickly closed the door as one of the level ones reached out to grab him. Gary thought he was safe for the moment, sadly this wasn't the case. The door began to dissolve as a hole appeared in its center and slowly started to grow larger. Gary watched in horror as the Slimer spit another blob of red goo on the door causing the hole to grow larger and revealing the corpse of the level one that had been standing too close to the door. Its entire head and part of its arm had been completey melted off, its headless torso driping some of the red slime into the display case where it had fallen. Gary had to act fast, he could either fight them...or try to escape out the back door.
11121121.title: More bullets...and more zombies...

choices: Examine the strange puddle
Get the hell out of here before more of these freaks show up
111211211.content: Quickly recovering from the shock of seeing this monster slowly melt away his only defence Gary quickly raised his handgun and fired off 2 shots just as another blob of slime came hurling through the door, barely missing his head. The blob hit the wall behind him and started to eat away at it just as easily as it had the door. Gary knew the door wouldn't how much longer, he would have to finish off the Slimer now before it got another shot off. He rushed over to the door and gave it a sharp kick. The weakened structure broke into two halves as it was launched outward. The Slimer spat another blob just as one half of the door made contact with its face, resulting in an explosion of red as the Slimer's own face began to melt and ooze away. Gary took this chance to finally put a bullet in the thing's now rapidly decaying head. It fell to the floor with a thud and didn't get back up. Gary stepped through the doorway and quickly surveyed his surroundings, trying to locate the remaining level one. His eyes soon met with its remains laying on the other side of the store, a bullet from one of his earlier shots buryed deep within its brain under the spot where its eye used to be. With all three zombies dead Gary finally had a moment to catch his breath and reload his gun. "I've got five shots left for this thing..." Gary said as he put the last round into his gun. "But I've also got a hunting rifle now, and its still got a shot left. I guess all in all, this little detour was worth it. Now I better get back to the bridge." Gary walked past the freshly dead bodies back over to the window where he had come in. Just as he was about to climb back out he heard a noise behind him. Gary quickly spun back around and raised his gun to the air. Just as he was about to fire and waste more precious ammo he happened to glance down. The corpse of the Slimer was now a deep purple color and begining to dissolve. "What in the hell...?" Was all Gary could manage to mutter as the slain foe was reduced to a large puddle in a matter of seconds. What should Gary do?
111211211.title: Gun store shootout

choices: Ignite one of the containers and throw it at the zombie horde
Ignore the zombies and climb over the window
1112112111.content:
Gary observed the strange purple goo. He recognized it. While the hospital was just starting get overrun by zombies, Slimers would spit this purple stuff all over the place. It's use remained unknown until one his co-works, Lenny, tried to light a zombie on fire with just a match. Had gotten too close to the purple goo, that it exploded, taking out a large crowd of zombies. Sadly, Lenny with them.

Gary smirked. He had no knowledge about any type of explosives what so ever, but this could be put to good use if stored the right way. Quickly scanning around the room, Gary found 5 small containers and a pack of matches. Returning to the slime, he scooped in as much slime into the 5 containers, and placed them around his belt. If he came across a huge horde of zombies, he could just easily light one of the containers on fire with a match and throw it at them. A good improvised bomb. He only had five though, so they only be used in desperate need until he can find more goo.

Now fully supplied with a hunting rifle and a few containers of slime, Gary was ready to climb over the window. Though before he could go through it, he heard several groans and footsteps behind. He turned around, his breath leaving him immediately.

"Shit!" he mumbled to himself. The little fight he had just a few minutes ago had attracted some visitors. 3 level ones, 3 level twos, a savage looking level three, and a German Shepperd turned beast made their way towards him. It was impossible for him to fight them off with his rifle, but one of the bombs could easily blow them away. Yet again, that would be a waste of precious weapons when he could just climb over the window and make his back to the car. Gary decides to . . .
1112112111.title: Storage made bomb

choices: He decides to take the time to check each marked location for stuff
He decides that he's wasted enough time and ignores all of the R.S.L.
11121121111.content: There was no time to think, if Gary was to survive he would have to act now. He quickly dropped his hunting rifle and handgun to the ground and pulled one of his new slime containers from his belt. He quickly lit it and was just about to throw it when the Beast dog pounced at him. Not expecting it to have greater speed then the human zombies, it managed to catch Gary completely off-guard. He fell to the ground, but was still able to fling his now active bomb at the rest of the approching horde. He could now use both of his free hands to hold it back and keep it from biting him, but would be defenceless if any of the other zombies survived the explosion. A few seconds passed... followed a loud boom. Bits of debris and body parts flew by, some still on fire. Fortunately, this new sound caught the attention of the zombie German Shepperd just long enough for Gary to grab his nearby handgun and put a hole in the things head. It went limp and was pushed aside as Gary got up and picked up his hunting rifle. "Four shots left..." He gasped as he made his way to the window yet again. It was finally over, he was finally about to walk out of here and start making his way home. Only he wasn't. Just as Gary began climbing out the window a sharp piece of wood caught him in the shoulder and knocked him out onto the street. "Fuck..." He quickly picked himself off the ground and looked back inside the gunstore. His fight wasn't over, he had one opponet left. Inside glaring back at him was the level 3, minus about half its flesh. "Jesus Christ... what the holy fuck ARE you...?" Gary gasped as he took a few steps back and put a hand on his now bleeding shoulder. The level 3 was still able to move, but just barely and very slowly. As it walked towards the living human it opened its mouth in a grotesque smile. It was almost too horrifying to look at, Gary couldn't believe that this thing had once been a person. Many of its organs fell out of its nearly skeletal body as it moved closer, not that it cared, its own wounds meant nothing, it only goal was to exterminate the living at any cost. Gary was about to run when he noticed the small glowing pentagram on its forehead. "Some kind of weakspot...?" He thought to himself. He laid his handgun on the ground and used both his hands to aim the hunting rifle. "I hope I'm right..." As soon as Gary had a sure shot he fired his one and only bullet at his shambling foe. The hit connected full-force and exited out the back of the level 3's skull. For a moment the zombie stood motionless... before falling over dead. Gary took a minute to catch his breath, pick up his handgun, and continue on towards the bridge. When he got there he noticed something off to the side of was a sign that stated that there was a church on the otherside of the bridge and that some of the cars along the way were re-supply locations marked by an R in a circle. Up head there was indeed a minivan with such a symbol on its front hood. Should Gary check it out?
11121121111.title: Gary's final showdown?

choices: Run over to the church
Run over to his house
111211211111.content:
A rifle with only 2 bullets, a small hand gun, and 4 containers of purple slime. For Gary, this would last him throughout the night. After that, he might as well say his prayers. By the looks of it, he'll be stuck in this hell-hole for much longer then that. The smartest thing to do at the moment was check the cars for possible supplies.

He scanned each car, looking for any sort of defense or weapon. Within at least every car was a gun or 2. Sadly most of them were oversized or overly damaged to be used against zombies. They would just slow him down while being chased by some rapid level twos, or weigh him down during a stalker ambush attack. One car held a duffle bag filled with food, a first aid kit, and a uzi. It was light enough to move around with. This was a keeper. That and a shotgun was mainly what he found.

Making his way to the church, Gary spotted a minivan in the corner of his eye. It didn't hold any guns, any supplies, nothing.Inside was all vacant besides the old blood-stains on the seat. On the windshield though was a letter, with a stuffed Teddy bear next to it. Curious, Gary walked over to the car and grabbed the note. A picture of a 5 year old boy holding that same exact Teddy bear. On the note it just said "Please bring him back" in bold red pen. He looked at the picture. A small innocent little child, holding a tiny stuff bear. Gary he felt a small tug at his heart. He always wanted children with his wife, Shelly, but . . . He just had some problems preventing so. He folded the note and stuffed it into his pocket. He then grabbed the bear. Through the cold endless nights, the bear still stayed warm. As if that one bear held everyone's hope. That boy was out there, he knew it. And Gary was going to find him and everyone else. He stuffed this bear into his duffle bag.

After looting all the re-supply cars, Gary took view of his current surroundings. From a faraway view, he could see his house, un-touched and not all damaged. There was a possibility his wife was still safe inside. Simply, he could just take a 8 minute walk over there, talk to Shelly, and hope that she’ll be ok with helping him search for survivors. Yet again, the journey over there would be extremely dangerous. Level ones, twos, threes, sirens, vampires, diggers, beast, any zombie could just come out of nowhere and eat his brains out. Its probably best to just hope she’s fine for now and come back to his house once he’s more protected. The church might be the best place to rest a bit. Already, he heard the groans and footsteps of oncoming zombies behind him. Gary quickly decides to . . .
111211211111.title: Guns and Teddy Bears

choices: He wakes up to Betty Winters
He wakes up to Eric Dressil
1112112111111.content:
In a burst of action, Gary makes run towards the church. In his mad dash, his foot snaps a twig. The cracking sound was enough to alarm a group of 5 level twos that were trailing behind him. He heard a loud ear-splitting screech and fast moving footsteps chasing after him. Gary began to freak out and run even faster. He didn’t have the time to light any of his slime containers or pull out one of his guns. His survival now depended on his legs. And after at least 3 leg transplants, he wasn't the best runner.

“Fuck, fuck, fuck, fuck!” he muttered to himself, now running for his life. Quickly turning his head around to the zombies, he noticed they were but just a few yards away from him, outstretching there long sharp claws, aimed right at his back. A foot or 2 more, one of them would be able to leap right at him and tackle him down. What had use to be average human being was now a crazed savage hunter, and Gary was the prey. Fortunately, the church was located more so uphill, so it made it harder for the zombies to catch up. Unfortunately, so was it hard for Gary.

Constantly was Gary tripping over his own feet, only to quickly get back up before the zombies took they’re opportunity. Sweat ran down his face, his eyes still trained on the Church. He was getting so much more closer to safety. Dodging stray cars and jumping over random bulks of debris, he ran towards the entrance. Gritting his teeth, he tried to endure the lingering ache in his lower thighs and kept running like hell towards the church entrance. (Ironic, no?)

His legs were about as ready to give out. His old weary vision turned blurry. As Gary reach more flat ground, he was already tired and out of breath from climbing up the rather steep hill. By now, he was only 10 feet away from the entrance of the church. He gave out a meek grin. Unconsciously though, he was starting slow his pace down. He already easily forgotten how much his life was in danger. The level twos seeing this as an advantage made a sudden lunge towards him with a vicious amount of force, bringing him down to the ground. Gary let out painful yelp as his face collided with the ground floor. Stings of agony went up his back from their digging claws. The church entrance was just a foot away. A foot more and he could of lived. There was nothing he could do. If death was to come, then death he would accept. He closed his eyes.

Right after closing his eyes, he heard someone yell out, “Back off you ugly bastards!” and 5 guns shots. There was a chorus of shrieks and then sound of falling bodies. Gary would of opened his eyes to see who his savior was, but at the time, he was too weak and tired to do so. He felt someone walk over to him and sigh. After doing so, he was picked up and propped up against someone, being guided into the church. By then, he was already asleep.
1112112111111.title: Them ugly bastards

choices: Offer to do anything he can to help out
Ask if they will give him his stuff back if he helps them
11121121111111.content: After hours of peaceful sleep Gary woke up in a sleeping bag next to the altar of the church where a young girl was sitting. As Gary started to get up bright sunlight shining in through the damaged windows overhead caught him in the eyes. He moved his hand to shield himself and stood up in his bed. There was a pain in his back from the wounds he had suffered the night before, but it was nothing he couldn't deal with. "Oh, you're awake!" The girl said as she looked over at him. "Yeah, are you the one who saved me last night?" Gary asked as he looked around for his stuff. "Me and Rob." She said as she pointed to a large man standing by a window near the door. "If you want to thank somebody, you should think him. All I did was help carry you inside, he's the one who killed those level 2's that were chasing you." Gary looked around the room and tried to see where his stuff was. Nowhere in sight. "Excuse me, but did you put my stuff somewhere?" Gary asked. "I don't see it anywhere..." "Your stuff was taken to the supply closent, well, except for your coat, that's over on the one of the bleachers." The girl said as she got up and walked over to him. "Anyone who wants to take refuge here has to turn over anything that might be of value. Everyone gives what they can and takes what they need. You were brought inside and had your wounds treated as best as we could manage so we took your weapons as a sort of payment." The girl held out her hand and offered to help Gary up. "You're also welcome to breakfast when its ready, and if you want, I could show you around and explain the rules." Gary was upset at hearing that everything he had scavenged was taken, but decided that he'd worry about that later, right now he was hungry and tired from the previous day. He took her hand and got to his feet. "I'm Betty, by the way." The girl said. "Nice to meet you." Gary smiled and introduced himself as well. "I'm Gary, I was a doctor at the hospital from across the bridge." Upon hearing this Betty gave him a surprised and excited look. "A doctor?! Really?! We've needed a doctor since we lost West 3 days ago!" Gary couldn't believe his ears, it appeared he now had a bargaining chip he could use to get his stuff back. Then again, they DID save his life and give him shelter, maybe doing things their way was the better option... What should he do?
11121121111111.title: Awake and alive

choices: Gary finishes his meal and begins treating the churches patients
Gary finishes his meal and leaves the church
111211211111111.content: "I promise I'll do what I can for your sick and injured." Gary said as he picked up his coat and put it back on. "Even in situations like this, I can't ignore by hippocratic oath." Betty smiled and led him over to where Rob was standing. "Hey Rob!" She called as she walked up. "Gary here's finally awake, but even better then that, he's a doctor!" Rob turned around to face Gary and held out his hand. "A doctor, eh? Good. We've needed one for days. I'm Rob, the guy who's in charge here. Follow all the rules and we'll get along just fine." Gary shook the larger mans hand asked him just what the rules were. Rob let go of his hand and his expression turned serious. "There are only three rules, but breaking any of them will result in a severe penalty. One, you give what you can and take what you need. Two, no harming anyone else and no fighting. Three, you do what I say, when I say. No questions asked. Do we understand one another?" Gary nodded his head in confirmation. "I see then, in that case welcome. I'm sure I be able to find you something do in a little while, but for now you need to eat. Breakfast will be ready shortly." Gary thanked the man and took a seat near the front of the church. The past few days had been so hectic and unbelievable and he hadn't had much time to stop and catch his breath. He had so many questions he wanted answered. Was his wife okay? Where did the zombies come from? Will this ever end? He was so deep in thought that he barely noticed the hot bowl of oatmeal that had been placed on his lap. "Eat up." A familiar voice said. Gary looked over to see Betty sitting next to him. "Here you go." She said as she handed him a spoon. Gary took it and looked down at his food. It was nice to finally have a hot meal again. "Thanks." He said as he took the first bite of food he'd had in days.
111211211111111.title: A new day of hope

choices: See where the carrier takes him
He attempts to shoot it off
1112112111112.content:
"Screw it, I'm seeing my wife!" he thought himself. It had been long enough that he had seen his home and he desperately wanted see Shelly, dead or not. Maybe they're even somethings that he could pick up while there.

He walked over to his house, ignoring his chances of being attacked. He urged on towards, seemingly not hearing the stalking footsteps of possibly not just one being. The low growls that were not all human. He didn't notice the path of burning steps trailing his path. Nor the wavering red eyes that focused on his every little move. Worry came over Gary. Despite the feeling of terrible danger, he didn't bother to look around. His mind was just playing tricks on him. After days of fighting off zombie hordes, it's the only thing he can think about. The sounds were just his imagination . . . Right?

Gary just moved on, focusing his thoughts on his wife. It was extremely hard to do while with the lurking feeling of something horrible was about to happen. Perhaps Gary was just being paranoid, thinking every coming second was a zombie attack. Yet again-

He immediatly stopped in his tracks. His hands traced over to the shotgun he had hung over himself, gripping it tightly, prepared for whatever was ahead. He quickly turned around towards the noises, pointing his gun at it's direction. Nothing. There was just nothing. The moon was still high up shining down. Trees waved around in the nature reserve right next to him. At that was really there was the long winding road and a gray fog. He turned around, giving out a sigh. Was he getting so old that he was thinking of imaginary zombies? All that was there was fog. Was fog really all that-

His thoughts had paused. "Wait." he thought to himself. "Fog. There wasn't any fog before." The mechanics in his brain started to work together before coming to a big realization. "OH SHI-"

Before he could turn around again, a vampire had lunge towards him, knocking him down. Out of the cloud, some level 2s, a stalker, and a pyro had emerged out of complete nothing. He could swear that underneath the veil of shawdows, he could see a pair of four glowing eyes smiling wickedly at him. It was a nightmare.

Gary had to quickly react. He faced towards the vampire on top of him, preparing to bite his neck. He kicked it off, since it was surprisingly light. He scramble back up, his mind still jumbled at what to do. Looking up, some level 2s were running towards him. His hands found the shotgun, barely being able to hold it up right due to the sweat on his hands. As one them came to close, Gary just automatically took a good hard swipe at it's head, completely braining the zombie and killing it. He was able to shoot out the other level 2s. Just barely in arms reach. After all the level 2s were dead, he searched around for the vampire. He spotted coming towards him, with a stalker by it's side, getting read to make another lunge. As the 2 killers ran towards him, he looked down at the zombies that lay before him. They were highly flammable. Without a second to spare, Gary had taken out a lighted match, and dropped it on the corpse and dodged out of the way. The two predators were already in mid-air before they could realize that there was a ring of fire. The hot flames had caught on to there skin, progressively burning it off. They howled in agonized pain, running around in madness, not being able to shake it off. Gary heard the screeches of other zombies within the cloud, running away from the scene, no longer having the desire to kill. Gary watched as fire engulfed the area, leaving the burnt bodies dead on the ground. It was a sick image, but he couldn't help but feel a bit satisfied at his work. But there seemed to be something else missing.

From orange burning flames, a figure still walked towards him. A pyro, immune to fire, had mixed in with the fire and was still fully alive. Gary would smacked himself in the face if he wasn't terrified. It didn't seem to at all lunge, run, or attack him. It just walked towards him, not even really wanting to kill him. The evil smile on it's face, however, told otherwise. Gary pointed his shotgun at it, not knowing what else to do. Bullets aren't enough to take it down. He just hoped it wouldn't come closer. 

Luckily, it didn't. It just stood there tilting it's head at Gary. After a few seconds, it had turned it's head towards the sky, shouting out giberish that he couldn't at all undertand. Gary still stood, now confused. He still got the feeling that it wasn't all for good intentions.

The pyro looked back down at Gary, it's grin mocking and rather smug. It turned around, walking into the fire and dissapearing into the night, leaving Gary even more confused then before. Was he just spared? He didn't understand what the hell just went down. He kept his gun in the duffle bag and just went back to walking off. Then suddenly, he heard the flapping off wings. The next moment, he had been carried 30ft up in the air.

Apparently, pyro's buddy the carrier had come to play.
1112112111112.title: Pyro's revenge

choices: Upstream
Downstream
11121121111122.content: Gary watched in horror as his house moved farther and farther away as this new monster carried him higher and higher into the night sky. When the carrier reached an altitude of about 200 feet it stopped moving up and changed direction. It was flying back towards the bridge Gary had just come from. "What?! No!" Gary shouted when he realized this. "I'm so close to home! My wife...!" Before the Carrier could get any closer to its destination Gary began to struggle causing it to veer off course and fall lower. Gary still had his shotgun in his hand, but the Carrier had it gripped with one of its own hands, preventing Gary from aiming it. As the two wrestled in the sky they came to the front gate of the nature preserve... and past it as each tried to gain the upper hand. Finally, Gary had an idea to turn the tide in his favor, it would be risky, but it was his only hope. He let go of the shotgun and quickly opened the duffle bag still around his shoulders just wide enough to grab something from the inside. It was the uzi he had picked up earlier, and it was fully loaded. Before the Carrier could tell what was going on, it had one of its front wings severed by a stream of bullets that seemed to come out of nowhere. The monster thrashed about as it tried to stay in the air, only to collide into a tree and and plummet downwards. By this point the Carrier was dead and Gary was holding on for dear life as branch after branch snapped under him on his way down. He was soon thrust off of the tree after the Carrier rolled off a large branch and began falling much faster towards the ground... Gary said a quick prayer in his head and braced himself for impact on the hard earth below. The very next thing Gary felt wasn't the ground, however, it was much softer and far more cold. The Carrier he was still holding onto had managed to land right in the creek that passed by the tree they had hit. Gary felt his whole body shake as it made contact with the water. It hurt like hell, but thankfully, the corpse of the dead zombie absorbed most of the impact from the fall. The force of hitting the water briefly submerged Gary and quick brought him back to full alertness. He let go of his fallen enemy and stood up. The creek was only about waist-deep and quite muddy, but Gary couldn't have cared less. Even if it had been raw sewage, it had saved his life and he was grateful for that. He took a deep breath of the chilly night air and reloaded his uzi. He looked around and saw that the banks of the creek were too steep to climb back up safely. A little farther upstream was a small stone bridge with a metal ladder attached and beyond that Gary could make out some sort of small building, possibly a ranger station. The opposite direction seemed to lead to a lake or pond as the creek grew wider as it went on. It was also downstream which would make moving a little easier as the water would be flowing with him. Which way sounds better?
11121121111122.title: Up the creek without a paddle

choices: He heads left towards the building
He heads right towards the front gate
111211211111221.content: Gary began slowly making his way upstream as best he could. The flowing water slowed him down quite a bit, but he was still able to make decent progress while keeping an eye out for danger. When he finally got to the bridge and was about to climb out of the numbing water he caught sight of something glowing up ahead, just under the bridge. Several red orbs seemed to be moving through the water towards him. Gary knew immediately that they were zombies, yet, they were also unlike any other zombie he'd encountered before. They were obviously swimming in the water, something Gary had thought was impossible as any other zombie that had tried sank like a rock. As they got closer Gary could make out their small forms from the shadows they cast in the moonlit water. They were smaller then most humans and were vaguely frog-like. Once they drew close Gary opened fire and killed two instantly, their bodies floating to the surface like rag dolls. Not wanting to waste any ammo he allowed them to swim up to him before shooting. His plan seemed to be working well, they apparently lacked a ranged attack and were only a danger if got a chance to latch onto him with their teeth, a chance he wouldn't give them. After about a minute of one-sided combat only two Swimmers were left. "Come and get some, you freaking fish people!" Gary shouted as they submerged themselves in what Gary thought was an attempt to hide. What he didn't know was that this was all just part of their plan. One of them surfaced a mere 5 feet away from him and shot something into his face. Taken by surprise, Gary fired his gun wildly and heard one of his shots connect with flesh, now only one swimmer was left. He opened his eyes only to find everything was pitched black, no moonlight, no creek, not even the gun in his hands. He had been rendered blind by the last Swimmers suicide attack. Struggling to remain calm, Gary listened desperately for the remaining zombie. He could hear water splashing, the wind blowing, and the sounds of the flowing creek, but couldn't tell where his final attacker was. He would have to make a guess when the Swimmer decided to attack and try to hit it with the ammo he had left. He heard loud splashing moving towards him from behind... closer... closer... this was it... Gary spun around just as the Swimmer leaped out of the water to take a bite out of his face and opened fire. He heard 4 shots ring out before the gun went silent. He was out of ammo. The last zombie collided with Gary's chest and knocked him under the water, his eyesight returning just in time to see the night sky disappear under the murky depths of what would surely be his watery grave. Something amazing had happened though. The Swimmer didn't bite Gary, not only that, it was dead! Its body began floating off of him and up towards the surface, allowing Gary to resurface himself and catch his breath. It seemed one of his last 4 bullets had caught the bastard right between the eyes as it made its last jump. The Swimmers were all dead, Gary had survived his encounter with this new type of zombie and would hopefully live to see another day. He put his uzi back into his duffel bag and climbed the ladder onto the bridge. It was nice to finally be out of the water, but Gary had no time to enjoy his momentary success. He had a new decision to make... travel down the the path to his left towards the building he saw earlier OR take the right path towards the front gate.
111211211111221.title: They're in the water!

choices: Yes, it could be zombies... or survivors!
No, ignore it and keep exploring
1112112111112211.content: That building off in the distance must be a ranger station of some sort, what else would be out here? Gary began walking down the narrow dirt trail slowly and carefully as it was hard to see in the dark. The fact that his clothes were soaking wet, freezing cold, and clinging uncomfortably to his skin didn't help either. Nevertheless, he didn't gripe or make any snide comments. He was going to get to that building come hell or high water, and seeing as he'd already dealt with the water, hell was all that was left. It seemed he had a little luck left, though, as he didn't encounter a single Beast on his way there. The building had been a little closer then Gary had though, but it was indeed a ranger station like he predicted. There was a jeep out front with blood all over the front and on the tires, but the keys weren't in the ignition. Gary did find a machete in the front seat though, so that was something. "People really should lock their doors." He said as he swung the blade a few times in front of him. "Guess I better see what we have inside there." He opened the door to the ranger station (which also wasn't locked) and stepped inside. The lights were out and he could barely see, but he could make out the shape of a flashlight sitting on a nearby desk. He picked it up and switched it on. A soft white beam of light immediately illuminated the small room he was in, it wasn't much, but it helped. Gary was about to explore the rest of the room when he thought he heard something move around outside. Should he go check it out?
1112112111112211.title: Wet, cold, and dark...

choices: Gary continues hiking up the trail that brought him here
Gary walks back to the creek and crosses the bridge
11121121111122111.content:
Just to be careful Gary shone his light out the nearby window to see if anything was moving. After a minute of searching the dense foliage and finding nothing he decided to step outside. He opened and closed the door slowly and kept his machete poised to attack. He tried to listen for sounds of movement, but the only noise came from the nearby creek he had climbed out of. He walked around to the other side of the ranger station and looked over the thick weeds and bushes. Nothing was here but him. It began to rain softly as he walked back around to the main door. Gary felt more then a little unnerved now. He KNEW he had heard something out here. He shook his head as he came back around to the front of the building, feeling he had wasted valuable time on a wild goose chase. As it turned out he was wrong, very wrong. As soon as he got back to the door he noticed something laying on the ground next to the jeep. It was covered in mud and seemed to be crawling along the ground slowly. Gary was careful to keep a safe distance as he walked over to it. "Hello...?" He called out over the rain, which seemed to be picking up. The thing crawled a little closer and dropped to the ground unable to keep moving. It appeared to pose no threat so Gary got close enough to shine his flashlight on it. It took only a moment for Gary to realize it was a human, or at least what was left of one. It was one of the parks many rangers, a young man in his early 20's. The poor guy was bleeding so bad that his wounds were actually starting to cover up the mud that covered him from head to toe. Gary knelt down beside him and pushed him over onto his back.


His front side looked no better, it even took Gary a few seconds to notice that he had blonde hair, what with the bloody grime covering it. The man probably should have been dead at that point, so it came as quite a surprise when he actually spoke. "T-they are heading towards t-the city." He moaned. "Y-you have to get o-out of here." He struggled to raise his hand to grab Gary's shoulder. "Escape..." The man coughed up some blood as he tried to keep talking, making his next few words non-understandable. "Easy!" Gary said as he tried to comfort the dying man. "You don't want to make it any worse than it is." He knew there was nothing he could do, but couldn't bring himself to tell him how bad it looked. The man let out a weak laugh as he took his hand off Gary's shoulder. "I k-know I'm done f-for. I was ambushed and b-barely escaped. D-don't follow the p-path t-that leads towards the city, t-they are..." The man fell silent. Upon checking his pulse Gary confirmed that he had died of blood loss. "Shit..." He whispered as he wiped the mud from the rangers ID badge that had fallen out of his pocket. It was hard to see, but he was able to read the name written on it. "Robert B. Clarke." He read aloud. "I'm sorry I couldn't save you..." With that Gary put the ID back into the mans pocket and drug his body back up to the door of the ranger station and disappeared inside for a few minutes. He emerged a short time later with a new handgun (fully load which he had found sitting on a desk) and a thick blanket. He wrapped Robert up and drug him inside and laid him next to a table. Before leaving and heading back out into the growing storm he grabbed a piece of paper from a clipboard and wrote on it. He laid it on the table next to Roberts corpse and Left. It simply read:

"There are two spare handguns in the drawer of the desk next to the bulletin board. I don't mind if you take them, but please pay your respects to Robert B. Clarke, the man wrapped in the blanket. He was trying to help his fellow survivors even as he lay dying. May he rest in peace."
11121121111122111.title: The calm before the storm

choices: He heads left
He heads right
111211211111221111.content: The rain showed no signs of letting up any time soon and in fact grew stronger as Gary made his way through the nature preserve. The machete had proven quite useful in not only clearing away bushes and foliage, but made killing the small zombie rodents he encountered a breeze. Too bad he hadn't gotten as much use out of the flashlight before it died. Oh well, at least he could sort of tell where he was going. After over an hour of walking Gary finally began to grow tired, but pushed himself to keep going despite his injuries and the freezing rain. He was going to get out of here and see his wife again, he had to. The early hours of the morning came and went as he moved along the trail almost aimlessly. The sun had risen, but the storm did not let up, giving Gary just enough light to see a few feet in front of him. The way things were going he almost expected it to start snowing. "Heh, I don't think I'd be surprised if hell itself had frozen over by now." He said softly to himself. Just when his legs were about to give out from walking all morning he came to a chain-link fence covered in vines and weeds. He had finally found his way out of the preserve. Gary had a bit of trouble getting over it, but with the help of some of the vines, made it over without hurting himself. He walked a little further and soon came to a road on the edge of the forest he had been hiking through. He hopped over the flooded ditch in front of it and looked both ways. The heavy rain masked both directions and he was too tired to wait for it to stop. If he didn't find somewhere to rest soon he'd surely pass out...
111211211111221111.title: Hard rain

choices: Something breaks into the house
Gary awakens with a fever
1112112111112211111.content:
Gary shrugged and and began walking down the road as the wind blew through the trees. He had chosen to go left, hopefully there would be a resting place waiting for him a little further up the road. Ten short minutes pasted with the howling wind kicking up rain into Gary's face and the thunderous sounds of the storm deafening his ears. He was about to give up hope when he caught sight of a building up ahead. A road with a sidewalk on both sides connected to the main road up ahead, apparently leading to a small grouping of houses on the edge of the city. Gary walked down the sidewalk slowly, glad to get his soggy shoes out of the flooded street. He looked around lazily as he moved, his weary, sleep-deprived eyes barely registering anything of interest as he moved by the houses. Many of the buildings looked fairly aged, even the street lamps seemed old fashioned. The only modern thing Gary could see was a large building up ahead that he didn't have time to explore at the moment. He didn't even bother reading the large sign that overlooked it as he searched for a place to rest. At least half of the houses had boarded up windows and doors, most of the other half were ether broken in to or outright destroyed by a combination of zombie attacks and the weather.


Gary saw one house that had its door hanging off its hinges that was barely damaged and had few broken windows. The inside was plenty damp from the storm, but looked warm and inviting enough to rest in. Gary smiled as he moved aside the door and walked inside. No dead bodies, no zombies, and the downstairs lights still worked. This had been a good decision. Gary walked by the countless pictures of old farmhouses and green, wide open fields with a feeling of homesickness. This house was much like his and he had been so close to getting home... he wondered if Shelly was okay. He pushed the thought out of his mind as he ascended the stairs. The upstairs was much like the downstairs, oddly sweet smelling and full of old rustic pictures of times long past. He opened the door to a bedroom and was pleased to find no bodies (dead OR alive) and an unbroken window. He took off his wet coat and shoes and sat his bag of supplies on a nearby chair. His undershirt and pants were still wet, but by this point Gary was too tired to care. He got in bed and pulled the covers over his head as he listened to the sound of the pouring rain outside. He didn't take long to drift off... but would wake up hours later in a cold sweat...
1112112111112211111.title: Shelter and homesickness

choices: He finds supplies and weapons.
He only finds supplies...
11121121111122111112.content:
Gary awoke with a fever. He touched his forehead and it wasn't that hot. He opened his bag and took out a bottle of medicine and drank a little bit, he felt a bit better and he got up. He covered the bottle and grabbed his bag as he packed his wet coat in it. It was afternoon and no zombies seemed to be wandering outside the cold, wet street.

He searched around the house to get a axe which was for emergency events. He got out of the house and walked along the burned street. Many cars were crashed and dead bodies were lying on the cars. Gary picked up a pistol and looked at it. "No... useless crap." He threw it on the ground. A zombie shuffled towards him when it heard the noise. He threw the axe and it landed at the zombie's brain. Blood flew out like a miniature fountain and it fell. He picked the axe back up and decided to search for stuff at the supermarket he had seen earlier.
11121121111122111112.title: Sick and Tired.

choices: Gary tells the truth
Gary lies
111211211111221111121.content:
The rain had slacked off greatly by this point, but Gary was still glad to get inside. The fact that there were no zombies here was a plus too. He walked to the back of the store first to check out the pharmacy. Even if all he had was a slight cold he wanted to stay prepared. He took a few small bottles of medicine from the back shelves and put them into his bag, which was starting to get full. "Only a little room left..." Gary said as he left the pharmacy. He took out the uzi he had gotten the previous day at the bridge and set it on a shelf behind some cans of beans. "I have no use for this if its out of ammo, maybe it can help someone else." Gary took the labels off a few cans of beans so that they made a large R shape on the shelf. After a few minutes of looting Gary had enough food and water to last a couple of days. He didn't want to spend too much time here, lest he give the zombies a chance to surround him. Gary thought about leaving with what he had when he noticed that the door to the storage room in the back was open. Since he hadn't seen many zombies outside he decided it couldn't hurt to at least check it out. He slung his duffel bag over his arm and walked inside careful to avoid trapping himself in a corner in case any zombies were there. The shelves were all lined with cardboard boxes of various shapes and sizes, some of which were laying opened and and empty on the floor.


The one thing that stood out was a large gun case sitting in the back of the room. Upon opening it Gary found a high grade military sniper rifle. Gary took it carefully out of its case and checked the scope, it worked perfectly. The only downside was that there wasn't any more ammo for it laying around... once it was used up that was it. Plus it was too big to fit in his bag... he would have to leave something else behind if he took it. Just as Gary was about to come to a decision a lone figure came walking into the back room without Gary noticing. The figure quickly drew a knife and began sneaking up on him... closer... closer... A sharp cold piece of metal had found its way to Gary's throat, the slightest movement would slice open his neck. Once Gary had noticed this he stopped moving and waited to hear what his capturer had to say. "Good, you seem smart enough not to try anything stupid. So, tell me, just why did you come in here and what do you think you are doing with my sniper rifle?" Gary thought for a moment about lying, there's no way this psycho would believe everything that had happened to him in the past 24 hours... but could he make up something believable? "Well...?" The figure asked again as they pressed the knife a little harder against Gary's bare neck. A single drop of blood fell to his shoulder.
111211211111221111121.title: Not quite empty...

choices: Introduce themselves.
Remain Silent and still work with Gary...
1112112111112211111211.content:
"I came to look for weapons and supplies, and found this." Gary told the pyscho. "I woke up with a slight fever and...." The pyscho started growling, dropping the knife. Gary quickly held the sniper rifle in his hands and blasted it's head off. It looks like he had turned into a zombie, judging from the wounds on his chest. Gary decided to hold the rifle instead of putting it in his bag. It may make getting around a bit more difficult, but this way he could take it with him. He quickly walked out just in time to see three zombies getting shot by someone, they fell and Gary looked. He ran towards him but a large growl echoed and a large zombie grabbed him. Gary stared with horror as blood splattered on the a nearby wall and the road. Gary went back inside the store and used the back door and ran for his life towards a lighthouse off in the distance.

The lighthouse was still flashing lights. It seemed that it was operated by someone as shadows kept moving at the glass panel. Gary knocked on the door and looked in.

It opened and he entered. He closed the door and locked it, then went up the stairs. At the top a sniper and a person who was operating the lighthouse was there. "Who are you?" Asked the sniper as he fired a round into a zombie. The blood could be heard splattering. "I'm Gary, I'm a doctor." Gary replied. The person operating the lighthouse told him everything.

They used this lighthouse to attract boats to rescue them or signal helicopters. Many people had tried to use boats to escape the zombies in the large lake nearby. Too bad they didn't know about Swimmers yet, otherwise they may have reconsidered their options.

Gary soon heard a large bang on the door down stairs. He and the unknowed person barricaded the staircase. The survivors soon..
1112112111112211111211.title: Ooops, that seemed a bit hard.

choices: They send out the person with the least amount of sniping training (Gary)
One of them volunteer to go and Gary provides support from the lighthouse
11121121111122111112111.content:
Once the outside was successfully closed off the man took the time to introduce himself and his partner. "I'm Matt." He said as he shook Gary's hand. "That other guy, the sniper, is Kevin. Come on, we should get back up top and help him." The two made their way back up the stairs and Matt greeted Kevin as they walked over to the outer railing. "We got the bottom secured, no way out... but no way in either." Kevin nodded and handed him a spare hunting rifle and pointed out towards the lake. "We got at least one survivor out there, trapped on a boat like the others we found." Gary and Matt looked out over the treetops out towards the lake where, sure enough, a large boat sat motionless on the water. "How do you know if anyone is still alive on it?" Gary asked as he sat his duffel bag down on a nearby fold-up chair. "During the storm earlier I saw someone jump overboard. Since then I've been checking it once every half hour or so. Just ten minutes ago I saw a woman looking through a glass window on a door. She had some blood or something on her shirt, but she was still alive. She must have locked herself inside the ship a few days ago. If we don't do something soon she'll probably die."


Gary walked back over to look at the boat again. It was fairly large, enough to hold several people on board. "Maybe she isn't alone." Gary said as he looked through the scope of his sniper rifle. "That ship could easily carry a dozen people or more. For all we know there could be several more lives at stake then we know of." He zoomed in as much as the gun's scope would allow. The door to the room where the woman had been seen looked sturdy, but there were several Swimmers on the upper deck. Gary knew they were waiting for anyone inside desperate or panicked enough to rush out and become easy prey. "We'd better do something soon." Gary said as he lowered his sniper rifle and turned towards his 2 new companions. "Any ideas?" The two looked at each other and nodded. "I got one." Kevin said as he reloaded his own sniper rifle. "One of us is gonna have to go out there while the other two provide support from here. There's a jetski parked in the boathouse down by the dock. The keys were there when I checked it a few days ago, but I don't know how much gas it has. Whoever goes might end up stuck out there... or worse, stranded in the middle of the lake alone and helpless." The men looked at each other before turning to get another look at the boat, it wasn't going anywhere anytime soon. "Sounds good..." Gary said uneasily. "But how do we decide who goes?"
11121121111122111112111.title: Snipe or rescue?

choices: Wielding duel handguns and taking them by surprise
Meeting up with whoever's inside the boat and teaming up with them
111211211111221111121111.content:
After a few minutes of discussion it was decided that Gary would be the big hero doing the rescue. After all, he had no prior sniping experience and nobody wanted to get shot in the head.
