Once he was well supplied the barrier downstairs was moved aside just long enough to allow him to get out and begin his rescue mission. "As soon as we get the barricade back up we'll head up top and give you some covering fire if you need it. Good luck!" Matt called as he closed the door. Gary took a deep breath and began walking down towards the docks. He would have to be careful, he couldn't run from anything as the ground was a slippery mix of mud and dirty water from the rain. His feet made sloshing noises as he stepped in puddle after puddle, all of them much deeper then they looked. Gary looked up past the trees towards the sky for a moment to get his mind off the wet ground and his waterlogged shoes.


It was still somewhat cloudy, but the sun was out now and even in the shade of the trees its light kept things warm. "At least I don't have to do this in a storm..." Gary said with a cough. It seemed his cold was starting to come back. After a short while he came to the docks and was glad to see the boathouse was empty upon entering and the jetski still had its keys. He put the handgun he had out back into his duffel bag, it seemed there was no use for it... at least not yet. He got onto the jetski and turned the keys, it hummed to life and Gary rode slowly out of the boathouse. He had never been on a jetski before and was careful not to do anything that might tip it over. To his relief he came to the boat in less then a minute and wouldn't have to drive any longer. He turned the keys back and shut it off once he had gotten to the side of the ship. As quietly as possible he stood up and climbed onto the deck of the boat. He took a quick glance around and couldn't believe his luck, there were no Swimmers on this side of the boat! Gary took advantage of this by...
111211211111221111121111.title: An unexpected advantage

choices: "Yes... good luck."
"Yes... let me come with you! It'll be too dangerous by yourself!"
1112112111112211111211112.content:
Gary decided to get to the survivor(s) first, that way they could deal with the Swimmers together. Experience had shown Gary they could be crafty and underestimating them was a bad idea. He walked silently over to the door with the window and looked inside. There was a woman sitting up against the wall sobbing, her shirt indeed covered with blood that must have belonged to someone else, no human could survive losing that much blood. Along with the woman there was a small girl sitting below the window on the other side of the room who looked to be about ten years old. The rest of the inside was obscured by the short narrow hallway that connected the room to the door. Just as Gary was about to tap on the glass to get their attention the little girl noticed him. They stared at each other for a few seconds before the girl got up and ran over to let him in. "Huh, what is it?" Came another young voice, this one a boy's. Gary opened the unlocked door and quickly got inside before closing it back and locking it. "Hello sweetie, who else is here with you?" Gary asked as he followed the girl into the room. It looked really nice in here, everything from sizable paintings to little models of ships and such lined the place as if it was trying to show off. Even with the bloodstains, Gary doubted anyone he knew would decline spending a night on this boat. He was so caught up admiring the furnishings, he almost didn't notice the young boy and teenage looking girl who were staring at him with surprise.


"Did you hear me mister?" The little girl said as she tugged at his sleeve. "That's Timmy, by brother and the older girl is Amber, who's my cousin." Gary snapped back to reality and realized he was being rude. "Oh, hello, its a pleasure to meet you both." He said as he turned to the woman sitting against the wall. She seemed as if she didn't even notice him come in. "Er, who's this?" He asked as he walked over to her. "That's mommy." The little girl and boy said together. "She's been sad since our sister died...." The little girl added. Gary felt another wave of sadness wash over him when he heard these words. "My god... I'm... I'm so sorry." The little girl bowed her head. "Her name was Lily, she was only two years old." The woman's head shot up upon hearing the name of her lost child, a look of utter rage upon her face. "They took her... THOSE FUCKING BASTARDS KILLED MY BABY!!!!! WHY?!!!!! SHE WAS ONLY TWO YEARS OLD!!!!!" A fresh stream of tears began flowing down her face. "They took her... its not fair... first my husband, now my youngest daughter... Damn them! DAMN THEM!!!!!" She buried her face in her knees and refused to talk anymore. Gary felt a tear slide down his cheek. He had never had children of his own, but was sure he had an idea of the pain it caused when they were gone. He silently prayed he never had to endure the same torture. "Hey mister, why are you crying...?" The little girl asked when she noticed his watery eyes and reddened face. "It nothing... I have a slight cold." He replied as he wiped his eyes on his shirt sleeve. "By the way... I never got your name did I?" The little girl smiled at finally being asked her name. "I'd thought you'd never ask! Its Clare, nice name isn't it?!" She shouted happily. "Its a lovely name." Gary said as he patted her head.


"Now... I'm sure you know why I'm here. I've got some spare handguns and ammo in my bag here, courtesy of some new friends. Once I've cleared out the Swimmers we can get to the engine room and start this thing. Then we'll head for the lighthouse." The two children and the older girl looked at him in surprise and confusion. "Swimmers?" Timmy asked. "What are those?" Gary was himself surprised they didn't know what he was talking about. "Those things that look like some kind of messed up fish creature. Those are Swimmers... at least that's what I call them." He reached into his bag and pulled out a handgun along with some ammo. "Here, Amber." The older girl took the gun and looked it over. "It this thing... real?" Gary nodded. "You're the the second oldest person here and you seem responsible enough, so I need you watch over the children while I clear the deck. Once all the zombies are dead I can start this thing up and we'll all get out of here." The little girl crossed her arms and the little boy made an angry face. "Hey we arn't children!" He said angrily. "Okay then,,," Gary said as he walked back towards the door. "You're kids, and good kids do what they are told. You don't wanna be bad do you?" Both shook their heads. "We'll be good mister, please save us!" They said together. "Don't worry, I intend to." Gary said as he put a hand on the door. Just as he was about to leave, however, Amber came running over to him. He took his hand off the knob and turned back around. "Yes...? Is there anything you wanted to tell me before I left?"
1112112111112211111211112.title: Tears, sadness, and hope...

choices: Gunfire
A loud scream
11121121111122111112111122.content:
"What?" Gary asked in a surprised tone. "You want to come with me?" The girl held up the gun Gary had given her and tighten her grip on it. "Yes... those things killed most of my family and friends... I had to kill a few of them myself when they... came back." Gary though she was about to cry, but her face didn't change as she spoke. There was even a small hint of anger in her voice. "If you think I'm unprepared to kill someone, don't be. I've done it before to protect the family I have left and I'll be glad do it again if you'll let me." Gary took a moment to consider the things she had said. He could use some help, but didn't want to expose a teenage girl to any more danger then he had to. Even if she seemed like she could handle herself. "If you go with me... who will watch your cousins?" He asked in an attempt to dissuade her from joining him.


"I will." A voice came from behind them. It was soft, yet firm. The woman who had spent the past few days slumped in the corner crying herself silly over the tragedy she had experienced, was standing. Her hair covered her face, but Gary could feel her gaze as if nothing was in the way. "I'll protect them... those things won't hurt my children, never again." Gary was about to speak, only to find himself biting his tongue. He could tell she wouldn't change her mind so he didn't bother arguing any further. "Guess you're coming with me." Gary said as he walked past Amber over to the children's mother. "Here, I've only got one handgun left. Keep the safety on unless they get in." He said as he handed her a small silver gun he had pulled out of his duffel bag. "You know how to use it, right?" She nodded and took the gun with shaking hands. "Please, please get my children out of here..." She said as she turned and walked over to sit down with her last two children next to the wall. "We will, aunt Susan!" Amber called from the hallway. "Come on, doctor! We got a boat to reclaim." Gary smiled and joined her back at the door. "You are a really brave girl." He said as he unlocked the door. "They say it runs in my family." She replied as she gave the door a slight push to open it quietly. "Alright, here we go!" Gary called as he ran outside and motioned for Amber to follow.


A cool afternoon breeze blew through the air and brushed the leaves on the trees into a frenzy. In the distance something could be heard shambling along the shoreline. A low moan escaped its lips. Gary took a deep breath as he moved down the deck and peeked around the corner. One Swimmer with an injured arm. He could take it by surprise and then kill the ones on the other side while Amber went in the opposite direction and begin hitting them from that side. A pincer attack, their only escape would be into the chilly water below. Once they had secured the ground level, they could both storm the upper deck and reclaim the entire boat. After that was done they would drive it to the shore and get to the lighthouse. It was a good plan. Gary held out his hand to motion for Amber to stop and turned to face her. "I'll go around this side of the ship and began my attack." He whispered just loud enough for her to hear him. "You go around the other side and cut off their escape. That way they'll have to retreat back into the water or be shot. Once we clear the lower deck we can move on to the upper deck and start this thing up." Amber gave a slight nod to show she understood and sprinted backwards towards the other end of the ship. When she began shooting Gary would make his move on this side. In less then a minute a noise came from Amber's side of the ship, it was the sound of...
11121121111122111112111122.title: The siege begins!

choices: "I see flying things carrying other zombies!"
"I see a huge group of Swimmers, and they're approaching fast!"
111211211111221111121111221.content:
"Here we go!" Gary thought as he ran around the side of the ship and emptied a round into the back of the Swimmers head. It didn't even let out a groan as it fell over and was kicked off the edge of the ship by Gary as he ran past it. Just when he turned to face the rest of them he was almost hit by a blot of ink, but dodged right before it connected. "Not this time." He called out as he blew half of the things face away. Other then the two he had just killed, there were four Swimmers left. Gary aimed for the one closest to him, but didn't pull the trigger fast enough. It fell on its side as blood ran down from its forehead and off the side of the boat. "Sorry doc, did you want that one?" Amber called as she pointed the gun at another Swimmer that was running toward her. "Damn, you sure can shoot!" Gary called cheerfully as he severed the right ear from a Swimmer that had its back turned 8 feet in front of him. His second shoot put an end to it just as it turned around. "Man, these things seemed so scary before, but now that we're armed they might as well be fish in a barrel." Amber said with a laugh. "I can't believe they gave us so much trouble before." Gary reloaded his gun as she killed the last Swimmer with 2 shots to the head. "I wouldn't underestimate them if I were you..." Gary said as he took an extra chip out of his bag and threw it to amber. "They almost killed me before, and that was just a small group." Amber reloaded her gun and followed Gary as he walked up the five steps that led to the upper deck. "Yeah yeah, I promise I'll be careful." She replied in an almost sarcastic tone. "Let's just hurry up and get out of here before we have to deal with more."


Gary didn't like her attitude, but couldn't blame her. She was young and still had a lot to learn. He fired off a shot at the lone Swimmer on the upper deck, only to hit the window behind it. "Here, I got it." Amber called as she fired a shot from her own gun. The Swimmer slumped over, dead. "You really can shoot..." Gary said as he walked past the body and opened the door to the small room that stood before them, careful to avoid stepping on the broken pieces of glass. "Careful..." He called as Amber began to follow him inside. He stopped when he noticed something sitting on the floor under the ships dashboard. It was the decaying body of the captain laying in a puddle of his own blood, his throat ripped out and his head crushed. "Stop!" Gary called before Amber could get any closer. "What?" She asked in an annoyed tone. Gary shook his head as he looked over the grisly scene. There were the keys still in the ignition, at least. "Go back and keep watch while I start this thing up." Gary said in an upset tone.


Amber seemed to notice that he was hiding something and was about to ask him if anything was wrong when he turned around and scooted her out the door. "Hey what is it?" She asked as he took the duffel bag off of his shoulder and handed it to her. "There's plenty of extra ammo in that. Shout if you see anything." He said hastily as he closed the door back. Amber was about to ask again if anything was wrong, but knew she probably wouldn't get an answer. She simply sighed and walked back over to the stairs with the duffel bag over her shoulder. "Don't let us down, doctor..." She whispered as she looked from the lake to the shoreline.

In the distance she noticed something moving.

Gary started up the boat and began driving it towards the shore near the lighthouse. The jetski he had used to get here was pushed aside and made a scrapping sound as it was knocked under the the water for a brief moment. The boat was moving. Not fast or smoothly, but it was moving none the less. They would all be safe soon if this thing held out for just a few more minutes. Gary was about to call out to Amber as they moved along slowly, only to hear her call to him from the outside. "What is it?" He called back as he kept his eyes focused on the shoreline ahead.
111211211111221111121111221.title: Reclaiming the boat

choices: Gary calls for help
Gary defends himself until the slime wears off
1112112111112211111211112211.content:
Gary quickly called Amber inside and asked her to take the wheel while he went outside to deal with the situation. "Don't stop. No matter what you hear outside, get this boat to shore. If they sink it... we're all dead." He said calmly as he headed outside. "I will, doctor! No matter what!" She called over the sound of the slamming door. They were a little closer by the time he got outside, but Gary knew exactly what they were, he had dealt with one only a day before. There were about two dozen of them, not counting the other zombies they carried, along with a small swarm of birds. Gary made sure both of the handguns he had were fully loaded and took the first shot when they got close enough. A Pyro was caught in the head and ignited its entire body as it went limp. The Fire quickly spread to the Carrier holding it and burned away its wings as it let out a death cry. Both bodies hit the water with a loud splash that was barely heard over the roar of giant wings and moaning corpses. Gary hadn't even put a dent in their assault and they were drawing closer by the second.

"Shit!" Gary called as he fired off a few more shots, only managing to kill or wound 3 zombies. They fell silently as their friends let out a chorus of growls that echoed through the trees as they moved in close, ready to kill the lone doctor. Gary only got off 4 more shots before he heard the click of an empty gun. He was out of ammo. Quickly he dug two more clips from the duffel bag he had taken back from Amber. He was halfway reloaded when the ones in the front finally reached the ship. Three Carriers, a Stalker, a level two, and a Siren loomed overhead for a moment before making a dive at him. He raise his guns just as they went for the kill, he was too late. They would strike him down before he could get a single shot off...

To Gary's immense surprise, they flew past him... into the water below.

"What the hell..." He gasped as he turned towards the shore. It was hard to make out, but two figures could be seen atop the lighthouse. It appeared Gary's new friends had finally gotten a good shot at the bastards and took them out. "Thank you!" Gary called out in relief as he raised his guns to air, knowing that his allies had no chance of hearing him. "Now help me get these people out of here!"

He fired as the rest of the swarm descended upon the boat. Two Carriers were hit and fell into the water along with the undead that they carried. The rest flew around the boat in circles, each trying to catch Gary off guard. He struggled futility to kept up with them, but soon the Carriers began flying away... empty handed. "Damn it... goddamn it! Where are they?!" Gary cursed as he backed up against the door. Almost on cue, two Slimers appeared from opposite sides of the boat and launched blue goo at him as they made a run for the stairs that would get them to the upper deck. "Oh, no you don't!" Gary taunted as he ran to the stairs and cut them off. He fired as soon as the first one turned around the corner and took part of its head off. The second, however, got off a sticky blast right as Gary shot. The blue gunk stuck to Gary's left arm and attached to the side of the boat when he leaned on it. "Shit, what is this..." He asked in an annoyed tone. "I'm stuck to the wall!" Both of the Slimer corpses dissolved into more blue slime that flowed over his feet as the rest of the horde prepared to finish off the trapped doctor...
1112112111112211111211112211.title: Air assault

11121121111122111112111122111.content:
Gary gave the goo one last pull to no avail. "Amber!" He called as loud as he could. "Get out here and help me!" A few seconds passed in complete silence. Gary tried yelling louder, but was soon cut off as a level one zombie bit into his ankle. He turned around just in time to see a small mob surrounding him. Gary raised his guns and fired franticly at his attackers, only killing two of them before running out of ammo. The gun clicked on an empty chamber as the remaining corpses began tearing him apart. The last thought to pass through his head was a cruel reminder of what he had said only minutes ago. "Don't stop. No matter what you hear outside..."

Sadly, the boat and its passengers never made it to shore.
11121121111122111112111122111.title: A call for help falls on deaf ears...

choices: Everything is quiet, no more zombies attack
Gary hears footsteps
11121121111122111112111122112.content:
This was it, they were almost to the shore and Gary was trapped out in the open. If he could defend himself until they got to dry land Amber could come back out and help him finish the remaining zombies. He struggled to reload both of his guns with his arm stuck against the wall, but managed to dig the clips out of his bag and put them in the firearms just in time. A group of level one zombies appeared off to the size and began shambling towards him. He aimed carefully with his free hand and took them all down with only one shot each. "So far, so good..." He mumbled as he waited for more to reveal themselves. A growl sounded on the opposite side of the boat and a large black cloud could be seen over the top of the railing on the upper deck. "Oh god... what now?" Gary groaned as it rounded the corner and made its way over to the stairs. Darkness enveloped him and his vision disappeared into a void of black. Deep within the inky shadows there was the sound of movement, something shambling and something crawling. Gary's breathing grew heavier as his foes approached slowly, hidden from sight. "Damn it, show yourself!" Gary yelled in desperation. There was a brief moment of silence and the moving resumed. Finally, four crimson red eyes appeared out of the darkness from the left side of the lower deck. They moved closer until they were only a few feet from Gary. Whatever they belonged to growled and snarled as if to say "KILL HIM." The sound of movement filled the air once again as Gary began shooting.


The Nightmare was hit instantly and was killed, but its corpse remained, providing an eerie veil to camouflage the remaining undead. Two... SOMETHINGS ran around the corner and growled as they struck at Gary. One was killed by a lucky shot and fell over dead before it could reach him, but the other one was more successful in its attack. A set of claws that felt like razor blades sliced through the side of Gary's right leg. There was a scream and the sound of metal colliding with flesh as Gary pistol whipped the monster right in the side of the head. It let out a groan and fell to the floor, twitching a bit before going limp. Gary clutched his slashed open leg and tried to assess the damage. Quite a bit of blood, possibly a broken bone or two, yet no major ruptured blood vessels. It was a treatable wound, but needed care immediately. Gary tried to pull his arm from the wall and was surprised to feel the slime give about an inch or two. He tried pulling a little harder, but barely made any more progress. "Not quite yet..." He said as he panted. He held up both of his guns in preparation for any more zombies and listened for sounds of movement...
11121121111122111112111122112.title: Lights out

choices: The man takes the time to introduce himself
The man is immediately hostile to Gary
111211211111221111121111221121.content:
Everything remained silent. The zombies were either all dead or regrouping somewhere else. Either way, at least Gary now had time to tend to his leg and get the others off of the boat. He pulled his arm free of the wall with one last tug and pulled his feet out of the dissolving goo around his ankles. "Finally gone..." He stammered as he limped back towards his comrade who was now docking the ship next to the boathouse. The darkness around him disappeared all at once and the bright sunlight stung his eyes when he first regained his sight. He squinted and knocked on the door as he grabbed hold of his injured leg, which was still bleeding. "Its me, Gary. Hurry up and open the door..." It took her a moment, but the cheerful teenager soon greeted him with a hug. "Thank you doctor." She said as tears began to form in her eyes. "You protected us, just like you said." Gary smiled back weakly and almost fell over as Amber helped set him down on the floor inside. "One of those things cut my leg, I'll have to treat it while you get your aunt and cousins to the lighthouse up the hill. My friends will take care of you there, now hurry." Amber nodded and bent over to kiss him on the cheek as he dug out the first aid kit that he had brought with him out of his duffel bag. Once he had what he need he gave the bag back to Amber along with one of his guns. "Go ahead, I'll follow as soon as I fix myself up. Be careful climbing down the stairs, one of those things somehow made everything dark." Gary called as she closed the door, leaving him alone.


Gary struggled to stand up after getting his wounded cleaned and bandaged. It seemed the zombie had inflicted major damage to the muscle tissue, which, on top of everything else, could leave him with a limp for the rest of his life. Even if he got it treated at a hospital with the best medical equipment, that was probably the best possibility, the worst would be losing the leg due to improper treatment. "Oh well, no use worrying about that now." Gary groaned as he finally got to his feet. "I did... the best I could with... what I had..." A few beads of sweat rolled down his face as he slowly made his way over to the door. He had about had it, if he didn't get some rest soon he'd be of no use during another zombie attack. He stumbled outside and grabbed onto the railing of the ship to help support himself. As he steadied himself he happened to look up towards the other survivors who were making their way up the hill with Amber in the lead. "Good, they're all still okay..." Gary said as he walked back into the darkness towards the lower deck. Once he was back in the light he walked around the side of the boat and carefully dropped down onto the dock with his good leg. He was about to resume walking when he heard a scream come from further up the hill. It sounded like Amber.


"Shit! What now?!" Gary shouted as he sprinted down the dock as fast as his nearly crippled leg allowed. It stung and ached as he forced it to carry him through the puddles of mud and water that coated the weeds and grass, but he was determined to reach his companions. "Please be okay... please be okay... PLEASE be okay..." He stuttered as he huffed and coughed. It wasn't long before he heard another scream, this time a child's. "NO!" He yelled as he pushed aside a tree branch. He stopped only when the other survivors came into view in the clearing ahead. Both the children were standing next to each other near their mother who was slumped in the grass as she shook uncontrollably. Amber was laying in the grass about four yards in front of them with a man in a white robe standing over her. The man had shoulder-length blond hair and two sets of white angelic wings sticking out of his back. Wasting no time Gary ran forward and revealed himself.
111211211111221111121111221121.title: A crippling injury...

choices: "Heads!"
"Tails!"
1112112111112211111211112211211.content:
"Oh, who's this?" The young man in the robe said when he noticed the doctor charging towards him. Gary slowed and came to a stop just in front of the children and their mother. "What... the fuck... did you do to her...?!" Gary wheezed as he pointed a lone finger at Amber's unconscious form laying in the grass next him. "Oh her? Hee hee, the poor girl tried to shoot me, but I was a little quick for her..." The man chucked. "By the way, I'm Ishmael, number 2748 of the 5000 brotherhood members sent to this city. My ability is that of the holy falcon. I can fly and..." As he said this his hands began sharpening into massive talons. "I can easily cut through steel." He finished as he looked into the eyes of the horrified doctor. Gary almost dropped his gun in shock, but his tight grip ensured that he held onto it. "Y-you have powers?! There are 5000 others like you?!" He stuttered as Ishmael began smiling again, a horrible smile that didn't carry a hint of malice or hatred. That's why it was so horrifying, it was a genuinely friendly smile coming from a man who had just knocked a teenage girl unconscious.


"Oh yes. Each member of our little order has powers, you normal humans have no hope of facing us. Why not just accept your deaths and die with dignity?" Ishmael spoke in a disturbingly calm tone. One of the children began crying when he raise his hand up in the sunlight for everyone to get a good look. The sun shone of of it as Ishmael twitched and shook his fingers around. "You needn't be afraid little one, I'll be sure to send your mommy and relatives along with you, you can all be together again in death." Upon hearing this Gary could take no more. He raised his gun and fired two shots at the bastard. A stunned silence then filled the air as Gary dropped his gun to the ground. Ishmael had caught both bullets between his talons and effortlessly shredded them into tiny pieces. "Don't worry, good doctor." He said with a sneer. "I'll send you away along with your companions... just as soon as I decide who to kill first."


Both children were now crying as the demented man tried to make up his mind of who would be his next victim. "Oh I know!" He said in an unnervingly cheerful tone. "I'll flip a coin. That way god can decide who he wants to meet first." He smiled as he dug around in a pocket beneath the outer part of his robe. "Oh goodie, I have a spare coin!" He said as he raised his hand to show a small silver coin between his thin claw-like fingers. "So, who'll be heads and who'll be tails?" He called in an enthusiastic voice, as if he expected them to answer. "C'mon... Fine then, I'll decide." His smile grew wider as he looked from the kids and their mother to the doctor who was struggling just to stay standing before him. "Alright children, you get to be tails, doctor, you're heads." He flipped the coin and watched as it fell to the ground. Gary tried to think of something, anything he could do as the deranged man walked over to the ground to see the result of the toss. "Oh, looks like its..."
1112112111112211111211112211211.title: Fallen angel

choices: Gary struggles
Gary attempts to keep Ishmael distracted so that the others may escape
11121121111122111112111122112111.content:
"HEADS!" Ishmael shouted with a look of utter joy on his smiling face. "Looks like you're first, doctor. I'll send the children off shortly after I deal with you." Gary took a step back and tried to stall for time. "Wait, why are y-" He was cut off as the taller man grabbed him carefully in his talons and effortlessly held him over his head. Now both children were crying even harder as they held onto their mother. "Looks like you're half-dead already. Our pets must have done a real number on you." Ishmael said as Gary thrashed about futilely. "Easy now, I don't want you to accidentally slice open your neck before I get a chance to kill you. After all, I rarely get the chance to finish anyone myself." He said with a chuckle. "Let's see, I could just slice your neck or cut off your air and be done with it, but that's far too easy. I like to be creative, each life I take must be elegantly destroyed in the most expressive way possible. A life taken by a bullet has no beauty to it at all."


Gary was close to passing out when Ishmael finally loosened his grip a little and let the doctor draw in a fresh breath. "I know..." Ishmael said as he looked over Gary's shoulder. In less then a second both men were airborne, but that didn't last long as they landed next to two trees growing about two feet apart from each other. "What are... you..." Gary said weakly as he was dropped to the ground. His whole body hurt now, not just his leg anymore and it was clear he wouldn't be running away. "Did you know I can regenerate?" Ishmael said as he casually ripped one of his finger talons off. "Well, to a minor extent, full regeneration eludes me... not that I need it. No one on this earth has ever so much as come close to damaging my perfect form." Gary winced as a fresh talon began growing in place of the one that had been removed. With a swift motion the new talon was removed as well, only to have a third begin growing in its place. "My... my god..." Gary moaned as he was lifted once again into the air.


The next thing Gary felt was a pain far worse then anything he had experienced in his life. His left hand was stuck to one of the two trees by the talon, which was slowly being driven into the palm of his hand. His screams of pain and horror did nothing to stop the cruel man as he drove the second talon deep into the bark of the second tree with Gary's right hand in between. A small trickle of blood ran down his hands and he finally fell silent as the shock overwhelmed him. Somehow, in spite of all of this, he managed to stay conscious. "Are you a believer in Christ? If you are I'm sure you can appreciate the irony of this situation." Ishmael taunted as he began laughing again...
11121121111122111112111122112111.title: Crucified

choices: Amber wakes up
Gary's friends from the lighthouse find them
111211211111221111121111221121111.content:
"You... piece of trash... you... don't even..." Gary groaned as he struggled to free himself. Ishmael returned one of his hands to its human form and punched Gary in the side of the jaw, causing a single tooth to fly out and disappear somewhere in the grass. Gary fell silent as blood began pouring out from his mouth and onto his shirt. "Why are you still resisting?" Ishmael taunted as he held Gary's head up and looked into his eyes. "Give up, you're going to bleed to death here." Gary opened his mouth to reply, but no words came out, the pain was so bad it was a struggle just to remain conscious. Gary coughed and spit blood on Ishmael's shoes, it was all he could do. This, as it turned out was not a very smart move.


Ishmael delivered another sharp blow to Gary's jaw and caused a stream of fresh blood to start pouring out. "You got blood on my shoes." He said in that eerily calm voice of his. "Fuck bleeding to death, I'm going to reach down your throat and tear your heart out." Gary's head snapped back up and he tried once again to get free, still to no avail. "I already told you. You're going to die here." Ishmael said calmly and his hand grew into talons again. "No!" Gary yelled as Ishmael lowered his claw over the doctors face with a smile. "This is it doctor... say goodb-"


Three gunshots echoed through the trees and red lines began running down Ishmael's robes. "What?" He groaned as he took his hand off Gary's face and turned around to see his attacker. It was Susan, who was standing in front of her children with a look of utter fury on her face. She pulled the trigger again, only to have it click on an empty chamber. "That... was... for my child you son of a bitch... my child..." Tears began rolling down her eyes as Ishmael rose one again into the air, seemingly unharmed by the bullets imbedded in his torso. In a flash he was upon her and struck her to the ground with a single blow. "You little bitch, I'll kill both your children and make you watch!" As he said this there wasn't even a hint of regret or remorse in his voice. "NO!" Susan screamed as she returned to her feet and smacked Ishmael across the side of the face. His head was knocked back a bit and for a moment it looked like she may have actually hurt him. Sadly, that moment was all too brief and quickly forgotten as Ishmael demonstrated the depths of his cruelty.


No words. There was complete silence as he plunged his talons deep into her stomach and lifted her into the air. Even the smile on his face had disappeared by this point. "Susan! SUSAN!" Gary yelled desperately as he struggled to get himself free. "Put her down you bastard!" Ishmael ignored him and once again returned one of his hands to normal. "You got blood all over my robe." He said in an enraged tone to the dying woman. "Allow me to pay you back for that." To the horror of Gary and the two children he began pelting her body with several vicious punches. "Cry now, I want to hear you beg me to stop." The blows grew sharper and more painful as the monster began to lose his patience. "Beg me to stop you little whore! Come on! Just say stop and I'll slit your throat and put an end to it." Susan simply coughed up some blood and looked into the man's eyes without even the slightest hint of fear in her own. With the last of her strength she punched him as hard as she could in the jaw. He let out a grunt and fell to the ground, dropping her in the process. "That... was for my child..."


A pool of blood began forming around her as she lay on the ground unresponsive. Her children rushed over to her and tried to wake her, begging her to open her eyes as Ishmael began getting back to his feet. "Damn her, I'll have pay her back for that too by-" Gary interrupted him just as he was about to finish with a talon to the back. "How's it feel to get stabbed with your own weapon?!" Gary asked as he shoved the man to the ground for a final time. YOU?!" Ishmael choked as Gary towered over him. "You said you could regenerate?! Let me see you regenerate from this!" Gary yelled furiously as he plunged Ishmael's other talon deep into his left eye. There was a prolonged scream and the body of the demon in the white robes collapsed into dust. Gary fell to the ground with a weak smile and looked up at his hands. The holes where he had been stabbed were leaking blood all down his arms. "Guess its... over..." He said as the forest around him faded from view and everything went black.
111211211111221111121111221121111.title: My child

choices: Back at the lighthouse with 5 hours until the rescue helicopter arrives...
Back at the lighthouse with 10 minutes until the rescue helicopter arrives...
1112112111112211111211112211211112.content:
Matt grunted angrily as he walked down the hill with his partner. "Hey Kevin, you mind telling me why I have to carry everything?" Kevin merely rolled his eyes as he listened for the sounds of the undead. "Because, we both know I'm the better shot and need to travel as light as possible. One extra bit of baggage could throw off my aim." Matt grunted again as he almost tripped over a rock. "Oh sure, anyway do you think Gary will be surprised at what we found?" Kevin laughed as he pushed aside a tree branch. "Not as surprised as he will be once he hears about the rescue helico-" He felt silent at the sight in the clearing before him. Gary, Amber, and Susan were all laying on the ground as the two children cried hysterically over the body of their dead mother. "Holy fuckin' shit..." Matt gasped as the two rushed to their fellow survivors aid. "Quick!" Kevin called as he tended to the two children. "Check them all for a pulse, I've got to get these kids back to the lighthouse!" Matt leaned down next to Amber and checked her arm. "I'm on it... this girl's okay! I'll check the other two, hurry and get those kids to safety!" In what was perhaps a miracle, no zombies appeared as the duo worked desperately to take care of their only allies. Soon, everyone who could be saved was back at the lighthouse...


Gary was surrounded by complete darkness. No light. No sound. No feeling. He couldn't even see his hand in front of his face. The most particular feeling had overcome him. It was like a bittersweet mix of despair, hope, and accomplishment. He had saved Amber and the children, but Susan died to protect them all and allow him to stop Ishmael. He had failed to rescue her as he had promised. "Why?" He thought to himself, the word seeming to expand endlessly in the nothing that surrounded him. "Why did she have to die? Why did the brotherhood do this? Am I dead? Is this hell? Is this the punishment for my failure?"

...

"If so, then I except my fate. I did all I could. If my death saved anyone, if my sacrifice meant something, then I can accept this." Gary felt an immense sadness pour over his shadowy form and lift him into a bright light. "If this... is... how it ends... so be it." The warm light spread over him and Gary Wilson disappeared into the void.
1112112111112211111211112211211112.title: Darkness

choices: A large horde of zombies appear about ten minutes before the helicopter arrives
The helicopter arrives on time... but makes a crash landing!
11121121111122111112111122112111121.content:
Gary felt as if a heavy weight had been taken off his body and found he could once again move, although only very slightly. His leg and hands burned with pain, yet he could feel the world returning around him. His opened his eyes slowly and the blurry shapes of the lighthouse began to fall into place. "Am I... still... in this world...?" He moaned as he looked around the lighthouse at the many surprised and teary faces. "Doctor, thank god you're still alive..." Amber said as she knelt by the side of his bed. The two children, Timmy and Clare, soon joined their cousins side and began crying again. "You're alive doctor, you saved us just like you said you would!" Clare shouted as she buried her head in the sheets hanging off the side of his bed. "Thats right..." Gary said as the memories of the last few hours came flooding back to him. "The boat... Ishmael... Susan..." Tears filled the doctors eyes as he hugged his companions. "I'm sorry, I'm so sorry I couldn't save your mother, I did all I could..." Amber and the children simply smiled as best they could with their sad red faces and told him that they knew he tried his best and that they were thankful. In a few minutes Matt and Kevin walked into the room to inform them that a rescue helicopter was on its way and they would all be getting out of here soon. In less then 5 hours they would be out of this hellhole and safe with the countless other rescued survivors...


The first four hours went by very slowly as Gary rested and Matt and Kevin kept watch for any approaching zombies. They had already shot 4 level ones and a level two by the time Gary woke up a second time with just an hour to go before the chopper was set to arrive. Both men had decided to keep secret about what they had discovered inside the lighthouse for the time being as they didn't want to cause any unwanted stress in the already strung out group. "So, we gonna tell em' about what we found down in the basement of this place when we get rescued?" Kevin asked as he blew away the head of a Digger that had finally decided to stick its head out of its hole about 70 yards away. "Yeah, we'll also have to show them the things we found on that white robe they had with them." Matt replied as he looked out over the lake. "By the way, how much time until that chopper we radioed shows up?" Kevin checked his watch while reloading his gun. "Let's see, its almost 7:00 p.m. so I'd say half an hour, give or take." Matt looked down at his own gun and once again out at the lake. "I still can't believe its almost over..."
11121121111122111112111122112111121.title: Still alive

choices: Gary attempts to fight alongside his companions
Gary is unfit to fight and must do what he can to help in his weakened state
111211211111221111121111221121111211.content:
"I'm gonna go check on the doctor." Kevin said as he sat his gun down and got out of his chair. "Keep watch out here, there shouldn't be too many zombies for you to handle, but if you need help just yell." Matt nodded silently as he took aim at a zombie crawling along the ground off in the distance next to a large oak tree. Kevin left the door open so he could hear his friend and began moving towards the bottom of the lighthouse where the doctor and the other survivors were waiting. "Hey, you're awake again. How do you feel?" He called when he noticed Gary sitting up in his bed talking with Amber. "Oh, well my leg and hands still hurt like hell and I feel a bit lightheaded, but I think I'll make it. You must have taken good care of me while I was out, I'm impressed." Kevin smiled as he sat down on the floor next to Amber. "Well actually... Matt and Amber here did most of the patching up, first aid really isn't my specialty." Gary grinned as he turned back towards Amber. "Wow, so you can handle a gun like a pro and helped fix me up? I wish I was that skilled at your age, all I could do as a teenager was play a decent game of chess." He said with a laugh as Amber began to frown. "Yeah... I just wish I could've done more... maybe if I hadn't passed out..." She trailed off without finishing and Gary put a bandaged hand on her shoulder. "You did all you could, same with the rest of us, we couldn't save everybody, but we did the best we could and soon we'll all be out of here. Safe and sound with a bright new day waiting for us."


Amber began tearing up again and gave the doctor a hug. "Thank you... all of you... thank you for helping us..." Kevin couldn't help but smile when he heard her kind words and began feeling good again for the first time in days. The group of survivors began talking with one another like they were all old friends and discussed the things they would do once they had escaped. Unfortunately, as soon as the mood began improving dramatically the cold reality of their situation was thrust abruptly back into their faces. Matt began screaming at the top of his voice about an incoming horde of zombies. Kevin quickly jumped to his feet and joined back up with his friend to see what they were up against. "It doesn't look good..." Matt groaned as he pointed in the direction of the city off in the distance. It was hard to see beneath the sea of green leaves and tree branches, but an unmistakable gathering of zombies had formed and was moving straight for them. "Quick, hold them off as long as you can while me and the others reinforce the downstairs!" Kevin yelled as he rushed back down the stairs to warn the others of the danger. The helicopter could show up at any minute now... and so could a thousand pairs of burning red eyes looking for a victim...
111211211111221111121111221121111211.title: The beginning of the end...

choices: Gary goes downstairs to buy them some more time
Gary stays put and tries to aim better
1112112111112211111211112211211112111.content:
"What?!" Gary yelled at the top of his voice upon hearing the terrible news. "A whole mob...?" Kevin nodded silently as he walked over to the door. "Damn it... damn it... we're so close...!" Gary shouted as his hands trembled in anger. "I know, but we don't have time to be upset over our current situation, we need to buy as much time as we possibly can. Help me with this door, doctor, and you children need to head upstairs with Matt." Gary slowly got up out of his bed and stood up with his aching hands and leg. "Shit, this hurts..." He groaned as he stumbled over to where Kevin was and helped him cover the door with whatever they were able to. "What about the windows?" Gary asked as he shoved a chair towards the door. "There's no need to worry about them, no zombie could fit through in one piece." Kevin replied as they finished their work and headed back upstairs just as the growls began echoing outside joining with the sound of gunfire from the survivors up top. "Come on doctor, we have to hurry, rescue will be here any minute." Kevin called as they made their way up the stairs. "I know, we made it this far, what's a few more minutes?" Gary replied with confidence.


Things looked pretty grim up on top of the lighthouse, but it was an awe inspiring sight to see each and every other survivor wielding a gun and blowing away the undead one bullet at a time. "Gary and Kevin are here!" One of the children called as they blew the jaw off a level 2 making a run for the lighthouse's front door. "Here!" Matt called as he tossed the arriving survivors their weapons. "No time for chit-chat, just start shooting! We need to thin their number as much as we can before they reach the door!" Gary took the handgun and ammo he was given and began loading it with a bit of difficulty in his weakened state. "Shit, you gotta be faster, they're almost here!" Matt yelled as Gary finally managed to load his gun. "Right, I'll try to be quicker!" Gary yelled back and began shooting. Unfortunately, his aim was off due to his bandaged hands and he only got two kills with his first clip. The rest were misses. "Damn it, I can't get a good shot!" Gary shouted as he attempted to loaded his second clip into the gun. By the time he had finally reloaded his weapon the door below them began creaking as a horde of corpses began pushing against it.

The helicopter was nowhere in sight.
1112112111112211111211112211211112111.title: Approaching conclusion

choices: Gary rushes the zombies
Gary slowly retreats back up the stairs while picking them off
11121121111122111112111122112111121111.content:
Gary looked down at his bandaged hands for a brief moment before turning to look at his allies. They fired as if the world had gone into slow motion. A zombies forehead burst open below and red liquid exploded from the wound like bits of confetti. Everything was almost frozen in a haze of doubt as the survivors continued with their almost hopeless struggle. It was at that moment Gary knew what he needed to do. He took a deep breath and the world resumed its normal pace. Several shots rang out in tune with the banging on the door below. Gary sat his gun down and with all the fury of a madman tore off the bandages binding his hands. The blood stained white ribbons unwraveled to the ground as the doctor grimmaced in pain. His hands were scabbed over and still coated with dried blood from wounds sustained just hours before. Gary forced his hands to move, to clench into fists so that he may visibly display his inner rage. Three fingers refused to budge, but the rest obeyed the command given to them and curled into a ball. Gary took another deep breath as pain shot through his arm and picked up his gun. He was just about to head downstairs when one of the survivors noticed he was no longer fighting.


"Doctor, what are you doing..." Amber asked with a hint of fear in her voice. Her eyes fell on the doctors hands when he turned around and she had to surpress the urge to yell. Instead her voice was calm when she spoke, although the fear never left it. "Your bandages... doctor what are..." She bit her lip when the realization hit her. "No! NO! You can't-" Gary silenced her with the sound of his own voice, which resonated with conviction and stern resolution. "I have to. I'm an old man and you're just kids. You must live... even if I have to die." Tears flowed down Ambers face as she tried to protest. "I... I'll come too! Those bastards killed my family! Let me-" "No. I'm doing this alone. Goodbye." Gary turned away to hide his own tears as he tightened his grip on his gun. Everyone else keep firing into the horde as the doctor parted with them and headed back downstairs. They pretended they didn't hear the words exchanged... although their faces made it clear what they were feeling. A thunderous roar in the distance punctuated the doctors exit. The helicopter was finally in sight.

"Goodbye doc..." Matt wispered to himself.

"You were a hell of a guy..." Kevin muttered as he fired another shot.

"We love you doctor..." The children said queitly in unison.

"Thank you..." Amber said sorrowfully as she wiped the tears from her eyes.


A chair fell to the floor just as Gary reached the bottom of the stairs. The door was busted and the barricade was slowly being pushed aside. "Guess thats it then..." Gary said as he made sure his gun was loaded. "I came close Shelly... I came real close..." He turned his attention back on the rotten arms reaching for him from the outside and took one final breath as the undead finally bypassed the survivors final defense. "All right you murdering bastards..." Gary called over the roar of the ghastly crowd advancing on him. "Come and get it."
11121121111122111112111122112111121111.title: The last goodbye

choices: Epilogue
111211211111221111121111221121111211112.content:
Gary immediately lifted up a nearby wooden chair with his good leg and kicked it into the front line of zombies, causing them to topple over and trip the ones behind them. "Sorry, I know you can't wait to get your hands on me... but I can't die just yet." With that he picked up the chair with his hand and smashed it over the head of a fat man who was about to make his way over his fallen friends. Another zombie, a skinny woman, then jumped onto Gary and almost knocked him over. Luckily, he kept his balance as he took a few steps back. The woman shrieked and tried to gash Gary with her claws, but something in his hand stopped her. "A level 2, huh? You bitches don't go down easy..." Gary smirked as he drove the broken chair leg he held into her eye as he shovered her off. "Yet you DO go down..." The doctor finished as he began backing up the stairs. He drew both of his guns and fired at the zombies trying to get back on their feet as well as the ones moving around them. With both his hands free the doctors shots were much more accurate, even if every jolt of the guns in his hands sent painful shocks up his arm. A Slimer in a torn ski mask opened his mouth to take a shot at Gary, only to have half his head blown away with 2 rounds right to the face. The thing's body collasped into burning acidic goo just as Gary popped off his last shot into the chest of an elderly man.


Without missing a beat Gary took the two spare clips he had been given and reloaded both guns in only a few seconds. More undead were pouring through the growing hole where the door had been, but the staircase was narrow and only allowed a few to engage him at a time. Plus, the rumbling of the chopper sounded just overhead, meaning it was about to pick up his friends. "I just might make it out of this yet..." Gary called hopefully as he pistol whipped a Stalker that jumped at him across the face and over the rail. Knowing that he was almost out of time Gary fired his remaining shots in rapid session to stem the tide of approaching zombies. Five of the seven shots connected, four of which were in the head. More dead zombies collasped on their friends which allowed Gary a 5-10 second head start to make it back up top before they caught up with him. He was already halfway there, but was tired and weak from his brief struggle against the horde. Right before he made it topside a level 2 managed to grab his ankle and almost pulled him down. Almost. A swift kick to the face made it release its grip and fall backwards as the doctor make a break for the reascue helicopter.


The rooftop was now empty except for Kevin, who was climbing aboard the helicopter which was flying a few feet above the roof as it slowly pulled away from the lighthouse. "Holy shit, the bastard made it!" Matt shouted in excitment when he noticed Gary sprinting towards them. "Hurry doctor, we're leaving!" Amber called from her seat as the chopper pulled away. A dozen zombies appeared behind the doctor as he closed in on his escape. A Siren screamed somewhere below them, which sounded as if it was the battle cry of the damned as they captured one last soul to add to their unholy army. Gary closed his eyes and jumped from the edge of the lighthouse just as a festering hand tried to close around his ankle. A stiff breeze blew through his clothes as his body soared towards his salvation.

It wasn't enough.

The doctor felt his leg brush against something metal as his body lost altitude and knew this was it. He had come so far... lost so much... and this was the end. He would die upon impact with the ground and the zombies would dispose of his remains. But he was still satisfied. He had lived a good life thus far... and cutting it short to save others was a price he had been willing to pay since the begining. A smile crossed his lips as he opened his eyes to see his friends faces once last time. The sky returned to his vision immediately with the ground below it, yet the helicopter and his friends were nowhere to be found. Only the blue and green of the trees and sky greeted him... then he noticed a tugging sensation in his left arm. "Jesus Christ, he's heavy! Pull!" Kevin called as he and Matt tightened their grip on the good doctor. Gary looked up at them as Amber grabbed his other hand and helped pull him up. Gary literaly couldn't believe his good luck. With one final pull he was safely inside the helicopter as it sped away from the doomed city and all it had claimed.


Tears filled Gary's eyes once again as he looked from the forest passing by below to the lighthouse and lake fading into the distance to all of his comrades equaly joyful faces. "Looks like... you saved me this time..." Gary said as a now sobbing Amber hugged him as tightly as she was phisically able. "You crazy son of a bitch... I thought we had lost you..." The doctor rubbed his sore eyes and grinned like he has just won the lottery. "I thought the same thing..." He replied as he patted her on the back. "You really are something..." Matt said as he wiped the sweat from his brow. "Yeah, fuckin' crazy!" Kevin interjected as he rubbed his eyes. "I think I'll take a rest now..." Gary said with a yawn. "Wake me when we get there..." And with that the doctor passed out and fell into the most peaceful sleep he'd had in days.
111211211111221111121111221121111211112.title: "I have not... come this far... to die now...!"

1112112111112211111211112211211112111121.content:
The following are undisputed facts:

On September 21, 2012 the Brotherhood Of Twilight unleashed a plauge of zombies upon the city of Bitterwood Pennsylvania. Many people were lost to the hordes of undead, but one group rescued by a local doctor had some startling discoveries to share. Beneath a lighthouse near a lake just outside the city limits was a meeting chamber for members of the brotherhood. Found there were strange runes and relics along with personal information on some of the members. Also recovered was a robe worn by a man named Ishmael who was killed in battle by the doctor. He was a very cruel member of the brotherhood with many strange abilities and connections within their organization. Upon death, the survivors claimed he turned to dust and were unable to present investigators with a body. These facts along with statements from a few other survivors imply that the organization and its undead army are supernatural in some way, although hard evidence has yet to be found.


Less then two weeks after all survivors were rescued the U.S. military exterminated the last zombie some 20 miles outside the city and peace is slowly, but surely, returning. The government is keeping quiet about what exactly happened or where the Brotherhood is now, yet they assure reporters that there is no long a valid threat. The total death toll is well over 10,000 with several people still unaccounted for.


Sadly, less then a week after his ordeal Gary got a phone call from police... they had found the body of one Shelly Wilson murdered in cold blood several miles from her house. The funeral was quiet and brief, only close friends and family showed up. It was raining hard that day, yet it couldn't hide the tears of her grieving husband. She was buried in a humble grave under a large oak tree in her home town next to a plot reserved for Gary when he once again joins her. In the end, Gary was able to retire at age 65 and spent the rest of his days fishing, golfing, and enjoying life with his friends. He passed away peacefully in his sleep one cold March morning after returning from a vacation. He was 82 years old.


Amber and her cousins stayed with family for a while after their escape from Bitterwood. After that Amber went to collage and got a degree in fine arts. The children took a while to get over all that had happened, but after years of therapy and treatment they were able to grow into happy, healthy, fully-functional adults. They, along with their older cousin, still talk to and visit the brave men who saved their lives that day from time to time. Likewise, both Matt and Kevin still keep in touch with their new friends. After all that had happened, after countless tears were shed, this small group of survivors managed to get a happy ending out of one of the worst disasters in history. They all made it out of hell and never looked back...
1112112111112211111211112211211112111121.title: Let go and begin again

choices: Aftermath
11121121111122111112111122112111122.content:
"Timmy, Clare, hurry up and get your things together... the helicopter will be here any minute and we have to be ready." Kevin said as he helped the two sobbing children gather up some food and water for their trip out of the city. "Here... I'll help you..." Amber said as she put a bag of Oreos and some juice boxes into a plastic bag. "By the way... hows the doctor?" Matt walked over to Gary's silent form and put a few fingers on his wrist. Everyone was silent for a few moments and then the doctors condition was confirmed.

"He... he's gone..."

Immediately, the two children ran over to Gary's bed with fresh tears in their eyes. "Oh... oh no..." Amber moaned as tears began filling her eyes. Timmy and Clare nudged Gary's unmoving body in an attempt to wake him from his slumber, but it was no use. "No! No! Mr. doctor, please wake up... you have to! First... daddy... then mommy... not you too..." Matt put his arms around the children and slowly let them over to their cousin. "I'm sorry, but you kids have to be brave... the helicopter will be arriving soon and we'll all be out of here, I promise." He gestured for kevin to watch them while he stepped outside to watch for the copter and clear away a few of the gathering zombies.


In five minutes a large transport helicopter appeared in the distance over the trees. "Its here Kevin, bring everyone outside!" Matt called as the helicopter began to descend to the ground outside the lighthouse. Everyone quickly came outside as the rescue vehicles blades spun furiously, ready to take off as soon as everyone was on board. In less then a minute after it laded the helicopter once again rose into the sky with 6 new passengers. The sunset was bittersweet that day as the rescued survivors morned their fallen friends and family.
11121121111122111112111122112111122.title: Requiem

The following are undisputed facts:

On September 21, 2012 the Brotherhood of twilight unleashed an army of undead corpses upon the unsuspecting city of Bitterwood, Pennsylvania. During this time many great heros sacrificed their lives to save and protect the innocent. One of which was the doctor Gary Wilson, who defended a mother, her children, and her niece from not only the zombies, but an insane member of the brotherhood. The doctor may have lost his life in the struggle, but his sacrifice allowed his two allies to find and rescue the two children and their cousin, although their mother was too far gone to be saved and was buried in the family tomb in Bitterwood National cemetery.

Kevin and Matt were able to reveal a secret passage in the lighthouse they that had turned into their base that led to a secret underground chamber filled with brotherhood experiments and tools. This, along with the robes and identification of Ishmael, a brotherhood agent, allowed the government to locate several other such locations and put an end to the zombies before they could spread far beyond the city. Both men were awarded medals for their accomplishments and heroism.

Gary's body was buried next to his wife Shelly, who lost her life soon after the undead first appeared. Amber, Timmy, and Clare stayed with Matt until Amber was old enough to take care of them by herself, as they had no other living relatives. When all was said and done life slowly returned to normal and all the remaining survivors managed to live full lives despite the ordeal they had been through. Truly, Gary Wilson had accomplished even more in death then he had in life.

Gary backed away slowly and tried walking back towards the car garage, only to have the door spring open as he reached for the knob. Apparently, when he had slammed it earlier it failed to close properly and allowed the monsters to cut off his second escape route. Finally, Gary ran back towards the doors that led into the hallways and pushed them open, knocking the two zombies that had been inside to the floor. For a brief moment it truly looked like he was going to get away...


A boney hand grabbed the back of his doctors coat and caused him to stumble into the hallway face first. He was quick to get back to his feet, but by then it was too late. The zombies surrounded him and ripped him apart as they poured out into the different hallways to find more victims.
11122.title: Three exits... and no escape...

11123.content:
Fortunately, the zombie that had noticed Gary was close enough that he could just kill it and hide in a row of cars before the others saw him. He tightened his grip on his scalpel and dashed forwards, effortlessly killing the slow moving fiend by driving the makeshift weapon deep into its heart. The zombie's now lifeless corpse began to stumble over, but but Gary managed to grab ahold of it and carry it with him as he ducked behind a row of cars. He sat the body down gently next to a blue Mitsubishi and listened to the sound of the shuffling feet and sad moans that filled the air around him. They didn't stop moving aimlessly about, yet after a few minutes it became apparent that the other zombies hadn't seen him dispatch their shambling brother. It seemed Gary's quick thinking had saved him again.


It took some effort to get the scalpel back out of the the zombie he had stabbed, but it soon came out... broken with the tip still embedded in the flesh of his fallen foe. "Shit..." Gary whispered as he quietly tossed the now useless piece of metal away. He was now completely defenseless, one false move would easily seal his demise. In an instant Gary's plan of escape became purely stealth based. He was too exhausted, under-equipped, and just plain old to deal with this many undead at once in direct combat. After deciding that it would be best to move quick to minimalize the chance of being discovered, he began walking down the row of cars he was in and into the next one. By paying attention to the directions the noises came from, he was able to avoid the zombies and get to his car. Just as he was about to enter, however, he caught a glimpse of the entrance to the floor below him. It was empty from what he could see and from there Gary could leave the hospital on foot. "Driving a car would be fairly impractical with 90% of the streets crowded with wrecked and abandoned vehicles... hmmm... On the other hand there may be countless zombies just out of sight below me..." The moans picked up again and Gary could tell it was only a matter of time before they found him. He had to make a decision... now.

112.content:
Gary walked alone in the darkness, tired, thirsty, and defenceless. He had drank his last bottle of water over a day ago when he had decided to take refuge in the subway tunnels under the city. It had been five days since it happened, and he still couldn't believe it. The dead were walking. This wasn't a movie or a game or a book, the dead were really walking, and killing. Gary could still remember that day it all started as if it had only happened mere hours ago. He had been driving to work when someone stumbled out in front of his car, a young police officer no older then 25. There was no chance for Gary to react... the car turned the officer into a human frisbee and sent him flying into a fire hydrant. In a panic Gary got out to see if there was anything he could do while some of the people nearby called 911.


The officer decided not to wait for Gary to come over, however, and grabbed a woman who had gotten a little too close to him. The woman screamed as he belched out a thick red goo onto her and himself as well. By the time rescue workers were there all that was left of the woman was a bloody corroded corpse laying in the street, but that was the least of their worries. By then the Slimer had killed itself with its own dripping acid slime and had dissolved into a new blue slime that had managed to trap a few unlucky people while they attempted to flee. They were easily finished off by the more powerful zombies while they were stuck and helpless. What had been a simple traffic accident soon escalated into a riot. Gary had managed to stay with a large group of people and got away from the growing assault, but as the zombies began appearing in greater number the groups started to disband, it would soon be everyone for themselves.


Two days after the incident on Cherry street Gary's group was down to 4 people. Then 3. Then 2. On the third day Gary's final ally was killed by a Deathtouch while he and Gary were raiding bottles of water from a supermarket. Of course, Gary managed to escape and enter the nearby subway station. Two days of wandering in the darkness aimlessly and getting lost later and here we are. Tired from walking Gary sat down on the cold ground and rested. After an hour of sitting in solitude he got back up and continued onward. Just as he was about to give up hope that he would never see the light of day again... he saw something up ahead. Something BRIGHT.


He picked up the pace a little and soon found the lights source. He had made it to a subway station that still had its lights on, it wasn't daylight, but it was good enough. After taking a moment to adjust his eyes to the sudden surge of brightness, Gary looked around at his surroundings. Up ahead of him was an overturned subway car and beyond that the tunnel was lit, which meant that the power was still on up ahead. Gary climbed up off of the subway tracks and onto the stations platform in search of a sign that might let him know where he is. After finding a sign next to the ticket window he read the name aloud. "Marigold Station." What luck! Marigold station was just 2 miles from his house, if he could get out of here he could go home...

1121.content: Now that he knew where he was Gary couldn't stand another minute of dimly lit solitude and ran over to the nearby escalators. Soon he was once again breathing fresh air and basking in the warm sun. It was a bittersweet welcome to be back on the surface though, as the landscape before him showed. Cars were driven onto the sidewalk, fires were burning freely, and more then a few corpses lined the empty streets. Gary felt as if he were on another planet, everything was so different then it had been just a few days before. Gary looked around at the wrecked city that stood before him. Had everyone else been killed? Was he the only survivor left? He tried not to think up any answers to those questions. As he walked along he noticed the road up ahead was blocked by a damaged police car. Gary could have easily walked around it, but felt he needed to investigate it. On the front hood he noticed an R in a circle that looked as if it had been spray painted on. It was certainly odd, yet it also gave Gary hope that someone else might still be alive out there. Gary opened the front door only to have a severed head roll out onto the street. He would have screamed had he not been so shocked. Just as he was about to move on he noticed something shining in the back seat. Careful not to disturb any more mangled body parts Gary reached back and grabbed it. What he now held in his hand was a brand new hand gun. After looking it over Gary was sure it wasn't standard police issue, someone must have left it here. Feeling a little more optimistic Gary put the gun into his pocket and continued walking home. After five more minutes had passed he came to the road that lead to his street, he was almost home! Unfortunately, a wrecked semi was laying across the road. What now?

Pushing, on the door, he was surprised to find it was open. "Something or someone is inside." Gary thought to himself as he walked inside. 1122.content:
Wasting no time Gary headed over to the ticket booth to check for supplies before heading out. At this point he'd be thankful just to have a drink or a weapon, even a small switchblade would make him feel a little better about heading back outside. As he walked over to the booth he heard some flies buzzing and immediately felt sick to his stomach when he noticed a splatter of blood on the interior of the booth.

As he peered over the counter he came face to face with what had once been a desperate man who was now a near headless corpse. Half of his face had been taken off from a point blank blast of buckshot from a small hunting shotgun sprawled across his lap. The model was fairly old and worn judging by the wear and tear on the stock and the barrel was sawn off to make for a bigger spread. It was no long range weapon, but it would shred anything that got within ten feet.

With a sigh Gary tore off a bit of cloth from his undershirt and used it to make a makeshift face mask to protect his nose from the smell as he walked around to the door of the booth on the other side. It was locked from the inside, but that mattered very little when the window was completely shattered. After reaching in and springing the door open Gary found himself standing over the mangled corpse of what had once been another survivor.

The guy wasn't dressed like a first responder or soldier, just some random person in a jacket and jeans who had found some gear before getting cornered or losing the will to live. On a shelf next to him was a small box of shells for the gun, mostly empty but with a few left inside along with a roll of dollar bills, which were now worthless. Aside from the cash the guy also had a small canteen with maybe an once or two of water left in it and some personal items like a wallet and keychain.

"Well, thanks for the gun and the drink friend." Gary whispered sadly as he popped the lid off the canteen and downed the liquid inside, which turned out to be fruit punch... not water like Gary had hoped. Oh well, it should keep him hydrated at least, though the fruity aftertaste would be a bit annoying. After loading the shotgun Gary took a quick stock of his remaining shells as he put them into his pocket.

In total he had six more shots after he expended the one he had already loaded into the chamber. The shotgun was a single-shot model, but that would help conserve ammo at least. Gary would just have to be smart about when to pull the trigger and pick his fights carefully. At any rate, he was feeling much better now and could finally head back above ground to see what the damage was. With a deep breath he walked out of the ticket booth and began ascending the stairs that would bring him back up to street level.

Unfortunately, things had gone from bad to worse while he was gone... very worse. The streets were littered with blood and gore that was splattered across abandoned cars and vans and several dead bodies were twitching and crawling about. Some were just torsos with gnawed limbs, others were little more than mangled heads rendered immobile after losing their arms and body and a few... were still up and walking around with large chunks torn out of their flesh. It was pure hell on earth, the stuff of nightmares.

"Merciful god..." Gary mumbled as he began walking out of the subway station and down the street. As he was about to round the corner a group of people with glowing red eyes stumbled out from behind an overturned semi truck and began closing in on him. There were less than half a dozen of them blocking his way but there was no way around them, if Gary wanted to continue forwards he'd have to either fight them or find another way past them.

What should he do?

115.content:
Deciding to go back to his home, the one he shared with his late wife Shelly, to gather his medical bag and perhaps some weapons. Still rather dazed by all that has happened and the fact that his second wife is now one of the walking dead population, numb and so scared that he can barely feel anything around him, he stumbles in the direction of the house that was once a loving home.

The intersections and the suburban roads are desolate and eerily quiet as he weaves his way through the center of town. Not wanting to be faced with any stumbling corpses, he was still ready for one to block his path... at least one. But he didn't see any living or not living being anywhere in sight. Leaves and trash littered the streets, abandoned cars with their doors still wide open from apparent previous escape.

Every corner he was faced to turn he expected the worst, but he was just forced to endure nothing but deathly silence. Amazingly nothing looked that disturbed. Store windows were intact, there was not any blood smears on walls or cars. It was as though the population just up and disappeared, not that they had probably been eaten by non feeling, non living creatures. It just added to the dream state Gary had felt he'd been existing in the past five days.

After he'd started to hear the reports of the unknown infection on the news that first morning while on call at the hospital he'd called home to Shelly to see if she had seen anything strange around their neighborhood. She'd told him that everything seemed fine, she wasn't worried and told him that he shouldn't either. But she had not been one to get too over worked over anything she had heard on the news.

A strong willed woman, she'd always been the one to calm him when he was upset. His quick temperament would get him into trouble periodically, especially with people that did not want to listen to reality. He wasn't one to live in a false, rose colored, environment. So his nerves had not been on edge too badly when he rang his wife that afternoon, but he did feel a bit of concern and wanted to quell that by at least hearing Shelly's soothing voice. She had told him that Bree had come by and they had talked about the garden club, sipping lemon aid and gossiping a bit. Told him that the van they owned was leaking a bit of fuel and that would probably have to be looked at when he got home or over the weekend when he had time, but other than that everything was perfectly normal.

His mind at ease he'd told her he loved her, like he would always end an exchange with her, and went about the rest of his morning checks at the hospital. But as the evening came and dinner would soon be on it's way things had gotten so very worse. Patients were coming in with gaping wounds, huge chunks of flesh that had been bitten out by other people. Being a rational person Gary just couldn't imagine that a mysterious case of biters were on the loose all of a sudden. The more he talked to patients and the people that brought them in and followed their account of events that lead them to the hospital he became more fearful.

He had been scheduled to get off of work at seven in the evening and he only had thirty minutes left on his shift when he decided to call Shelly again. He punched in the number to his home phone while he stressfully leaned against the nurses station, tapping his finger tips on the counter and counting off the rings 1..2..3...7...9. That's when he really started to worry.

He knew that his wife should very well be home now, he called regularly right before leaving to see if he could pick up something from the store on his way home. So for her not to answer at least by the third for fourth ring wasn't in her nature. That's when he was grabbed from behind by a nurse.

"Doctor, Doctor! I'm so glad I found you. We've been looking for you for the last then minutes, it's your wife... she's been brought into operating room seven-two and, well, you have to come, you just have to!" nurse Tina said hysterically.
