122.content:
Frank Hughes stepped out of the train station for the first time in days and walked out onto the boarding platform. He looked down at the tracks that faded off in the distance behind an endless sea of trees. Frank had been one of the few survivors who had the idea of heading to the secluded Bitterwood train station. All in all, it was a pretty good idea, and he would have gotten away... if only he had arrived a bit sooner. Five days ago he had run screaming up to the very same platform he stood upon now, just in time to see the very last train pull away as soon as he got there. By the time he had made it outside to signal it the train was already too far away to notice him. Worried, but certain that they would return later for more survivors he had stayed at the station. He had plenty of supplies thanks to the gift store and snack bar, a nice clean restroom, and due to the station being located far out in the countryside that surrounded the city, a relatively safe place to stay. Zombies had walked by every now and then, but none bothered trying to get inside. Even if they did, Frank had barricaded the doors and a few of the windows, so he could have probably handled them anyway. He had even found a reliable weapon in the gift shop: A shovel left behind by someone who had boarded the escape train.


Frank waited patiently for his first day here and didn't grow worried when the train didn't show up on the next day... when it didn't show up on day three, four, or five he soon began considering heading out on his own. He sat down on the edge of the platform and looked out over the woods before him. It was beautiful in the morning sun of his fifth day here and provided him with a small bit of comfort. "Looks like... its finally time to head out..." Frank said as he went back inside and picked up his shovel, stuffed some snacks into his backpack, and walked past the covered up corpse of the only zombie that had managed to break inside. It was an old woman who had been part of a group that had passed by. She was the only one to noticed Frank and he dealt with her quite easily, but he took note that the group she had been with was larger then the ones before. He knew if he stayed here it would only be a matter of time before a big group found him... and then he would be in trouble. Frank jumped down onto the train tracks and began following them west as the bright morning sunlight blanketed the city in a brand new day. He took one last look at his home for the past five days and disappeared behind a corner into the trees. He walked for 25 minutes before coming to a road that crossed the tracks. To his left about 40 yards up the road was an abandoned mini-van...

What should he do?
122.title: It was good while it lasted...

1221.content:
Frank decided it was best not to get sidetracked and kept moving along the tracks without checking the van. Even if there was something useful inside it he already had plenty of supplies and a decent weapon. Right now the most important thing Frank could do was put as much distance between himself and the city as possible. It was unlikely that there would be many zombies out this far anyway, and the probability of running into one of them would surely decrease as he got further away. "I bet they have some sort of safe zone just a few more miles up ahead. I'll get there without even seeing another zombie." Frank said confidently to himself, keeping his eyes peeled on the surrounding trees for signs of movement. "Still, it can't hurt to be careful..." The wilderness was beautiful, but Frank knew all too well how dangerous the forests around Bitterwood could get. Bears, wolves, and other vicious animals made their home amongst the trees. Now they could all be undead as well, which only contributed to their intimidation factor. The thought of a red eyed wolf shambling out of the trees crossed Frank's mind. "Jesus, I just hope I find something soon... all this walking in silence is maddening..."


His lonesome journey continued for another half an hour before he stopped for a second time. Up ahead was a large steel bridge that crossed Limestone Creek below. It was roughly 25 yards long and very narrow. Frank got off the tracks and sat down on a rock overlooking the shimmering water below. He couldn't see any zombie fish, but that didn't surprise him. It was at least a 50 foot drop from the bridge above and filled with quite a few sharp rocks. Frank opened his backpack and pulled out a bag of trail mix to eat while he took a rest. "Guess I'll have to cross that bridge if I want to keep going this way..." He said as took a sip from one of his 5 water bottles. Once he was done with his snack he stuffed the empty bag and bottle back into his backpack. "Time to get this over with..." He grabbed ahold of the railing and tried to avoid looking down. "Focus on moving... keep moving..." Frank thought to himself as he looked ahead to make sure a train wasn't coming. It was an immense relief when his feet finally touched solid ground on the other side. "Well, that ordeal is over... now I just need to keep m-" He was suddenly cut off by a loud growl that seemed to come from all directions at once. It didn't sound vicious or even angry... just otherworldly... like it didn't belong.


Frank tightened his grip on his shovel and took a quick look around. The only visible movement came from the wind blowing softly through the trees and weeds. As soon as the growl ended the whole world seemed to return to a dead calm. No noise. No movement. No malice could be detected. It was without a doubt the most unnerving thing Frank had experienced yet. Hell, he questioned whether he had even heard anything or not as he slowly moved along. All was silent except for the crunch of his shoes as he walked. Up ahead Frank could see a dirt trail that led up a hill deeper into the woods. It might be safer then walking out in the open on the train tracks... or it might lead him straight into the jaws of some hellish animal. Suddenly, without warning, a second growl echoed throughout the forest... this time a little closer... and angrier...

12212.content:
Frank picked up his pace a little as he continued forward down the tracks. Being out in the woods alone with god knows how many otherworldly creatures was slowly starting to get to his nerves and he hoped he'd run into someone soon. A shelter, a rescue party, even another lone survivor... anything but another hour of hiking alone in silence. Unfortunately for Frank, he would soon get his wish.

After nearly twenty more minutes of walking he caught sight of something on the tracks up ahead. It was too far to make out in the distance but as he kept moving closer the true horror of the situation slowly began to dawn on him. Within minutes it became perfectly clear what the obstruction was: a wrecked series of train cars that had been severed from the rest in some kind of accident. Passenger cars, to be specific, which explained the wandering zombies that slowly began to shamble into view from behind the trees and wreckage.

"Oh... oh fuck..." Frank whispered in horror as the walking corpses noticed him and began their slow approach. They were all slow and gruesomely mangled, but there seemed to be at least a dozen of them with even more popping out with every passing minute. Frank slowed his approach and smacked a skinny teenage girl to the ground as she tried to lunge at him, which caused a spray of teeth and rotten flesh to splatter the creature behind her. She let out one final grunt as Frank smashed in her ruined head and then took a quick jab at the zombie behind her.

This one was an older man who looked to be in his early thirties and had lost half of his body and left arm, another easy opponent. Frank's blow snapped his twisted spine like a dry twig and caused him to collapse in a heap as his remaining arm flailed about weakly. He was quickly finished off with a few good whacks to the head and soon fell motionless as his comrades drew ever closer.

Frank backed up a few steps as he looked over the approaching wave of undead ghouls and realized this was a pointless fight. Even if he killed another ten the stragglers would likely just close off his escape and pin him. "Shit, guess I'll have to come up with something else." he muttered as he knocked an obese woman into one of her companions. Just then, another chilling growl came from nearby, whatever it belonged to was getting closer as well. "Well, doesn't this just fucking suck..." he groaned as he turned around to gaze at the tracks behind him.

Frank better think of something to do quickly...

"Oh... oh shit!" Frank shouted as he broke into a run, desperate to get away from whatever was making the noise. In his panicked state he jumped off the tracks and began making his way up the trail. He stumbled a bit at first as he tried to keep his footing on the weed and branch choked path. At one point he stumbled to the ground and smacked his shoulder on a rock, only to immediately pick himself up and continue on as he cursed under his breath. In all his haste he didn't even notice the wooden sign off to the side of the trail, the one with a large "R" in a circle spray painted on it... After 10 minutes of relentless running Frank finally slowed to a walk and began looking around at his surroundings. The path twisted and turned up ahead through the trees and bushes. It was also shady and cool with a gentle breeze blowing and the soothing sound of Limestone creek could be heard in the distance. Best of all there were no longer any signs of a third growl happening, it seemed Frank was safe for the time being. "Thank god... I must have lost it..." He said as he continued up the trail.


It wasn't long before a large wood billboard of some sort caught Frank's attention up ahead. "That trail must have taken me into the nature preserve..." Frank noted as he checked it out. There was a map of the preserve plastered on it with a plastic container filled with smaller copies right below it. This was useful, but the real prize was hidden deep within the attached wooden box on the side. Intrigued by the "R" symbol carved on the front Frank opened it to find a knife, two bottles of beer stuffed with rags, a lighter, and about a dozen pamphlets with details about the park written on them. "Well now, what do we have here..." Frank said cheerfully as he reached in and grabbed the supplies. "This knife is in excellent condition, guess now I don't have to carry around this shovel anymore..." With that he stuffed the molotov cocktails in his backpack and laid his shovel against the side of the billboard. The last thing he did was grab a map and he set out with his brand new knife. It didn't take long for it to be put to use either. The billboard wasn't even out of sight when a large badger crawled out of the weeds. It was heavily decayed and missing one of its eyes, just the sight of such a mangled creature almost made Frank puke.


The Beast tried charging him with the few fangs it had left bared and ready to bite a chunk out of his flesh. Fortunately, Frank was able to avoid its initial attack and plunge his new weapon deep into the monsters rotten skull. A sound like crushing a pumpkin was heard and the badger collapsed to the ground. Frank took a moment to catch his breath and looked down at the glimmering blood-soaked blade. It was beautiful in the tiny bit of sunlight shining through the leaves. "I think I'm gonna like this knife..." Frank said as he wiped the blade clean and moved on, eager to dispatch more of the undead. Soon he came to a divide in the path with a sign in between the split, It read:

<----- Moonlight Hill
Park Ranger Station ----->

Below that was a bloody handprint with more words written crudely beneath it:

You can all go to hell. Stay the fuck out!

Frank looked up each path. To the left he could see a tall hill in the distance past the trees. To the right he was sure he could make out some type of building. Which way seems better?
12213.title: Take a hike

choices: Takes a quick look inside the window before opening the door
Calls out to see if anyone is inside
122132.content:
It was tiring trying to walk uphill after all the hiking and running Frank had done that morning, but at least the trail was easy to navigate. There were few branches and the only weeds were off the side, the view was pretty nice too. By now the sun had climbed higher in the sky and was casting its warming rays all over the cool forest. Frank looked out over the preserve as he climbed higher up the hill, admiring its beauty to keep his mind off the horrors lurking within it. Off in the distance past all the flowers and plants he could see the city, in all its remaining glory. Amazingly, it looked the same as it always had. If Frank had just arrived here from out of town he'd think there was nothing wrong, well, until he got a little closer. "Its incredible how much Bitterwood has changed over the past few days... and still, it looks exactly like it always has from this distance..." He took one of his water bottles out of his backpack and took a sip as he marched along. It didn't take long to reach the campsite at the top, although it hardly looked like one anymore. The few tents were either torn down or sprayed with blood, the grills and benches were broken or in some cases, totally destroyed with pieces strung about the area, and the ground was covered in litter. To top it all off, there were corpses and a few body parts laying about, some on the ground, a few on the tables, and one that was hanging off the roof of the nearby restroom. It was uncertain when was the last time living people had stayed here, but it appeared as if days had pasted without anyone passing through, alive or dead.


"Well, I certainly took the right path back there..." Frank said sarcastically as he walked by the grisly scene and took a seat on one of the undamaged benches. "At least there were no zombies here." He thought as he pulled out a bag of chips and had a snack. When he was done he threw the bag into an overturned garbage can and decided to explore a bit. He doubted that there was anything useful in the restroom so he started with the tents. Only three were still standing, but that didn't stop Frank from looking over the collapsed ones as well. Along with countless beer cans and various other litter he came across a working flashlight, an undamaged sleeping bag, and a handgun. The gun only had 2 bullets left in it, but it was better then another melee weapon. After frank had checked the tents he moved on to the small cabin a litter higher up the hill overlooking the campsite. It wasn't fancy, yet had a strange charm to it. Of course, anything would look inviting to someone who spent the last five days sleeping on the floor of a train station. Frank walked up to it and...
122132.title: Moonlight hill

choices: Frank panics and runs
Frank attempts to kill the zombie
1221321.content:
Frank walked over to the nearby window and peered inside. The partially closed curtains shrouded the room in darkness, but he could make out some faint movement in the far corner. "Hello, can you hear me in there?" Frank called as he tapped the window lightly with the butt of his gun. The creature inside stirred and moaned as it struggled to get up. "Are you hurt, do you need help?!" Frank called worriedly as he began looking for his flashlight. "Hang on, as soon as I find my flashlight I'll come in there and get you out of h-" A bright glimpse of red light caught Frank's attention inside. The woman who had been confined there finally noticed the living human standing just outside the window. Her lips curled into a wicked smile and she let out a soft growl. "Oh, oh no..." Frank gasped as she lifted her head and stared at him with her burning crimson eyes. Frank's hand touched plastic on the inside of his backpack and he quickly flipped the switch to turn his flashlight on. With a deep breath Frank shone the light inside and illuminated the form of the thing looking at him. She had once been a young woman, pretty and polite, who had never left her friends side. She was also the apple of her parents eye and always got good grades in school. The week before she had planned on going on a camping trip with her friends to celebrate their high school graduation. The party had been fun and her first time was something she knew she'd remember forever.


Unfortunately, forever turned out to be a cool September night that was interrupted by the sounds of the damned returning to the earth. The last thing she had seen was her best friend getting ripped apart right in front of her while they desended upon the helpless campers. That was five nights ago. Frank had been the first person to find them, and now more then ever, he wished he hadn't. "Jesus Christ!" Frank yelled as he stumbled backwards onto the ground and accidentally fired a shot through the window. The woman, or rather, the zombie inside was no longer as pretty as she had once been. All that was left of the poor girl was a torso, one mangled arm, and an immense desire to kill. "Shit! SHIT!" Frank cursed as he backed away from the cabin and climbed to his feet. The only sounds that tainted the air were Frank's heavy breathing and the scratching of the zombie moving inside the cabin...
1221321.title: A night they'll never forget...

choices: Frank checks the room at the end of the hallway
Frank investigates the second floor
12213212.content:
It was a few minutes before Frank fully snapped back to reality. What he had seen inside the cabin scared and disgusted him... but he knew he couldn't just leave the poor girl like that. "Goddamn it..." He said with a sigh as he walked back up to the door. He could hear the creature moving around inside, although he couldn't be sure exactly where it was. He took a deep breath and checked the chamber of his gun. He knew there was only one bullet left, that he would have only one shot at this, yet the actual sight of it prevented him from becoming careless. With his flashlight in one hand and his gun in the other there would be no time to draw his knife... this was it. Frank turned the knob slowly while listening carefully for sound on the inside. Dead silence. It knew he was coming in...


The door creaked slightly as it swung open and shone a ray of light upon the gloomy inside. The girl was nowhere to be seen. "Fuck..." Frank cursed as he moved the flashlight about to check every nook and cranny for life. Decade old paintings of fields and trees were illuminated on the dustly walls along with several antique-looking pieces of furniture. It was cozy and at the same time deeply unsettling. Frank took a few causious steps and let the door close quietly behind him. In front of him was a door leading to what seemed to be the kitchen. Right next to the door was a set of stairs and a hallway leading to a room on the other side of the cabin. Three ways to go and no way of knowing if one would lead him into a trap. Figuring that the kitchen was as good a place to start as any Frank walked into the small room, ready to fire at anything that no longer looked human...


The only things to be found were what anyone could expect to find in your average kitchen. A table with a tattered red and white checkered cloth covering it, an old green refridgerator, and a sink on the counter with a blood soaked sponge lying next to it. Frank walked over to investigate, only to stop dead in his tracks upon hearing a board creak in the next room over. Then a thought crossed his mind...

What if there were more then one of them in here?

Frank spun around to the door leading to the back room of the cabin and grabbed ahold of the aged bronze handle. He tried to turn it but it wouldn't budge. There was something blocking off the back room from this direction... he would have to go around through the hallway. "Shit... this kitchen was a dead end..." Frank groaned as he quickly stepped back into the living room. He had two ways he could search... the room at the end of the hallway... or the upstairs. One of these two places had something waiting for him... and he was determined to find it.
12213212.title: Hide and seek

choices: another train station
an abandoned train
Readers Choice
1222.content:
Frank walked over to the van, which was a blue 2002 Kia Sedona.

http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/co...

Frank smashed the drivers side door, to make sure noone was inside. Assured noone was in the van, he broke the drivers side window, and unlocked the van. Then he walked around to the rear hatch and opened it to reveal an array of weapons.

There was a Saiga 12 with a 20-round drum
http://www.imfdb.org/w/images/a/a3/Saiga...

a Mossberg 590 shotgun
http://www.imfdb.org/w/images/c/cb/Mossb...

and a Colt Single Action Army
http://www.imfdb.org/w/images/8/80/ColtS...

Thankfully, there was also a crate of ammo as well. He took the asult rifle and some ammo. He then shut the rear door, went back to the drivers seat and managed to hotwire the engine. "I'll be able to travel more quickly in this." he said. He then put the van into drive, and drove, still following the train tracks. After several miles, Frank came upon
1222.title: Head down the road towards the van

choices: The sporting goods store
The electronics store
The food court
123.content: Frank sat alone behind the counter of a small gun store located deep inside the Bitterwood city mall, perhaps the only safe place left in the entire city. Frank had first found out about the recent zombie outbreak many days ago when the zombified remains of a group of girl scouts broke into his appartment building. Shortly after they appeared the whole building and everyone in it except Frank were either dead or a zombie. Frank had managed an escape by nothing less then a miracle. He remembered shooting at least 2 people with his brothers revolver during his escape, the rest was mostly a giant horrible blur. Frank was shaking, he had killed two people, zombified or not, he had taken two human lives. He checked the revolver to see how much ammo was left, 3 bullets. For a brief moment Frank contemplated suicide, but what would that solve? It wouldn't bring those people back. It would simply add another body to the growing count, and Frank had witnessed enough death to last him a lifetime. He sat up, wiped the fresh tears from his eyes and placed the revolver back in the gun holster on his belt. He knew he wouldn't last long barricated in a gun store without any food or water so he worked up his courage and decided to leave. He had been isolated in here for 5 days with the only exit covered by boxes, for all he knew all this could be over, maybe the army was rescuing survivors at this very minute. Frank walked over to the door and took down the boxes while trying to keep calm. If there were zombies out there, he would have only his revolver with 3 shots to defend himself with. The gunstore had been cleaned out when he had arrived and only provided shelter along with a few bags of chips and some water bottles he had found stashed in the back in a safe that had been forced open. Frank removed the last box and opened the door slowly. The entire mall was quiet with the only sound coming from the chilling breeze blowing outside. Everything in sight was cast in shadow and disorder, but thankfully there were no zombies in sight. Frank creeped slowly away from the door and started walking towards the fountain in the middle of the vast room. Moonlight shining down from the large windows overhead provided enough light to see which made navigating somewhat easier even though it made Frank feel like he was in some kind of horror movie. After passing an overturned bench while making his way to the fountain Frank saw a directory sitting in the darkness over to his right. It was somewhat hard to read, but there was just enough light for Frank to see all the major nearby locations marked. Nearby stores included a sporting goods store (that may have things Frank could use as weapons or armor), an electronics store (which may have some flashlights somewhere inside), and the food court (hopefully still with food). Where should Frank go?
123.title: Alone in the shadows...

choices: Frank looks for something he could use as armor (Pads, helmets, and so on)
Frank looks for something he could use as a weapon (Golf clubs, bats, and so on)
Frank looks for something that will help him carry stuff (Like a duffel bag)
1231.content:
It had been a few minutes since Frank had decided to go check out the nearby sporting goods store and by now the quietness was starting to get to him. He started to hum a soft tune to himself as he walked down the (hopefully) empty hallway. The eerie silence was the last of his worries though as the area in front of him seemed to get more messy, damaged, and...bloody with each step he took. Frank began fingering his weapon as he hurried along. He decided to hum a bit louder, careful to keep his voice somewhat low in case any of those things were nearby, but quickly stopped right before he got to the store when he noticed something written on the glass window of a nearby jewelry store:

"Help me"

It was written in blood and the end of "me" was smeared down along the glass all the way to the bottom. It must have also been at least a few days old as the blood was dried and starting to peel. Frank took in this disturbing scene slowly and it was a few seconds before he managed to speak again. "Jesus..." He was deeply unerved now and a bit frightened too. This little sign wasn't fresh and it was entirely possible that whatever had occured here had happened long enough ago that there was no remaining danger...still, it was unsettling to find. Frank pulled his gun out of its holster and pointed it ahead aimlessly as he slowly walked on. Finally, he had made it to the front of "Bret and Chad's sports emporium." The outside looked nice enough with the windows intact, the interrior mostly undamaged, and not a drop of blood to be seen. "Guess I'll head on in." Frank said with as much bravery as he could muster. The inside was quite plesant, in fact it was even better looking then the outside. There were rows upon rows of basketballs, footballs, baseballs, soccerballs, and even a few balls for less popular sports such as rugby and polo. The shelves were all lined with hockey sticks, baseball bats, and several other types of fine sports equipment. Towards the the back of the store were T-shirts for sports teams Frank had never even heard of along with things like pads and hockey masks that could give Frank some protection if he needed it. After seeing all of this Frank started to feel a little more safe and was able to regain some of his confidence. He then began to wonder what he should look at first. This place was fairly large compared to most of the other nearby stores and he didn't want to waste too much time here.
1231.title: Bad signs and good signs...

choices: Frank heads towards the hold-out, maybe they are still there...
Frank heads towards the other direction, they must have moved on by now...
12311.content: Frank already had a weapon and could worry about getting supplies later, right now he wanted to get some protection so he wouldn't be helpless if one of these things jumped him. He walked to the back and began looking at the different types of padding the store had. He managed to find pads to cover his shoulders, torso, elbows, and knees, a football helmet for his head, and even put on a sports cup (he wasn't willing to leave anything vulnerable if he could help it). After making sure everything was on right he walked over to a mirror to see how bad he looked. "Well, it makes me look like an idiotic sports mascot, but at least it'll help keep me in one piece." He walked back towards the front when something crashed through the window and knocked him to the ground. It was an animalistic Stalker who had found a live human, possibly the last one in the whole city. Frank's gun had been knocked out of his hand and sent flying across the store when the thing jumped him, it would be of no help now. Frank sat up on the floor as the Stalker made a second attempt to kill him with its razor-sharp claws. He had no time to react and took the blow full-force as the zombie ripped off his shoulder pad and knocked him into a nearby shelf. Frank felt dizzy from the blow and couldn't stand up right away. The Stalker growled as it raised its hand again for the final strike. Frank quickly grabbed something from the shelf he was backed up against and swung it at the Stalker just as it went for the kill. The aluminum baseball bat Frank had managed to grab caught the zombie on the side of the neck just as its outstretched hand made contact with Frank's other shoulder. The creature had managed to tear off Frank's other shoulder pad, but other than that he was okay. He stood up as the Stalker laid twitching on the floor and finished it off with one last blow to the head. "I'm sorry..." Frank said as he walked over to an open box laying on the ground behind the front counter. Inside were a few posters, a duffel bag, and a note. Frank slung the duffel bag over his now bare shoulder and picked up the note. "Dear... Anyone." He read aloud. "If you are reading this get out of the mall, these goddamn monsters have overrun security and are growing in number. I don't know why they haven't just surrounded us and killed us yet, we're mostly unarmed and a few of us are injured. They must be planning something. We'll try to get out tomorrow night when Sam gets back. If this note is still in the sporting goods store where I left it our holdout location should be north-west up the escalator. The door next to the nearby toy store has a red circle on it, thats where we are. On the way there's a Re-supply trash can hidden behind the escalator. Inside are 2 handguns, a box of snack food, and a few pictures of... my daughter, Marie. If you see her, please bring her to us. We were seperated earlier and I can't leave without her. I've looked for her everywhere, I haven't found her yet, but... I KNOW she's still out there, she's smart, she wouldn't have died. I know you'll want to get out of here as soon as possible, but I beg of you, if you see my little girl please bring her back to me. I'll be waiting. - Mark" Frank silently put the note in his pocket and walked back outside.
12311.title: In need of help

choices: Quickly hid behind the counter at the front of the store
Took aim and prepared to shoot it
Used his flashlight to get a better look at whatever it was
1232.content: After walking in almost complete darkness for the last fifteen minutes Frank was glad when he finally came upon the small abandoned electronics store. The lights inside were all off except for one dying light flickering on and off in the back. "I best be quick or that light might go out while I'm inside." Frank said as he walked into the store. It was hard to see anything, but Frank could make out most of the objects as he moved past the shelves quickly yet quietly. He soon came upon a stand with all types of batteries lined up on it in neat little rows. Frank took as many as he could fit in his pockets and made sure to take as many different types as possible to make sure he would have what he needed when and if he found a flashlight. Soon after Frank had finished collecting batteries he came upon some small hand radios sitting on a shelf. He picked one up and tried turning it on to see if he could find out anything about the zombies that had appeared only five days ago. All the radio seemed to pick up was static so Frank shut it off, but decided to take it with him just in case. He continued his search and found himself at the back wall in no time. If he didn't find a flashlight here he would have to leave. Fortunately he came across a row of flashlights about halfway through the shelf. He took 2 of them (a large handheld flashlight and a smaller one that barely fit into his battery-stuffed pocket) and started walking back towards the entrance with his new flashlight in his right hand and his gun in his left. Frank was about to walk back outside when he saw something move near a bench. It stayed low to the ground and seemed to walk on all four of its legs. Frank was sure it hadn't seen him yet so he...
1232.title: A bright idea

12321.content: Frank quickly hid behind the front counter next the corpse of a man named Tom. The smell of the decaying body was horrible, but Frank didn't dare move, lest that thing see him. He had no idea what it was... he just knew there was no way something like that was good. He couldn't have been more right. The Stalker had apparently seen him after all, and it decided to strike first. Frank felt a horrible surge of pain as a razor-sharp clawed hand forced its way violently through his torso. He tried to scream, but could only make gurgling noises as his blood drained out. The Stalker finished him off by ripping out his heart and shredding it in its hand. After licking most of the blood off its arm it took one last look at Frank's mangled body and moved on in search of more prey.
12321.title: The silent killer

choices: He makes a run for it!
He stands his ground and gets ready to confront his attacker...
12323.content:
Instinctively, Frank shone the light on the strange creature and soon realized he had made a terrible mistake. The thing looked vaguely human, but couldn't have possibly been more inhuman. It had long claws, sharp teeth, and worst of all, glowing demonic red eyes. Frank screamed and fired off a shot with his gun as the thing began sprinting towards him. The bullet connected with its shoulder and caused it to stumble, but it just shrugged it off and ignored the blood pouring from the wound. Frank had used the distress to flee deeper inside the store and it was now hurt... but it didn't matter. It had found prey, that alone was more important then any injury it could ever receive, even a fatal one. The monster licked at its bleeding flesh with what could be considered a look of glee on its twisted face. The small shred of a mind it had left knew this would be fun. Most of its other victims hadn't been so helpless, it had to wait for them to make a careless mistake before it got them... this one would be different.


Frank was trapped inside a store that could lose its last light and go pitch black any minute, was small and allowed little room to maneuver, and... it could smell his fear. A fear that the Stalker knew all too well... the fear that came from someone cornered with no way out. Frank raised his gun again and desperately fire another shot. The sound of glass breaking told him he hadn't even come close to hitting his target. One shot left. Frank ran even deeper into the store as the Stalker ran off into the shadows right behind him. "Shit, where did it go?!" He yelled as he moved the flashlight around franticly, trying to get even a tiny glimpse of the demonic predator. Nothing. Not even the sound of growling or heavy breathing. All Frank could hear was his own heartbeat... and that would soon change if he didn't do something. He was about to take a literal shot in the dark when he noticed the aisle between him and the exit was clear. He could make a run for it... and hope that thing didn't jump out and rip him apart. The option of staying here and waiting for its inevitable attack wasn't much better... but at least then he'd have a decent shot at it. What does he do?
12323.title: Helpless prey?

choices: A nearby flight of stairs that led to the second floor
The nearest exit
123232.content:
Frank had spent his whole life up to that point running from confrontations, even trivial ones. He had apologized to people who bumped into him on the sidewalk, he walked away when people made fun of him without answering back, he never stood up to bullies when he was a kid, and he ran away from his first encounter with the undead. He couldn't bear to do it again, even if it meant his death. He would stand his ground for the first time and face his foe head on. "Bring it, you little bitch..." He called out with a little of his courage restored. "I'm right here." A few seconds passed before the Stalker made its move. All that could be heard was Frank's own heart as a pair of clawed hands emerged from the darkness. Not even a scream escaped either combatant's lips as Frank squeezed the trigger on his revolver for the final time. A single shot rang out as blood splattered all over the nearby shelfs. Frank fell to the floor with a thud with the Stalker on top of him. The things claws and teeth had sunk into his arms and shoulder. Frank closed his eyes and waited for the monster to finish him off...


Only it didn't. The Stalker's limp body had hit Frank with enough force to sink its claws and teeth into his flesh, but not deep enough to cause a fatal amount of blood loss. Indeed, most of the blood splattered in the confrontation had come from the bullet hole in the Stalker's head. Once Frank realized his victory he shoved the things dead body off of him and felt around for his dropped flashlight. It took him no time to find it and he quickly shone it on the body of his enemy to make sure it was dead. The sight was sickening, but it was clear the zombie wouldn't be getting back up. "I killed him... it... I killed another one." Frank gasped as he returned his empty gun to its holster. "I took another life, yet... somehow I don't regret it..." Frank looked down at his shaking hands and bleeding arms. "It hurts like hell, but its not deep." He said to himself reassuringly. "I'm still alive... because I did what I had to... these people... these things are not human, not anymore. They may be able to move, but all they are is corpses..." Frank walked out of the store with a heavy heart and found another directory with his flashlight sitting about thirty feet away with a few bloodstains on it. Oddly, this didn't seem to bother Frank and he was soon on his way to...
123232.title: Taking a stand

choices: Leave the store and continue onwards
Investigate the store, there may be people inside!
1232321.content:
Frank decided to get to higher ground where he'd have a somewhat better view and hopefully encounter less zombies. He didn't see a single zombie on the way to the stairs, so this was probably a good idea. As it turned out the little icon on the directory had stood for escalator, which wasn't really much help, but Frank was grateful for the small luxury. He just hoped he didn't end up using all of his luck on trivial matters or small conveniences. "As if I even believe in luck!" Frank said with a laugh. It felt good to have a small break from the horror surrounding him, even if only for a few seconds. The first thing Frank saw as he stepped off of the escalator was a large coffee shop with a banner over the entrance proudly advertising their newest concoction, which looked to be some strange blend of coffee and fruit. He had always been more of a tea person, but wouldn't have turned down a free cup of warm refreshment if it had been extract of pickle and lemon juice. Frank cheerfully walked in and looked over the vast wall of flavors and styles, over two hundred in all! When he finally found one he liked he began making himself a cup while looking the place over. All that he found besides countless packets of artificial sweetener was a kitchen knife that was stained with days old blood that was peeling and flaking. "I don't think I wanna know the story behind this..." Frank said as he looked at a thin trail of dried blood that led across the table and disappeared into the floor. "But its good to have a weapon."


In a few minutes Frank found himself pouring a cup of coffee and relaxing at a table near the back wall next to the counter. Well, as best as one could relax in a situation such as this. A single sip was all it took to let him know it was too bitter for his taste and he was soon filling his cup with several packets of sweetener and cream. Another sip confirmed it as still bitter, yet tolerable so Frank sat down his knife and flashlight and took a few minutes for himself. When he had finished his drink he got up and threw away the empty cup, grabbed his knife and flashlight and headed out. He moved a little further along and soon came to a store that was barricaded with everything from boards to stacked boxes and empty shelves. Fitting, considering it was a hardware store stocked with all manner of home improvement supplies. Frank knocked softly on an overturned work bench that helped cover the main entrance and called out quietly to anyone inside. When no one answered he knocked a little louder and when he again got no response, shone his flashlight through an opening and looked around inside. He saw something move near the back, but couldn't tell what it was. He thought for a moment and decided to...
1232321.title: Coffee break

1232322.content:
Frank walked down the pitch black hallway towards the exit with his flashlight barely illuminating the darkness around him. He passed a pair of restrooms and turned around the last corner to see a single metal door at the end of the passage. It seems he had found his salvation... or did he? The door was intact... and also locked with a key that could be anywhere in the mall now, although it was most likely still on the corpse of one of the security guards. "No, damn it!" Frank cursed as he tried to get the door open. "I should have known it would be locked..." He said as he turned around to see someone walk around the corner. Its dark outline seemed feminine and it walked slowly as a sad moan escaped its lips. Frank shone his flashlight on it to see that it was indeed a young woman, a deceased one. She walked up to him with an expression that Frank could only interpret as sad/troubled and reached out as if she meant to hug him. In a panic Frank smacked her in the side of the head with his flashlight as he backed up against the door.


She fell to the ground, but quickly got back up with three red streams of blood running down her face. Two of which were coming from her despair-filled red eyes. Suddenly, her face twisted into an expression of pure rage as she let out a loud howling shriek. Frank covered his ears and dropped his flashlight as he put one of his hands on the door for support. Then, as quickly as it had started, the shriek stopped and her face returned to its sad state. This was all he could take, Frank wanted to get the hell away from this thing as quickly as he could. He ran back down the hall as best he could in the complete darkness and knocked aside a zombie as he stumbled past the two bathrooms where the Siren must have been hiding. A horde of level ones had been gathering near the entrance and Frank was having a little trouble getting back to the main hallway. That little became a lot real quick as another shriek echoed from down the hallway behind him. Frank fell to his knees as the zombies quickly surrounded him. He passed away before the poor undead girl could even finish her second song, a dirge of undiluted sadness that stopped humans in their tracks...
1232322.title: Just a dead end...

choices: Exit the mall and make his way across the parking lot outside
Go back the way he came and check out the other stores
Check the restrooms
1233.content: Frank hadn't had anything to eat in over a day and decided that since the mall seemed abandoned he wouldn't need to use his gun any time soon. He could look for more weapons after he got something in his stomach. He tried to walk in the shadows as much as possible to avoid being seen, just in case there were zombies in here somewhere. After five minutes of walking without seeing anything he came to the food court. It was quite large and had over two dozen different places to eat, it even had some games and rides in the center which reminded Frank of a carnival. Most of the ceiling was taken up by a large glass window that lit the entire room with beautiful moonlight. The brightness was comforting and made things much easier to see. Frank took a plastic bag from one of the nearby resteraunts and began checking for anything he could take with him. After checking a few places all he had found was a can of grape soda. "People who were here before me must have cleaned these places out..." Frank said as he hopped back over the counter of a KFC. He went over to check some of the overturned vending machines that had been broken into. Most were empty, but he did find some candy bars and a bag of BBQ chips that someone had left behind in a machine that had been turned over on its side. Frank opened one of the candy bars and put the rest in his bag. After a little more searching he came across another bag of chips (green onion) and a bottle of water. He decided to save the water for later and opened the grape soda, drinking the whole thing in 3 big gulps. It was good to finally get something to eat and drink, but Frank didn't want to stay too long so he decided to move on. The food court had an exit that led to the outside parking lot on the far end, but Frank didn't know how safe it would be outside. He could go back the way he came and try to find one of the other stores he had read about on the directory, but it could be hard to find his way back. Lastly off to the side of the food court was a hallway that led to some more vending machines and some restrooms. Frank thought for a moment and decided to...
1233.title: Thank god for vending machines!

choices: Keep running towards the store
Try to get to the van
12331.content: The cold night air was like a sharp slap to the face when it hit Frank as he stepped outside. He didn't think it would be this cold out and wish he had worn warmer clothes. "Oh well..." He said to himself. "At least its not raining." He stepped off of the sidewalk that ran along the outside of the mall and into the parking lot. Aside from a few overturned or wrecked cars everything looked the same. The pale moon hung overhead, lacing everything in a thick blanket of light. It was even creepier outside the mall, but Frank was glad to be able to see. As he walked he began to feel slightly uneasy, as if something was wrong. He hadn't seen a single zombie since leaving the gun store. "Hello, is anyone there!" He called nervously. Silence. Frank decided to pick up the pace and get out of this open area as fast as possible. He could feel it, something was out here with him, something evil. He was halfway across the parking lot when he found out what that something was. A few crows with glowing red eyes landed on one of the nearby light posts. They didn't attack right away, instead they waited for their friends to show up. It didn't take them long. Frank was up to a steady run by the time he noticed it. Birds of every shape and size were descending on the almost empty parking lot. Their grotesque bodies forming a dark shadow over the moon. "S-shit!" Frank spat as he made his way towards the nearest building, a lifeless looking video game store. The birds drew closer and began moving in for the kill when Frank noticed a van up ahead with the door open... on the other side of the row of cars he was running besides. If he wanted to get inside he would have to climb over at least two cars without stopping or falling off. He pulled his revolver out of its holster with his free hand and got ready to fire when he glanced ahead across the road at the video game store. Just a little further and he'd make it. He fired off a shot that caught a beakless robin in the wing, severing it. He was almost past the van with the open door... what will he do?
12331.title: Moonlit legion

choices: Frank checks behind the counter
Frank checks the storage room
123311.content: For a brief moment Frank considered taking the risk and trying to get to the van... but couldn't bring himself to chance it. All he'd have to do is slip once and it would all be over. He gritted his teeth as he crossed the highway and pulled open the door to the abandoned building on the other side. He closed it back just in time to sever the head off of a small sparrow. The next few seconds were filled with the sound of tiny dead bodies colliding into the glass windows and door. Thankfully, the undead birds didn't have enough strength to penetrate through and many were left splattered stains on the sidewalk outside. After a few minutes the birds began to fly back to their posts on the edge of the mall, maybe later they'd get some other hapless survivor traveling alone in the dark, but not tonight. Frank leaned against the stores counter next to a cardboard cut out of a space marine from a newly released game. He had made it just in time, another second and he would have been bird food. Frank sat his bag of food on the floor and took out the bottle of water he had gotten earlier and had a drink. Afterwards, he placed it back in his bag and checked his revolver, two shots left. "Damn, I shouldn't have wasted a shot on that bird..." Frank said to himself as he got up off the floor. "Might as well have a look around. I don't think they'd sell bullets here, but maybe they have something else I can use..."
123311.title: Take that, Alfred Hitchcock!

choices: Frank chooses the AK-47
Frank chooses the grenade launcher
1233111.content:
Frank decided to check behind the counter first, if there was anything valuable in this tiny store it was likely to be there. Frank saw some boxes laying half open on the floor, but the only thing he found inside them were a few games and a broken controller. He had a little more luck when he checked the drawer beneath the cash register. Inside he found a switchblade and and a small flashlight. Frank decided to put the switchblade in his pocket for now and keep using his gun until it ran out of ammo. He checked the flashlight before adding it to his inventory to make sure it worked. The light flickered on and back off the two times he flipped the switch, it was a keeper. The moon had provided enough light to see at the current time, so Frank put his new flashlight into his pocket as well. After checking a few more drawers and not finding anything Frank decided to move on. He was just about to get up when he heard something click behind his back. The next thing he saw as he turned around was a shotgun about two inches from his face. "Don't fuckin move." The owner of the shotgun ordered in a calm voice. He looked pretty young, only about 20 or so years old. He was wearing a Halo t-shirt and black jeans. The only thing that suggested he was an adult and not a teenager was the short beard around his lower face. He looked Frank over for a few seconds before asking some questions. "Why did you come here?" Frank took a moment to find his voice, replying as soon as he was able to get over the surprise of having a gun pointed at him. "I-I came from the mall across the street. Some birds attacked me." The man gave Frank a look that said he didn't believe a word of what he had just told him.


Nevertheless, he asked another question to the frightened accountant. "Why are you alone? Did the group you were with get killed?" Frank answered more quickly this time. "No, I didn't have a group... I was the only one to escape my apartment alive." The man raised an eyebrow. "You saying you been by yourself this whole time? You must be one hell of a zombie killer then." Frank felt a bit ashamed of his next words. "No... I hid once I got out of the apartment. I've spent the last few days hiding in a gun store, the only reason I'm still alive is sheer dumb luck." The man looked into Franks eyes to try and tell if he was lying or not. "What you're telling me is the truth?" He asked as he leveled the shotgun with Franks forehead. "It is." Frank replied as he looked down the barrel of the gun at the man who held his life in his hands. There was silence for a few minutes, then the man pulled the gun away from Franks face and helped him up. "Name's Rob. You seem to be telling the truth so I'll trust you... for now." He walked back towards the door he had entered from and motioned for Frank to follow him. "Oh, thank you... my names Frank." He said as he joined his new ally in the stores supply room. On the floor inside was a large box with some high caliber guns inside. "You seem to be pretty unarmed so I'll let you have one of these." Rob said as he sat his shotgun against the wall. Frank didn't know how Rob had gotten ahold of these guns... and for the moment, he didn't care.
1233111.title: Who says all gamers are sociopaths?

choices: Frank thinks they should continue on foot
Frank thinks they should turn around and keep moving along the highway
12331111.content:
"Alright, I guess I'll take this one..." Frank said nervously as he lifted the gun out of the box. Rob gave him a smile and padded him on the back. "Ah, the Ak-47. Not quite as loud as a grenade launcher, but great for moving down the hordes of undead." Frank didn't really like using guns, yet felt a lot safer with his new weapon. "Just so you know, I've only fired a handgun before, not something like this..." He said as he looked over the powerful gun. Rob gave him a surprised look. "Its real simple, just pull the trigger when you see something move... that shouldn't. Its set to full auto, so you just need to make sure you actually hit something when you fire. I've got plenty of extra rounds, but we can't afford to waste ammo." Rob picked up his shotgun and headed back out into the store. "Wait here, I'll sneak out and bring the car around." He called as he walked over to the windows and looked outside. "I better do this quick... be ready to jump inside when I get back around, I'm not stopping and you'll get left behind if you're too slow." Frank didn't like the sound of this. "Wait, I just got here, shouldn't we-" The sound of the door slamming cut him off as Rob ran around the side of the store and disappeared. A few birds stirred in the distance, but didn't bother chasing him, he could just run back inside if they attacked him. They wouldn't make another move unless he was dumb enough to try and cross the parking lot.


Frank scratched his head as he stood just behind the large glass window, looking out into the night sky. It was so beautiful with the stars and moon shining overhead that it almost made Frank forget what lurked beneath it. He was lost in thought for only about a minute before he was snapped back to reality. A loud engine started and tires could be heard screeching. Quickly Frank ran outside and waited for Rob. The sound of the car grew louder and a small vehicle pulled out from around the other side of the store. Rob honked the horn and yelled for Frank to get in. Easier said then done. The car must have been going at least 40 miles an hour. Frank gulped as he ran across the road, turned back around, and jumped onto the opened passenger side door as it whizzed past. He tossed his Ak-47 in the back seat and quickly climbed in before shutting the door. "Nice job!" Rob said cheerfully as he sped around a corner onto the highway. Frank's heart was beating faster then it ever had before and his hands were shaking uncontrollably. "G-good job?!" Frank stammered angrily. "I just jumped onto a moving car! What in god's name were you thinking?!" Rob gave him a grin.


"Sorry, I had to outrun a couple level twos that saw me start the car. If I had slowed down they might have climbed on." Frank shifted in his seat as he struggled to get his seat belt on. "Ugh, just try not to be so reckless next time okay? You almost gave me a heart attack..." The duo moved along the mostly abandoned highway for about an hour before taking an exit off onto a back road, before finally coming to a wreck that blocked their path. "Well shit!" Rob shouted as he stopped the car and got out. He walked up to two crashed cars that cut off their way forward and looked around. Up ahead he could see a large sign advertising a reststop, a diner, and a motel further up ahead. He let out a sigh and walked back over to the car and got in. "Looks like we've got two choices, Frank." He said as he sat back down. "We can get out, and kept going on foot, or turn around and keep moving along the highway."
12331111.title: A speedy getaway

choices: They stop when they get to the reststop
They walk past the reststop and head straight for the diner/motel
123311111.content:
"We can't go back after coming this far." Frank said in a stern voice. "We were only able to get about 10 miles outside of the city in an hour's time. At this rate we're better off just going on foot." Rob nodded his head slowly in agreement. "Right, I was thinking the same thing, it'll be more work, but at least we won't need to worry about getting stuck somewhere, like now..." Frank let off a laugh. "Hey, you did a pretty good job getting us this far, especially with so many closed off streets in the city. Its almost like you knew exactly where to go." Rob stretched his arms before climbing out. "Yeah, that was mostly luck, I just followed the same roads I used to get to work. People may call me a slacker, but I sure do know how to find shortcuts and avoid roads known for heavy traffic. I never figured it would help me escape a zombie infested city though..." Frank opened his door and stepped out, taking in a deep breath of the cool night air. "Yeah... I never thought I'd have to fight my way out of my own apartment with my brothers revolver. Guess its been a pretty crazy week..." Rob laughed as he closed his door back. "Yeah, but it sure beats a week of work." Strangely. instead of joining Frank at the front of the car he moved around to the back. "What's the matter, you forget something?" Frank called as he remembered that he himself had left his bag of snacks back at the game store. "Ah, shit..." He blurted out as he joined Rob. "What is it?" He asked. "Its nothing... I just forgot some of my supplies back at the store..." Rob grinned that devilish grin again and Frank started to feel a little uneasy. "Oh don't worry..." Rob chuckled as he popped open the trunk. "I got plenty of supplies stockpiled for an emergency."


Inside the truck were three backpacks along with several boxes of ammunition. "Holy... shit." Frank gasped when he saw everything. "Where do you GET this stuff?" Rob grabbed a backpack and tossed it to him. "I'm just crazy prepared is all... I think that one has all the extra ammo for your AK. Shame we couldn't bring the grenade launcher too, I also got some spare rounds for it." Frank put on the backpack and almost fell over. "Jesus this thing is heavy." Rob put on a backpack himself and opened the last one that was still sitting in the trunk. He pulled out a can of red spray paint and close the truck back with his key still in it. After giving it a good shake he sprayed a crude circle on the trunks lid, along with a "R" in the center. When he was done he threw the can off to the side of the road. "It really is a shame you didn't bring a friend with you... we're gonna have to leave the food and drinks here." Frank stopped in his tracks when he heard this. "Wait, there was food and water in there?! Thats more important then ammo, lets put mine back and take that one!"


Rob simply shook his head as he walked. "No good, we need the extra ammo in your backpack and the spare gear in mine. The food does us no good if it can't help us kill zombies." Frank couldn't believe what he was hearing, this guy really was crazy. "Just how the hell do you suppose we survive without it then? We can't eat bullets or whatever "gear" you got in your backpack!" Rob let out a sigh. "Look, I'm nice enough to get you out of the city, share my stuff with you, and not shoot you in the face for getting on my nerves... and FYI there's a reststop, diner, AND motel up ahead. We can eat and drink all we want there before moving on." Frank simply shook his head silently as Rob began climbing over the cars. It seemed he had no choice but to trust him. It was a little hard to get over the the cars with a full backpack while also carrying an AK, but Frank managed just fine and jumped down next to Rob. "Guess complaining won't do me any good, go ahead and lead then..." Frank said as he followed Rob down the cold, quiet road...
123311111.title: Always take precautions

choices: "To get moving."
"To start setting up a place to sleep."
1233111111.content:
On their way to the reststop Frank and Rob came across only 3 level one zombies, which were easily dispatched by Rob's shotgun. "You take the next ones we see, okay Frank? You need to get used to firing that gun." He called as he reloaded his weapon. "Um... sure." Frank called back unenthusiastically. He wasn't sure he had what it took to take any more human lives, zombie or not. Fortunately for him, they came to the reststop before having to deal with any more undead. He was so glad to finally take a break that he ran past Rob and took a seat on one of the picnic benches next to an outdoor grill. Rob walked past him up towards the public bathrooms at the top of a steep hill to clear out any zombies that might be inside. "I'll be right back, I'm gonna go check the restrooms up there. If you want, you can come with me or stay here and rest for a bit." Rob called as he made sure he had plenty of spare ammo with him. "Yeah, I'll stay here. Call if you need anything." Frank replied as he took off his heavy backpack.


Rob returned about ten minutes later with stick of dynamite in his hand. "Jesus, where'd you get that?!" Frank shouted when he saw it. "Don't tell me that you had that when you went in there. "No..." Rob said with a grin. "It was pretty bad in there... blood, bodies, and trash everywhere, but the garbage can in the mens bathroom was a RSL." Frank gave him a confused look. "RSL?" Rob shook his head it disappointment. "RSL? Re-supply location? You didn't know that?" Frank shook his head. Rob let out a sigh. "Anyway..." He said. "I also found this." He held up a shiny metal lighter, a Zippo in fact. "Thats good, I guess." Frank said as he stood up and put his backpack back on. "I guess we'll be moving on now?" Rob shook his head. "Not just yet... come with me." Rob began walking back up to the bathroom with Frank following closely behind, curious to see what Rob had to show him. They walked past the soda machine outside and into the small smelly room. The first thing Frank noticed was the half dozen corpses scattered across the floor in pools of blood or torn sleeping bags. Most were fairly decayed and covered in blankets or sheets, but one or two were still fresh.


"Dear god, what HAPPENED in here?!" Frank gasped as backed up against the wall for support. Rob ignored the question and walked over to a stall with the door broken off. "Come here." He said as he knocked a severed leg out of the way with his foot. Frank began shaking, this was too much. What could have done something like this? He lowered his gun a little and slowly walked over to where his friend was standing. Rob pointed to some graffiti on the wall just above the broken toilet. Frank bent over and began slowly reading it to himself. "Sophie Newhart 1978 - 2012 A dear friend and loyal companion until the end. Bob Mills 1962 - 2012 Beloved father and brother. Taken too soon. Nick "Fingers" Rhodes 1989 - 2012 Saved my life at the cost of his." Frank was confused. "These names... are they the people who died here?" Rob pointed below the names at something else that was written. "This was what I wanted you to see, as for the names, they were probably scribbled down when other groups of survivors passed through here. But never mind that, just read this." Frank looked to where he pointed and read. "I saw one of them today, the ones who did this. The brotherhood. They wear white robes and each one has a unique ability. They used dark magic to do this. The only way to kill them is..." Frank trailed off as the paint used to write the message smudged, making the rest illegible. "What do they mean brotherhood?" Frank asked as he turned to Rob. "I don't know." Rob replied. "No point in worrying about it right now, we need..."
1233111111.title: A short rest

choices: Frank asks what they want...
Frank remains silent and waits to see how this plays out...
12331111112.content:
"What?! You want to sleep here?!" Frank shouted as soon as the words reached his ears, not caring at the moment that the volume of his voice might attract zombies. "My god, look around you, whatever came through here massacred these people!" Frank stood trembling as Rob gave him a mildly surprised look. "Yeah, I expect you to sleep here." He said without missing a beat. "We can't keep moving if something's out there hunting. Its night, thing's are dark, and we'd be easy prey. I've seen several types of zombies, big fat ones, burning ones, hell, even ones that can shoot slime. I wouldn't be at all surprised if there was a fucking Wendigo out there killing people right now. I know this isn't the safest of places, but use your head. If whatever came through just brutalized these people I doubt it would bother coming back before morning. Besides, would you really rather be walking down an abandoned road at night with only me and that gun you don't want to use as protection, or sleeping in a semi-comfortable public bathroom with a few dead bodies?"


Frank's stomach turned as he considered the two options, he almost wanted to take his chances outside with whatever boogieman did this. Almost. The color left Frank's face when he realized staying here was the better option. "Ugh, fine... We'll stay here until morning, but then we get the hell out of here. Deal?" Rob grinned. "Glad you see it my way. Come on, we're sleeping in the ladies room." He said as he stepped back outside and went into the only other room. Frank followed and was somewhat relieved to see that the ladies room only had two bodies over in a corner, thankfully with a thick blanket covering them. "Heh, guess the girl's restrooms really are nicer..." Frank said with a weak laugh, trying his best to calm himself. "Yeah, that's funny, now give me a hand with this!" Rob called as he yanked a loose door from a stall and carried it over to the only entrance. "Eat shit and die." Frank said in a deadpan monotone. "What did you say?!" Rob called angrily as he placed the door against the wall. "I was reading this message on the wall..." Frank said as he pointed to the bloody words written just above the sinks in all capital letters.


"Never mind the damn graffiti, just help me secure this place... or do you want to sleep outside?" Rob called in an annoyed tone. Frank sighed and helped him with the second door and the third. "You really thank this'll keep us safe?" Frank asked half-expecting an answer he would regret hearing. Sure enough, that's exactly what Rob gave him. "Fuck no, this won't keep us safe. The only reason I put it up was to alert me to the fact that something's gotten inside and is munching on your guts. That way I can escape and leave you to die." Frank's face lost its color again and he sat down on the cold hard floor with sweat pouring down his face. "I think I'd like to go to sleep now..." Rob grinned as he sat down his backpack and pulled out a couple of thin sheets and pillows. "Here you go little Frank, would you like a bed time story?" He taunted as he tossed Frank his sheet and pillow. "NO!" Frank shouted, more annoyed then angry. "And why didn't you tell me you had pillows and sheets stuffed in there?" "You didn't ask." Rob mumbled as he pulled his sheet up and turned on his side. "Now get some sleep, we'll only be here for about 5 or so hours."


Frank spread his sheet over the ground and laid his head on his pillow. He was cold, but there was no way in hell he was going to lay on the bare floor. The wind howled a bit outside and he soon found himself dozing off. That morning Frank dreamed nightmare after nightmare about the events of the last few days. A thousand twisted faces appeared out of the darkness and taunted him as he screamed. "You killed us, why? WHHHHYYYY?! What did we do to you?" They laughed as they watched his torment. Finally, after four hours of restless hell, he woke up to a new nightmare. A double-barrel shotgun was planted firmly against his cheek and Rob had a cleaver just inches from his throat. In the dim light of the new morning sun Frank could see that their attacker's were not monsters, but humans. The one who had captured Rob was wearing an orange hunting cap and a flannel shirt under his orange jacket. The one who had Frank had a thick mustache and a camo colored jacket and pants. Strapped to his belt was a high caliber revolver along with some small pouches. "G'mornin." The one with the shotgun taunted as he removed his sunglasses and revealed a nasty scar running across his left eye and down his cheek.
12331111112.title: One hell of a night

choices: Try to escape, this might be the only chance they get!
Stay put, its still too risky to try anything!
123311111122.content:
Frank considered asking questions for a few seconds before deciding it would be best to just let things play out for the time being. He was so shocked that he doubted he could even speak without accidentally provoking them in some way. "Yeah, nice to meet you too." Rob suddenly blurted out. "Good fuckin' morning." Frank's jaw dropped open as the hick with the shotgun walked over to him while his buddy held him in place with the cleaver. "What? You g-" Rob began to speak, but was quickly silenced with the butt of the shotgun painfully smacking him in the side of the mouth. Two teeth flew across the room and landed on the floor as a thick stream of blood began pouring from his torn open lip. "Augg..." Rob gasped as he raised a hand to wipe off his mouth, only to have it grabbed and pulled behind him. "Rob!" Frank called out as he moved closer. "Hol' it." The man in the orange hat and vest called as his friend aimed his shotgun at Frank. "You shoulda kept quiet like yer buddy there." The man with the shotgun taunted as they tied Rob's hands behind his back with rope. After both his hands and feet were bound one of the two rednecks carried him outside while the other tied up Frank.


"Okay boys, we got em!" The man called as he hauled Frank outside where the others were waiting. Down near the road were three pickup trucks, one of which was piled full of supplies. The other two seemed to be moderately armored, but Frank hardly took notice as he was far more concerned about the fifteen or so armed men loading Rob into the back of the one on the far end. "W-where are you gonna take us?" Frank asked meekly as one of them walked over to help the one carrying Frank. "Shuddup, boy!" The new hillbilly growled as he grabbed Frank by the feet. Once both of the survivors were secure in the back next to each other a few of the men began loading their supplies into the back of the truck in front of them. "Shit!" Frank thought to himself as he looked around the bed of the truck. Not only was there nothing that could cut the ropes, but there were also no less then 3 guards keeping a close watch on him and Rob. Seeing as there was nothing he could do at the moment, Frank simply sat back and listened as the truck up in front of him started its engine. "Alright boys, les git these two back to th' farm!" One of the hicks up front called. Soon, the trucks were all moving in the same direction Frank and Rob had been walking the previous night, only to make a sharp left turn as soon as houses starting coming into view up ahead. The last thing Frank saw as they began driving deep into the woods was a quick glimpse of the shiny, silver diner off in the distance behind the trees.


The gravel road leading to the farm made for quite a bumpy and noisy ride, but Frank dared not to complain. Occasionally, the men would fire off a shot or two at the odd zombie that they drove past, often scoring a killing blow on the first try. "Damn Lester, you see tha son' bitch?!" One called as the guy next to him fired three shots at a large bear off in the distance. "Um yeah, good shot..." Frank said weakly in an attempt to make conversation. "Yew best jus stay quiet, boy..." One of them sneered in reply. The rest of the trip was silent expect for the crunching of gravel beneath the wheels of their trucks. Finally, after 20 minutes they pulled into the driveway of one of their homes right next to a large wooden barn. Most of them began heading towards the nearby house while the rest unloaded supplies and such. As luck would have it, none of them remembered to keep an eye on their prisoners, leaving Frank and Rob a possible chance to escape...

What should they do?
123311111122.title: Rural hospitality

choices: One little sip can't hurt...
Frank refuses to drink any...
1233111111222.content:
Frank scooted over to the edge of the truck and peered over the side. From the looks of it the driveway steadily moved down a steep hill surrounded by trees. Off to the right he could see a small house far below them through the trees. "Damn, if we try to run while we're tied up we could end up tripping and falling off the edge." He whispered as he leaned out a little farther. No way he'd survive a fall from this hight... and the woods surrounding them were probably filled with zombie animals... "No... no. Its just too risky, one slip and we'd both be dead..." Frank muttered as he sat back down in the bed of the truck, careful not to make any noise. "Well Rob, looks like our best bet is to just wait this out. If we tried getting down the hill before they saw us we would most likely trip and either end up shot or dead at the bottom of this hill." Rob only made a grunting noise as he stared at the nearby house. He had been really quiet ever since the incident at the reststop and seemed to be in a daze, but now he was really focused on the farmhouse for some reason. It was indeed a nice two-story house, but Frank hadn't noticed anything going on near it. Of course, he had spent the last few moments trying to think of a way to escape. Maybe Rob had noticed something important...


For the next few hours the two sat in the back of the truck waiting to see what these men wanted with them. The sun was now almost overhead and slowly warming the earth with its light. Finally, around noon three of the men walked out to the truck, two with weapons, and one carrying some supplies. "Git out." One of the men said in a cold tone as he lit up a cigarette. Frank and Rod did as they were told and stood before the men waiting further instructions. "Well now, you two seem to be behaving real good now." A man in a NASCAR t-shirt said with a grin. "But don't be thinking you'll be getting off for good behavior." Both of the other two men rolled their eyes and told him to shut up as began leading their two captives to the barn. A forth man was there waiting and opened the door as they walked up. "You sure they'll be secure until tonight?" He asked as the man with the cigarette nodded his head. "Don't worry, if they try to escape, we'll feed em to ol' Bessy." He replied as he shut the door back. "Just remember that they'll be here at 8." One of the other men called from inside the barn. Immediately, Frank noticed two things. One, the barn was smelly and dark. Two, there was something breathing in the pin up ahead. Something big, with glowing red eyes...


"W-what is that thing?" Frank stuttered as he and Rob were shoved to the ground. "None of your fuckin' business!" The man in the NASCAR shirt hissed as walked out of sight for a moment. He returned less then a minute later with two large cinderblocks in his hands. "You wanna help me Jonas? This shit weighs a ton!" The other man let out a groan, but obliged. Soon Frank and Rob found themselves in a kneeling position while the rednecks wrapped chains around them. Each chain severely restricted their movement and was attached to a cinderblock, making it impossible for them to get free without outside help. "Here ya go boys." The man with the cigarette called as he flicked it to the ground and opened up a jug. "Y'all have been so good we decided to reward ya. Have a sip." The liquid in the container smelled of alcohol and something sweet. "T-thats okay." Frank stuttered as the man lowered the jug closer to his mouth. "Drink it." He said in a much less friendly tone.

Things seem to be going from bad to worse. What should Frank do now?
1233111111222.title: Down on the farm

choices: "I'll grab us some food at the diner."
"I'll clear the motel for us."
1233111112.content:
Frank kept his Ak-47 pointed straight ahead of him as he walked, ready to fire it at anything that decided to jump out at him. Rob however, was more laid back in his approach and didn't even bother raising his shotgun unless he saw a zombie. By the time they walked the half mile to the reststop they had encountered three zombies, all level one. Rob had made short work of them with his shotgun, but encouraged Frank to deal with the next one they saw. "You need to get in some practice with that thing, so the next time we see one of the undead I'm letting you kill it." He had said when he realized that Frank hadn't so much as pulled the trigger once on his gun. Frank was perfectly willing to let Rob do all the dirty work as he seemed to enjoy it and Frank didn't like shooting things, living or dead. Yet, as much as he didn't want to, he knew Rob would expect him to help out sooner or later and he'd have to start shooting or give up his only source of protection and possibly his only ally. He let out a sigh as he looked over the reststop. It wasn't much, but it would be nice to take a break and sit down. "Hey Rob, should we check out that reststop?" Frank called out as he gave it another hopeful look. "Sorry, but we gotta get to a place with some shelter, and that place isn't exactly a fortress. Besides, its small potatoes compared to what we'll likely find at the motel and diner." Frank thought of protesting, but knew it would be fruitless so he decided to forget he ever saw the reststop and focused on the trip ahead.


Frank fired his gun for the fist time ever when a large buck with a broken antler jumped out from the side of the road and rushed the two. Rob, who was about 15 yards ahead, managed to jump out of the way just in time. Frank, who had no time to move, simply opened fire and emptied the entire clip into the undead deer. It slumped over and fell to the ground as the bullets tore through its flesh. When the gun finally ran out of ammo, the Beast's corpse was riddled with holes and leaking blood. Rob got up off the ground and walked over to congratulate his companion on his first kill. "Nice job, noob." He said as he brought the butt of his shotgun down on the zombies mangled head, just to make sure it wasn't getting back up. "Next time, you might want to stop firing when your opponent falls over dead, you know? Saves more ammo that way." Frank slowly got to his feet and surveyed his fallen foe. "Did... did I really do that?" He choked out as sweat poured down his face. "Yeah, it was close, but you're still alive so I guess we get to hang out a little longer. Here." Rob tossed him a spare clip that he had taken out of Frank's backpack. "You know how to reload, don't you?" He taunted as he resumed walking down the road. "Oh, yeah..." Frank mumbled as he stepped away from the corpse and joined back up with his friend.


A half hour passed and a few abandoned houses came in to view behind the trees and bushes. Rob cautioned Frank to keep his eyes out for any sudden movement.
