13223.content:
Betty ducked back inside just as the first of the undead rounded the corner, with luck it didn't see her. Rather then stay in the front of the dinner with all the windows she headed for the kitchen.

The door to the kitchen swung shut behind her and she looked around the dimly lit kitchen, only one of the lights were on. Betty started to looked around the kitchen just to make sure here were no surprises in the kitchen, there wasn't, what there was was a good set of butcher knives, she took one as it would be better then going unarmed.

At that moment she heard the windows in the front of the diner shatter and the snarls of the zombies. Betty ran to the serving window and looked out, there were about 20 of them coming in though the windows and what looked like more behind them, they didn't seem to know she was -CLANG- Betty spun around, she had backed into one of the frying pans and it had fallen to the floor, she spun back to the window and all eyes were on the kitchen, as one the undead surged forward towards the door of the kitchen.

Betty would have one chance, the back door, she didn't know if it was locked but there was no way she could fight that many with a butcher knife. She ran for the door just as the door to the rest of the dinner opened to alow the first of the undead into the kitchen.

She ran and and made it to the hall she could see the door.

She sprinted and threw her full weight against it and
13223.title: The rules of engagement.

choices: She runs inside the open door into the darkened room
She tries to go up the fire escape
132231.content:
For a brief moment Betty felt the ground disappear from beneath her as she soared through the air before landing in the alleyway behind the diner. Fortunately, she had managed to not land on top of her butcher knife, although she was now bleeding from a skinned knee. "Oww! Dammit!" Betty groaned as she quickly got up and rubbed her knee while examining her injury. It wasn't bad, but it sure hurt like hell. A boney hand reached out for her just as she began running down the alley as quickly as she could. Thunder roared overhead as a flash of lightning illuminated the way ahead. Betty turned a corner while trying desperately to avoid stepping in the large puddles or slipping on the wet pavement. It didn't take much for her to keep ahead of the zombies as they were all level one, but she knew that one slip up would give them time to close in on her, especially if she hurt herself again. She was making her way past an overturned dumpster when she ran into her first mayor threat that night, a zombiefied dog. It was a doberman that was missing half of its front leg, which ended in a bloody stump. It had jumped out from behind the dumpster just as Betty tried to make her way past it and knocked the butcher knife from her hands.


It attempted to maul her, but with quick reflexes she had managed to grab ahold of the Beast's head and hold it away from her. "Oh my god! Oh my god!" She screamed as it tried wrenching its mangled head free. The footsteps of the zombies behind her grew closer and would soon be upon her so Betty braced herself for what she had to do and grabbed the dog's remaining front paw with one of her hands. It was hard to keep it away with only one hand, but Betty was soon able to force it off of her and slam it headfirst into the ground. It began whimpering as its eye tracked her as best it could while hanging out of the socket of its ruined head. Betty had earned herself a few more scrapes in the battle, but was far from dead. She picked up her butcher knife and lopped off what remained of the dog's head in one clean swipe before moving on. Finally, she came to a dead end on the other side of a large apartment building. "Shit, how could I make such a bone-headed mistake?!" She growled at herself as she turned to face the approaching hordes. She had only one escape route, an open doorway that led into a darkened room. Just as she was about to run inside, however, she noticed a fire escape above her to her left...
132231.title: Alleyway escape!

1322311.content: Betty quickly rushed inside the darkened building and slammed the door shut behind her. As soon as it was closed she began running towards a boarded-up window off in the distance where she could faintly see the shadows of the rain outside. "Hopefully the front door isn't locked..." Betty said to herself as she narrowly avoided tripping over an overturned desk. Just as she reached out to grab the handle the door behind her burst open with savage force as the undead began to pour into the room. Betty let out a loud yell as she turned the handle... only for it to stop moving just short of opening. Something on the other side was blocking the door and keeping it from moving. "No! No! God damn it!" Betty screamed in a panic as she turned around to meet the terrifying swarm of red eyes glaring at her amidst the sea of black. Betty tried running off to the side in an effort to get around them, only to trip over a chair and stumble to the ground as her butcher knife dug deep into her left arm. "No..." She moaned softly as the hordes surrounded her. She managed to pull the butcher knife from her arm and kill a few of them, but it wasn't long before her injuries were too great and she succumbed to the pain coursing through her body. By the next morning the only evidence of her desperate struggle was four fresh corpses... and a new addition to the growing army of the dead...
1322311.title: Into the dark

choices: She wakes up early due to bad dreams
She sleeps in and gets up at noon the next day
1322312.content:
Betty took one last look at the doorway in front of her and sighed to herself. "God, I must be crazy..." She turned to the fire escape and jumped up to grab ahold of it. After a moment of steading herself she tried to pulled herself up just as a cold moist hand grabbed ahold of her leg. "No, dammit! Let go!" She screamed as she kicked it away and pulled herself the rest of the way up as the undead crowded below her. Without looking back Betty began ascending the fire escape as the zombies tried to climb up after her, knocking each other aside with their hands reaching up vainly for the cold, wet metal. By the time Betty reached the forth floor she came to a blockage that prevented her from going up any further and the zombies below her finally began spilling onto the platform under her while trampling their brethren underfoot. Thinking quickly Betty went back down to the floor below her and climbed into an open window before the zombies could get to her. She jumped down from the inside counter and sat her butcher knife down on the nearby table as she blocked off the window. Once a fairly secure barrier was in place she picked her only weapon back up off the table and made a run for higher ground.


The halls were dark and only a few lights were on, but Betty had just enough light to navigate by as she made her way to the top of the building. The final staircase leading to the top floor was closed off by several large pieces of furniture, however, there was a small hole in the ceiling of one of the bedrooms of that floor. Betty took a few minutes to catch her breath before sitting a nearby coffee table on the bed. After she was sure she could make it she carefully tossed her butcher knife through the hole and made a jump for it. The table bounced off the bed and crashed to the floor below her as Betty pulled herself up onto the slowly collapsing floor. A few large chunks of splintered wood fell onto the bed below and Betty quickly backed away as the wood creaked and groaned. She was sweating all over and exhausted, but was now relatively safe. Even a level two zombie wouldn't be able to climb through that hole without a lot of help. "Now maybe I'll at least be able to get a decent night's sleep before I head out tomorrow." Betty said between huffs. "Now where did my knife land?" She began looking around as she got up, only to notice she had a new problem to deal with. She could feel something warm running down her inner thigh and quickly began unfastening her jeans to investigate.


At first she thought she may have actually wet her pants, only to scream as she caught sight of the small blood trail that stained her panties and ran down her leg. "Oh no, was I cut and didn't notice it in the excitement?!" She stuttered as she tried desperately to find an injury. Then it hit her. The blood wasn't from a cut or scrape. It was menstrual blood. She was now on her period. "No, it can't be..." She groaned as put her jeans back on. "That isn't supposed to happen for another week..." She buried her face in her hands and began crying as she collapsed into a nearby chair. "Can anything else possibly go wrong...?" She moaned as she listened to the downpour outside. The past few days had seemed to only get worse and worse and now she had to deal with this as well. Betty was unsure just how long she sat in that chair before finally getting up, but it felt like hours. She wiped away her tears and tried to find a bathroom. Luckily, there was one in the room next to her with decently stocked medicine cabinets. Betty smiled faintly as she pulled out a box of tampons that was sitting on a shelf next to a pink razor. "Finally, its about time something went right... I just hope these are the right size..." She said as she also grabbed a box of band aids for her knee. Once she had taken care of everything she found a bedroom and took a well-deserved rest.
1322312.title: What else can go wrong...?

choices: Head down the fire escape
Search for a possible alternate escape route
13223121.content:
Betty managed to get a few hours of sleep, but she soon found herself laying awake in the darkness with sweat pouring down her forehead. A nightmare she could vaguely recall now had stirred her from her sleep. All that she could remember was a man in a suit smiling wickedly as a fiery red sky burned behind him. "Jesus, what time is it...?" She groaned as she got out of bed and headed back into the bathroom to see if she could take a shower. Fortunately, the water was still running and even decently warm, allowing her a brief escape from the madness around her. When she was done with that she wrapped a towel around herself and headed back into the bedroom to check for fresh clothes as the ones she had worn yesterday were still wet from the rain. Among the various clothes in the closet were a small purse and a shoebox filled with home and gardening magazines. Betty changed into a fresh pair of barely fitting panties and a large t-shirt with a bird on it. None of the jeans she found had fit well as they all seemed to belong to an older male who must have had a few weight problems. Thankfully, the man also had quite a collection of belts which made the jeans a much better fit. Once she was dressed Betty went through the purse she had found looking for anything useful. Inside had been a comb, brush, half a pack of cigarettes, a packet of tissues, a bottle of hairspray, and some makeup. Betty laid everything out on the bed and sat there for a few minutes deciding what to keep.


She put the tissues and hairspray back inside the purse while leaving everything else on the bed. She then made a quick trip back to the bathroom to fill up the rest of the purse with other useful supplies. Once she was sure she had everything she needed she slipped the purse over her shoulder and stepped back out into the hall to grab her butcher knife. After about ten minutes of searching she noticed something shining in the morning light that peeked through the boarded up window at the end of the hall. She bent down and reached underneath a fallen painting that was propped up against the wall. The feel of a cold metallic blade meant that she had found what she was looking for. With her weapon reclaimed and a bright new morning to great her Betty readied herself to move out. She stepped outside onto the fire escape and looked at the alleyway below her. There were still a few zombies down there, but most of them had given up on her and moved on. Betty was sure she could handle the ones that remained... if they were indeed the only ones down there. It was entirely possible that some had simply moved inside the building, which she would surely encounter on her way down. From the looks of things Betty had two options. She could travel down the fire escape to the blockade on floor 4 and then navigate the rest of the way down through the building itself. Or she could just stay here and look for another escape route, it wasn't like the zombies were getting up here anytime soon...
13223121.title: Not a morning person...

choices: She tries to prove that the zombies are the result of the supernatural
She points out that if this was indeed a virus it would've gotten him by now
132231212.content:
There was no way that Betty would be heading back down there any time soon with only her butcher knife, especially if some might be waiting for her inside the building itself. "Guess I'll have to find another way down..." Betty said as she stepped back inside. After all, she hadn't taken the time to explore the entire floor last night and there were still a few rooms that might be worth checking out. Betty walked down the hallway and began checking the rooms one by one. Most were free of corpses and blood, but also supplies. It was as if everyone that had lived here left in a hurry, packing up anything even remotely useful to take with them. When Betty finally came to the last room she crossed her fingers and turned the knob. When the door swung open she let out a gasp of surprise and grabbed ahold of the door frame for support. On the wall was a large triangle spray-painted inside a square with an arrow next to it pointing towards the roof. More importantly then that, there was a massive hole in the ceiling with a ladder leading up onto the roof. Betty quickly closed the door behind her and walked slowly across the waterlogged carpet to investigate.


She put one hand on the gleaming metal and made sure it was steady before heading on up. It was slippery, but at least she didn't fall. Up on top of the roof were a couple of sleeping bags and an empty cooler along with one of the most bizarre things Betty had ever seen. On the edge of the building was a makeshift bridge that connected this building with the next. It didn't look very sturdy or even safe (most of it appeared to be made from filling cabinets and duct tape) but it was also the only way down aside from the fire escape. "What... were they thinking...?" Betty groaned as she tested the odd structure with her foot. It creaked a bit, but held in place. With a deep breath Betty broke into a quick run across it and jumped down onto the second building just as a large piece of the bridge came loose and fell to the ground. "Jeez, rickety piece of crap..." She said as she walked over to a door located on the far side of the building. To her surprise it was locked, as she found out when she attempted to turn the knob. "Oh no, shit... shit, open up!" She called as she banged on the door with her fist. Amazingly a voice called back.

"W-who's out there?" A young male voice asked in a worried tone.


"Oh, thank god! Another human!" Betty called out cheerfully as she heard the man climb up the inside stairs towards the door. "A-are you... infected? Did they... bite you?" He called out as he leaned against the inside of the door. "Infected?" Betty asked in puzzled tone of voice. "Mister... I don't think an infection did all of this... there are zombies out here who have strange powers and abilities. Its... I can't believe I'm saying this... its almost supernatural... like they're demonic in nature or something..." Upon hearing this the man banged his fist into the door, startling Betty. "Who the hell are you trying to fool?! You think I'd buy that?! You're infected, ain't you?" He growled in a paranoid tone of voice. "No!" Betty protested desperately. "I've been bitten by those things, yeah, and I've even been punched and scratched by them. Its been almost an entire week since I first encountered them and I don't have any sort of symptoms. Whatever this is, it can't be passed on simply through contact. The only people I've seen turn were the ones who were actually killed..." In a rage the man on the other side of the door began banging it even louder. "Liar! LIAR! I've seen every zombie movie ever made and I know you're lying! You must be a carrier! That's why you've been okay so long!" Things seem to be getting worse by the minute... how will Betty get out of this?
132231212.title: Infected?

choices: The door's open, might as well go inside
Zombies show up while Betty is distracted
1322312122.content:
Betty figured that using normal reasoning wouldn't work with this man so she decided to appeal to his paranoia. "Look if this all really was the cause of some kind of virus don't you think it would have gone airborne by now?" She called out over the sound of him banging the door. "Unless that room you're in is air-sealed it would only be a matter of time before you became infected as well..." At this point the man stopped banging on the door and fell silent as he listened. "But since you're still okay I'm guessing that there's nothing to worry about... now, will you please open the goddamned door before the zombies hear us?" The man didn't respond and began breathing more heavily. "Mister, are you okay...?" Betty asked as she leaned on the door and tried to hear what was going on inside. "You're... right..." The man said abruptly as he began walking back down the stairs. "You're right... the infection must be air-borne by now... I have to kill you before you infect me..." Betty immediately moved away from the door and took a step back. "What...?!" She yelled as she heard the man begin digging through his supplies. "You want to kill me?! What the hell is wrong with you... can't you see that this isn't an infection?!" The man didn't bother responding and soon began making his way back up the stairs. "No..." Betty thought to herself as she backed further way from the door. "I can't make it back to the other building... if he has a gun I'm as good as dead...!" The man paused for a moment as he opened each of the locks. Then the door swung open and Betty finally got a look at him....


He looked to be in his early twenties and had a short beard along with a mustache. He was wearing a bloodied shirt and pants. On his exposed forearms were many scratches and bruises along with a few on his face. In his hands were a bloody fire axe that had a bit of dried gore on the blade. "Im sorry..." He said in a soft voice. "But I can't let you infect me like my wife and daughter tried to..." He began moving closer as he spoke, his expression never changing as he closed in on the helpless girl in front of him. "I don't like this... but it must be done to insure my survival... I had to leave friends and family behind to die when this whole thing happened... What's the death of one more stranger if I get to live?" Betty would have screamed, but her throat seemed to have gone dry as she slowly backed towards the edge of the building. "Oh god... oh god... think, think of something!" She yelled out in her head. She remembered the butcher knife in her left hand just as her foot connected with the side of the building. Murder and violence had always been the last things on Betty's mind, however in this situation it seemed she would have no choice. "Don't... please... don't hurt me..." She whispered through tears as the crazed man raised his axe to swing, "I... I regret it..." The man choked out as he steadied the axe. Betty tightened her grip on her own weapon and prayed silently for him to come to his senses.


A gleam of sunlight reflected off the blade as it was swung into its victim, sending blood flying through the air. "Wha? No.." A voice mumbled as one of the weapons fell to the ground. A look of utter horror spread across Betty's face when she realized what had happened. A deep gash glittered in the midmorning light as fresh blood poured from the wound. The man stumbled forward moaning as the pain from his chest reached his brain. He reached out to Betty as if he wanted to ask for help, only to trip over his fallen axe. Before Betty could even register what had happened a terrified scream filled the air as the man tumbled off the side to his death. Betty loosened her grip on the now blood-coated butcher knife and slumped to the ground as she slowly realized what had happened. She had killed him... not directly, but that injury she had inflicted on him would have been fatal even if he hadn't fallen. She had willingly assaulted another person, in self defense yes, but she had stuck to kill...

Betty didn't know what horrified her more, the fact that she had to take a life to survive... or the fact that she was okay with it...
1322312122.title: What must be done

choices: Ignore the rooms and get the fuck out of there!
Search the other rooms before moving on
13223121221.content:
Betty took a tissue out of her purse and wiped her face off while trying to get back on her feet. She managed to stand back up, although she was shaking so badly she had trouble walking. With her bloodied weapon in hand she slowly made her way over to the open door and grabbed ahold of it to support herself. A horrible smell crossed her nose as she set foot on the first step causing her to throw up on the nearby wall. "Oh, oh god... what is that?" She groaned as she wiped her mouth off with a tissue and closed the door behind her. As she made her way down the stairs the smell grew slightly stronger, which forced Betty to cover her mouth and nose with her free hand. At the bottom of the stairs was another doorway with blood smeared on the nearby wall leading inside. Betty raised her butcher knife and peeked around the corner into the dimly lit room. What she saw made her throw up again.


Laying on a table next to a curtain was the mangled body of a highly decomposed corpse. She looked to have been about 30 years old and was stripped to her underwear. The entirety of her exposed flesh was covered in scrapes, cuts, and lacerations. Her face had a twisted mix of fear and panic painted upon it as she died, which made it seem like she was staring directly at Betty in some kind of dazed stupor. Her stomach had been carved open and was held open by several odd tools. A bloodied syringe and other various surgical instruments were sitting on a tray next to her. She even had an I.V. stuck in her arm, not that it seemed to have done any good. Perhaps the most disturbing thing was her hands... which were covered in blood with bits of flesh underneath the fingernails...


Betty turned away and pulled the curtain next to the body the rest of the way closed as she walked towards the door, trying her best to ignore the charts and graphs hanging on the wall covered in various insane graffiti. Whatever horrors laid beyond it she would rather not see. The front door was locked, but since it was from the inside Betty had no trouble opening it. "My god... that was horrible..." She choked out as she closed the door and stumbled out into an abandoned hallway. There were several more rooms lining both sides of the long hallway, ending in a set of stairs that led down at the very end. Checking the rooms before leaving was probably a good idea... but Betty was afraid she would come across another horror show like the room she just left... What should she do?
13223121221.title: Depths of depravity

choices: She heads back into the alley she escaped from the night before
She tries going out the bathroom window
132231212211.content:
Betty was tempted to check the surrounding rooms for supplies, but the crippling fear of what she might find kept her moving towards the stairs. There was no way she would be prepared to deal with another encounter like the room she had just left. "I have to... keep going... I have to get... out of the city..." Betty said to herself as she looked down to make sure it was safe. Once she had recovered her nerve Betty took the first steps leading to her freedom outside. After getting back on the streets she would have a lot more maneuverability. Things went smoothly at first... then she came across a corpse slumped against the wall right above the stairway that led to the first floor. Betty almost screamed when her eyes fell upon him, but somehow she managed to keep her voice down even as she walked closer. The man wore ragged clothing that was torn in places and was otherwise unkempt, yet he was very handsome. A single bullet hole underneath his short blonde hair had been the cause of his death. In his hand was a 9mm handgun and in his coat pocket was a piece of paper, a suicide note. Betty took it out and began reading it slowly, unable to keep from tearing up as she went along:


To my dearest Brittany, I'm sorry. They've cornered me and trapped me inside this building. I tried to get to higher ground, but some insane fuck won't let me inside. Said something about zombie movies and an infection, crazy bastard. I heard screaming come from his room today, a little girl. I demanded he let me in, that I'd break down the damn door if I had to, but he just taunted me. The door must have been reinforced somehow, he must have moved something in front of it... or even sealed it off. I'm sorry my love, but I haven't had any food or water in almost three days... and I just can't take the sounds of that man or those fucking things outside anymore. If you find this, for god's sake, don't go upstairs, get out as fast as you can! Goodbye baby, take care of the kids and tell them I love them.

- Richard


Betty crumpled up the note and put it in her pocket. "Goddamn it... why'd this have to happen... this fucking zombie apocalypse..." She picked up his gun and checked to see if it had any rounds left. Five bullets. Five shots. She put her new weapon into her purse and continued to the ground floor. The entire downstairs lobby was a complete mess and more then a little creepy with thin beams of sunlight slithering in through the boarded up windows. "At least there isn't any..." Betty said as she looked around, unable to finish the sentence. She walked over to the front door, which was barricaded by several large objects, including a massive sofa. "Damn... there is no way I'll be able to move all this..." Betty groaned as she turned her attention to the front desk. "May as well look for stuff I can use... then hopefully I'll be able to find a way out of here..." It was a little difficult to search at first thanks to the darkness... fortunately, there was a working heavy duty flashlight hidden behind an abandoned stack of magazines. The soft glow illuminated the room perfectly and made looting the place much easier.


Betty was satisfied when she had recovered a pack of batteries for the flashlight along with a case of shotgun shells and 2 unopened bottles of flavored water. Betty took a long drink from the first bottle and shown the flashlight around the room, looking for alternate pathways. There were three doors in the room apart from the main entrance. One had merely led to an empty janitors closet, however, the other two were much more useful. One went down a hallway to a backdoor that led to the alleyway Betty had escaped from the night before. The other led to a bathroom... which had an opened and unbarred window that looked like it would lead to the streets outside. The sounds of movement could still be heard, although there was no sure way to tell where it was coming from. As much as she hated it, Betty would have to gamble her safety on a guess if she wanted to leave here alive...
132231212211.title: A way to safety?

choices: Betty heats up some of the frozen patties for a quick meal
Betty visits the restroom to freshen up before making her lunch
1322312122112.content:
It had been less then a day since Betty had narrowly escaped death in the alleyway out back... and there was no way all the zombies had moved on yet. Betty walked into the small bathroom and took out her gun, ready to use it if need be. She quickly gathered up her courage and peeked out through the large frame into the street. The rain from the previous night had left puddles of muddy water everywhere, but there wasn't a single zombie in sight. "I'll just have to be careful to avoid the puddles and I'll be fine..." Betty said, trying desperately to reassure herself. With a deep breath she climbed up onto the toilet and sucked in her belly. It was a tight fit, but the window was just large enough to accommodate her as she dropped down onto the sidewalk outside. She hadn't made much noise in her exit and didn't drop her gun, although she did skin one of her elbows. "Ow! Ow! Ow! Dammit!" She stuttered as she got back on her feet and took cover behind a nearby truck. She listened for a few seconds and didn't make a sound. Once she was sure nothing had noticed her she got back up and began walking hurriedly down the street with her eyes peeled for the undead. After a few minutes she came to a familiar row of restaurants off to the side of the road. Needless to say, she was eager to get a bite to eat and rest a moment before making her next move.


A brief and fleeting memory of her mother and father taking her to the nearby McDonalds flashed through her mind. It had been her 5th birthday and she was finally old enough to explore the vast playplace by herself. Before long she had gotten lost and began crying... it had been once of the scariest moments of her childhood. The last thing she remembered as she opened the front door was her mothers calm voice telling her it would be okay as she embraced her in a warm hug. "Mommy... daddy..." Betty whispered as fresh tears began filling her eyes. It took all of her strength just to keep from breaking down as she approached the counter and caught the first glimpse of the playplace she had enjoyed so much as a child. As Betty climbed over the counter more memories came flooding back. The smiling cashier who had worked there. The children laughing as their parents watched them play. The reality of the establishment she now stood in was truly melancholy. Betty wiped the tears from her face as she began her search for something to eat, completely unaware of the glowing red eyes that had watched her every move since she had come in...
1322312122112.title: Then and now

choices: Betty looks around for any more notes that might be here
Betty ignores the warning and heads straight to the factories
Betty decides to heed the notes warning and leaves
1323.content:
A small metal key fell out of the envelope and into Betty's hand. "Huh?!" She shouted in disbelief. She had expected a paycheck, instead she got a key to the diner's wine cellar in the basement. "What the fuck is this?!" Betty groaned as she wadded up the envelope into a ball and threw it against the wall. She looked back down at the key in her hand and let out a sigh. "Maybe, they have something in the basement for me..." She walked out into the diners back hallway and stood silently before the door to the basement. She had always hated going down there... even it the daylight it was creepy as hell. She took a deep breath and turned the key. The lock clicked open and she turned the handle slowly as it creaked all the way open. She felt around for the light switch on the wall and flipped it when she found it. The dark stairway before her was then illuminated with a bright and eerie glow that came from the overhead light on the ceiling below her.


She walked down slowly and made sure to keep her eyes peeled for any sort of movement. When she reached the bottom without any problems she began to lose some of the fear that had been building up inside her as soon as she climbed down the first few steps. It was silent and peaceful down here... nothing to be afraid of, right? Then she turned around. A screamed escaped her lips as she fell to the cold, hard floor. Upon the wall opposite of her were no less then a dozen corpses propped up against the wall in a line. Some were fairly fresh, only a day or two old, but some were almost a week old and heavily decayed. A lone spider crawled out from beneath ones eye and skittered down the side of his pale cheek. None of them moved, indeed none of them were undead, but the sight was the most horrifying thing Betty had seen in her entire life. Tears began to form in her eyes as she crawled away slowly and backed up against the wall. Apparently, the survivors had stored their dead down here before moving on.


After a few minutes Betty was able to get back up on her feet and walked a bit closer to get a better look at the corpses. She recognized three of them as employees of the diner like herself, but the rest were people she had never seen before. Each one of them had a hole in their foreheads, wounds made by a small caliber gun. Betty breathed out a sign of relief when she realized that they wouldn't be getting back up. She wiped away the remaining tears in her eyes and walked over to a wine rack that caught her attention. There was a note attached to a bottle of Pinot Noir that was barely legible in the dim light. It informed anyone who might be reading it to stay away from the factories on Oak Street, but it didn't say why...
1323.title: What could be down here...?

choices: The gas station
The apartment building
The pizza place
13233.content:
Before leaving Betty picked up an empty duffel bag that had been laying next to one of the corpses and looked it over. It was empty and a had a few dried bloodstains on the side, but it didn't have any big holes and was clean on the inside, which would make it a great mobile storage container. The last thing she did before heading back up the stairs was grab a few bottles of expensive champagne and stuff them inside the duffel bag along with a few clean rags. Betty had never drunk before and wasn't about to start now, but she knew that some high quality booze would make a good trade or bribe if she ran into any other survivors.

Steeling her nerves for what was to come she grabbed a knife from the kitchen and headed back out into the streets. It was raining fairly heavily now and small trails of water poured along the streets towards the storm drains as various undead shambled about. Betty knew she wouldn't last very long if she tried to make her way home with the weather like this, one bad slip and she could be cornered. These ghoulish monsters weren't too fast or smart, but there were enough of them to catch a lone survivor easily enough even if they were very careful.

"I need to find a place to stay and rest for the night." Betty whispered to herself as she closed the door to the diner and ran across the street to a vacant lot sandwiched between two condemned buildings. A lone zombie stirred near the brick wall of one of the buildings next to a pile of trash and let out a soft growl. He was immobile thanks to a survivor kneecapping him with a rifle some days beforehand, though he still managed to give poor Betty a fright as he flailed around on his hobbled legs. With a small grunt she kicked his head back against the wall, painting a oozing red stain where his head had connected.

The zombie groaned as it stirred about on the ground, its glowing red eyes fixed on her as she ran out of the lot onto the next street without looking back. "A place to rest for the night... somewhere safe..." she chanted as she took cover behind a car as a large dog ran down the street after a cat. She couldn't tell if the dog was undead or not, but wasn't in a hurry to find out either. As the cat made its escape through an open window Betty ran out of cover and continued onward.

Most of the buildings she ran past had been boarded up or stained with blood, not exactly ideal hiding spots. Finally, she came to a large intersection with few zombies traveling through it and decided she would find a secure place here to spend the night. Across the street was a gas station, abandoned though it still had electricity. It would be a good spot to rest if Betty could find a way to block the main door. Alternatively, on the opposite streets were a small apartment building and a local pizza place. They would both make good hiding spots as well if she could barricade them.

Which one should Betty choose?

The undead had chased her here the day before and she narrowly managed to escape them. She had also managed to shove the teachers and students desks over the door. Somehow she had managed to hold on to her spatula from work and bring it with her. She woundered if it would even be any help. In anger and dispair Betty threw the spatula agenst the wall. Suddenly the noise outside grew, and the zombies started to draw closer to the room she was in. She held her breath and didn't move, hopefully they wouldn't find her. She heard the sound of wings moving outside and drawing closer towards her. They must know where she is! She got up from the floor and made her way over towards the door slowly and quietly. Along the way she picked up her spatula, it won't be much help, but at least she'll have some type of wepion. She carefuly started moving aside the desks when she heard something loud behind her. She looked back at the window and couldn't help but scream. The Carrier was pressed up agenst the glass window, its red eyes glowing and its mouth wide open growling. Crawling along its body were several small Beasts, mostly chipmunks and rats, along with a few lizards and even a turtle. 1341.content: There were only 3 desks left before Betty could open the door and escape, but would she get out in time? The beasts were about to bite into her legs when she slamed the desk in her hands down onto them as hard as she could, causing them to make sickening noises as they were crushed like grapes. Betty was disgusted at the sight, but knew she had to hurry up if she wanted to get away. She picked up the 2nd desk and threw it at the Carrier that was now crawling at her at a fast pace. The desk only managed to graze its shoulder, but it was enough to slow it down and allow Betty to grab the final obstruction to her freedom. By now the remaining beasts were starting to move around the desk that had crushed their friends. Betty decided to ignore them for the moment and tossed the last desk at the Carrier. Her aim was much better this time and the Carrier took a sharp hit to the face. Betty knew that it wasn't enough to kill it, but had no time to finish it off. She opened the door and stumbled out into the hall just as a zombie rat made a swipe at her leg. She slamed the door behind her, cutting a few of the Beasts in half, and ran down the hall as fast as she could. 13411.content: Betty took the stairs down to the ground floor and entered the main hallway, which was eerily empty and quiet. Off to her right were the front doors, but they were probably locked. On the other end of the hallway was the round school assembly room and beyond that was the large cafeteria. After thinking for a minute Betty decided to ignore the exit for now. Even if it was unlocked, where would she go? The zombies had taken over everywhere else and she didn't even have a decent weapon. Walking outside right now would be suicide... and it wouldn't be painless. Betty walked down the hallway making sure to keep an eye out for any zombies that might be hiding. The lighting wasn't too bad, but there were several dark areas where a zombie could hide while waiting for something that was still living to pass by. Betty's stomach growled, the last thing Betty had eaten was a burger and fries... three days ago. She wanted nothing more then to raid the cafeteria for food, yet at the same time felt as if she should check the assembly room. If anyone else was alive, chances are they would have hidden in there. Where should she go?

134111.content: Betty didn't care if there was somebody else here with her... she needed to get something, anything to eat before she passed out. She hated the idea of being helpless and alone in this school, being hungry too was something she couldn't stand. She passed the assembly room without a second glance and took a good long look at the school lunchroom. It was vast and empty, but provided little cover if a zombie were to find its way inside. The tables were covered in blood and Betty saw what she thought was a severed arm sitting on a chair on the far side of the room. "Guess I better get moving..." She said meekly. "Its better I get some food sooner rather then later." Walking as quietly as she could Betty made her way past the gorey scene. She hadn't noticed before that some of the bloodstains looked like handprints and footprints, but up close their eerieness was unmistakable. Betty tried to ignore all the horrible thoughts that entered her mind with little success. By the time she had made it the kitchen doorway she was shaking. She walked inside without even bothering to check for zombies, thankful that she had at least made here without any trouble. Upon checking the back room she found a few boxes full of snack foods and a case of grape soda. Grape wasn't her favorite flavor, but right now it tasted better then anything she had ever drunk before. After a few minutes of eating snack cakes and chips she got back to her feet feeling much better then before. She was able to fit two bags of chips and some small snack cakes in her pockets along with one can of soda. She still had her spatula, which was soon joined with a small cutting knife that had been on the floor next to the boxes. Not much, but still better then before. Betty left the kitchen feeling a little more hopeful about her chances of survival and headed off to her next destination.
