13412.content: Betty hadn't been to the library yet, hopefully it would be free of zombies. She ran up to the door and looked through the window. The floor inside was a mess of books, magazines, papers, and a few computers that had been knocked to the ground. Most of the lights were broken or barely shining dim light on different parts of the room. The front desk was abandoned and the fire extinguisher was laying on a nearby table instead of being secured to the wall. On the plus side however, nothing inside moved or made any noise, there were no visible zombies. Betty opened the door slowly and walked inside, careful not to make any loud noise. The inside was pretty creepy if not outright scary. Before this horrible nightmare had begun this would've been one of the nicest places in the whole school. Now it was just another abandoned room in a school that seemed to be crawling with the undead. Betty walked over to the front desk and looked around for anything that might be useful. All that was on the top of the desk were some pencils, pens, papers, and a few folders. Nothing of value. Just as Betty went to check the drawers she heard a noise on the far side of the room. She couldn't beleave it...SOMETHING was in here with her! She was frozen in place behind the desk, unable to move. Suddenly whatever was there made another sound, this time behind a bookshelf. It's coming closer!
13412.title: Not alone...

choices: "Go past the gym."
"Go past the office."
134122.content:
With every bit of courage Betty could gather, she called out to the unknown figure. Trying to sound as threatening as possible, she weakly yelled out, "Whoever, or . . . Whatever you are, you better stay back. I have . . . Um . . . A spatula?" Yep. She was screwed.

For a second, it was just eerie silence. By now, if it was zombie, it would of clawed her face after making that pathetic threat. Soon enough, a pair of hands had gone up. One of which was holding a gun, which he or she had quickly dropped, in surrender.  

Maybe they really didn't like spatulas. 

She wasn't convinced that whatever "it" was, was human. Several students were turned into mimics and attempted to trick her. Yet again, these were the students who ran naked through the cafateria so they were easily out-smarted. She wouldn't think twice before going anymore near another human being after the apocalypse. It would be just like every other average day, but with zombies.

She felt more brave as she edged towards the pair of hands. If this was another airheaded mimic, then she could just easily throw a playboy magazine and make a run for it. "Come on. Get up and show me your face!"

The figure slowly stood up. It was blonde-haired man wearing a business shirt and a pair of pleats. On his back was an array of guns hanging from his belt and a baseball bat. Turning around, she saw a face that she had recognized. Instantly, Betty had dropped her spatula.  

"Uncle Frank!?" shock had come across the Frank Hugh's face. In the same second, it had turned into a widespreaded grin. That he was able to find his favorite niece through the hordes of zombies seemed impossible, but she was right there. "Betty?"

She instantly ran towards him and tackled him into a warm embrace. The sound of his heart beat was reassuring enough.

"Betty, you gotta be careful during times like these. I was this close smashing a baseball bat into your skull!" he said, still a bit shocked.

"I missed you too, uncle Frank." after refraining from the hug, she took a big long look at here uncle. It was strange to see her calm well-mannered accountant of an uncle suddenly go all Rambo. Rips and bloodstains were all over his shirt. He kept guns around his belt. There was a bullet hole through one of the lenses in his glasses. "Sorry for threatening to gut you with a spatula." 

"I don't mind. I just thought it was kinda sad that that was the best weapon you had." he grabbed the handgun from his belt and a survival knife. "There. You have now been un-pathetic-erized."

Having an actual weapon in her hands felt rather uncomfortable, but she could get used to it. "Thanks." she kept the survival knife in her pocket and held tightly to the handgun. "What are you doing here anyways?"

He grimaced. "As you can tell, we've got a huge infestation problem with zombies. I was worried about your safety and I expected that you were stuck here in the highschool of bat-shitery. And I was able to find you!" he took a look of his surroundings. "And . . . Now I don't know how to get out." 

Betty quickly answered out of nowhere. "Down the hall, to the right, and pass the gym there's an emergency exit." Frank thought about the option.

"I don't know. I passed by that gym area, and it was infested with vampires and level twos. Might be a bit too risky." Betty searched her brain for any more routes.

"Well there's another way past the office. But it's way harder to find. The only thing it has is a bunch of level ones hanging around." Frank thought about his two options.

"Well, I say we . . .
134122.title: A spatula. Seriously?

choices: They stay up on the bleachers and try to kill all the zombies before leaving
They run for the exit while shooting any zombies that get in their way
1341221.content: The duo exited the library and made their way down the hallway without incident. When they came to the door they checked the window to make sure it was clear. No zombies, not even any blood. Frank motioned for Betty to follow behind him as he opened the door quietly and walked inside. The hallway passed over the gym and cafeteria and led to a door that would take the both of them to the top of the bleachers inside the gym. Once they were there they could walk down to the door and take another hallway to the exit. It would be easy, hopefully. When they were about hallway through the hall Frank decided to look out one of the windows that overlooked the cafeteria and asked Betty to check a window overlooking the gym. After surveying the cafeteria below him for a few seconds Frank noticed some zombies near one of the folding tables, two level ones and some naked teenager with no head, clearly a Mimic. "Like that's going to fool anyone..." Frank said as he turned towards Betty. "How are things on your side?" She didn't answer. When he walked over and looked out the window himself he saw why. The entire gym looked like the killing floor of a meat processing plant. Bodies (and body parts) were laying all across the floor, some in piles and some by themselves. Blood red may as well have been the new school color as it was covering the floor and walls like a fresh coat of paint. This was all topped off with several level two's, a few level ones and worst of all, a nest of Vampires who were eagerly "cleaning up" the blood that had stained the massive room so throughly. "Jesus..." Betty whispered once she was able to speak again. Frank put a hand on her shoulder and turned her away. "We should get going..." He said as they moved forward. Soon they came to the door that led to bleachers inside the gym. "I don't think those zombies will just let us out of here, we'll need to fight at least a dozen or so of them." Frank said as he took out a another handgun. "You should keep that survival knife in your pocket unless you absolutely need it. Use this instead, it'll be better if you use long-range weapons." Betty took the second handgun and gave her uncle a confused look. "Wait, if I use both of your handguns what will you use?" Frank just smiled and held up his bat. "I have more then just two handguns, but I'd like to use this and it requires both my hands to use it to maximum effect." Still confused, Betty asked Frank another question. "But didn't you say long range would be better?" Betty said as she held up her two handguns. "Yeah, but one of us needs to do melee in case they get too close and you need to learn how to use a gun, plus I'm stronger then you so I'll be able to use this bat better." Frank replied. Betty did need to learn to use a gun, but the real reason Frank wanted to cover the melee angle was for Betty's safety. He would have to be a lot closer to the zombies and didn't want to put Betty in that kind of danger. "Alright, I'm ready uncle Frank!" Betty said as Frank put a hand on the door. "Good, just remember to only fire when you have a clear shot and be careful not to slip in the puddles of blood. Now lets Go!" Frank yelled as he slung the door open.
1341221.title: Several good reasons to hate gym class (even more)

choices: Bombard Uncle Frank with questions
13412212.content:
It didn't take Frank all that long to realize that perhaps just kicking into the gym, full force, wasn’t the greatest of ideas. Maybe he was deeply into the whole Rambo persona that he surprisingly enjoyed. Maybe he sought to impress his niece with his new found bravery. Either ways, he immediately regretted it.

One of the vampire's slightly pointed ears twitched, sensing a newer, fresher prey. It took a few good whiffs into the air, amazingly able to smell the dry stench of blood, not too far away. It's head jerked quickly to the side, tilting a bit upwards. In sight was a tallish blonde man, eyes wide open and mumbling what seemed like swearing. From behind him was another figure, standing safely behind the man, doing what seemed like smacking her forehead with her palm. Details didn't matter all that much. The need to satisfy its never-ending hunger did.

Frank watched as one vampires crouched down, letting out a short calling screech. The second it had rang out, every zombie surrounding the area looked directly towards him, baring their claws in anticipation. About every one of them, except the brain dead 1's, kept that horrifying grin on their faces as they got ready to pounce.

Now seemed like a very good time to move.

"Go, run!" he yelled out, breaking off from his initial shock. As soon as Frank took off, Betty followed after him with no time to loose. She managed to keep a weary eye on the crowd of ravaging zombies, coming towards them all too quickly.

For the short while, Frank was able to simply push out the wandering level ones, not coming across that much as a threat. Eventually, from the crowd of 1’s in front of him emerged one the vampires, clawing towards him. If there was one instinct that the zombie apocalypse has thought him that he loved most, was the need to smash just about anything that moved. Before the vampire could outreach its claws, Frank already had his bat swinging, aiming towards the vampire in a blur. All that came next was a deafening crack and the major splatter of blood and what seemed like brain matter. Originally, Frank would of cringed at this and immediately head for the showers. When both his and Betty’s life was in danger, it would have to wait. He simply ran onwards, rubbing away some of the few specklets that had landed on his glasses.

Meanwhile, Betty continued to follow her uncle, holding onto the handguns given to her in an intense grip as her heart pounded as quick as ever. She watched as he desperately battered down each and every zombie that had dared cross them. Even though Frank was able to rid of the oncoming zombies ahead of them, he wasn’t able to cover the ones coming at them from the side or behind. This worried her, noticing how they all seemed to be getting closer. One of the level 2’s were getting awfully close, treading just a few feet away.

Frank quickly glanced back, only managing to let a out few words. “Just shoot-” he was cut off as he smashed his bat into one the bigger vampires.

Betty raised one the guns towards the zombie, gripping as tight as possible. She tried to rid all of her fears of violence and harming another being. This “thing” was no longer human. It no longer had a pulse, or a soul. Repeating this thought in her mind, her finger had let down. She heard a loud boom travel to her ear, feeling as though she had just released lightning. After stumbling a bit, she found the one zombie blown completely off its feet, landing onto the ground, emotionless. She also noticed a few vampires that were falling back, changing course, and actually going for the blood of one of their fallen comrades. This had given her an idea.
“Uncle Frank, try aiming more towards the level 2’s!”

“Why?” he responded, beating down one slightly moving vampire laying on the ground.

“Just do it!” she yelled out, plowing another bullet into a level two, letting a few more vampires wander off.

Frank was surprised by his niece’s sudden harshness. Not wanting to argue, he kicked away the nearest vampire, landing a deadly blow to the head of a level two. At the smell of more strong blood, some of the nearby vampires began to ignore him, lunging towards the new dead body, fighting amongst themselves for a slab of flesh. Sickening, yet highly useful.

This worked rather well for the while they were running, noticing how more vampires ignored them to feed on the other dead zombies. By the time they had made it to the door, they had already rid themselves entirely of zombies, letting the vampires simply fight amongst themselves. For the short time, they looked back, noticing the trail of dead zombies, all with a cracked skull or bullet hole. Nearby they saw there were still at least 25 vampires feeding upon them. Betty looked towards Frank, as he took out some sort of purple tube-shaped grenade. Only slightly did she catch a label on it, something about a man named Gary Wilson. He also took out a match, silently asking her if she wanted him to finally rid them all off.

She nodded. “Do it. I never liked this place anyways.”

He smirked, lighting the small tube on fire as he tossed it towards the middle of the gym. After a few seconds of running away from the building did they hear an explosion and the sound of several screeches.
13412212.title: Smart

choices: "Where are my parents?"
"Where are we going?"
134122121.content:
"I think that was the last of them!" Betty yelled ahead to her uncle Frank as she ran closely behind him, careful not to lose sight of his taller frame. "Where are we running to?" She asked loud enough for him to hear clearly, but quietly enough to not alert any zombie that might still be around. He replied in a serious tone: "We're going to my car, I left it in the parking lot." Betty was surprised to hear that. The only car her uncle owned that she knew of was an older model he used to drive to work. Definitely not something she expected to still be in use in the zombie infested hellhole the world had become. For a moment, Betty considered asking Frank if he was indeed referring to wimpy old car, but decided she would find out soon enough and instead decided to ask something else. "Okay then, where did you get that thing you threw at those Vampires back there?" Frank let out a chuckle. "Oh, you mean that anti-son-of-a-bitch bomb? I got those from a man I met, a doctor, named Gary. I helped him clear away some Swimmers down by the river and he tossed me a few. Said the stuff was highly flammable and prone to exploding in intense heat. We didn't get a chance to talk very long, but he said he got the stuff from these things called Slimers, zombies who spit slime, obviously. You have to watch out for them though, they also spit red acid and blue sticky slime." Betty hadn't encountered any Slimers yet, and was very thankful for it. The Mimics she had learned how to handle early on, and weren't a major threat. Something that shot deadly slime at you, on the other hand, was something she doubted she could handle by herself. "Wow, that's amazing... say what happened to Gary?" Frank was silent for a moment before answering.


"I don't know." He finally said. "Me and Gary were separated when a group of zombie dogs chased us into a nearby building. By the time I lost them Gary was nowhere to be found. We had run in opposite directions so I sure we just lost track of each other, but..." Frank trailed off as he and his niece came to the school parking lot. "I'm sure he made it out okay." Betty said as she put a hand on her uncles shoulder. "Me too." He said with a smile. "Anyway, we need to get going, my car is parked over there." The car Frank pointed to was indeed the one Betty had thought it was, only with a few small changes. The wheels were reinforced, the front grill had a row of spikes running across it, and thick sheets of metal helped cover and coat the car with added protection. "Whoa...!" Betty gasped as she got a good look at the car. "When did you get all of this?!" Frank merely grinned as he got in and started it up. "Oh? I guy I met fixed it up for me, but we can talk about that later. Get in and let's get out of here." Betty nodded and got in on the passengers side. The two soon left the school in the distance and began moving along the cities empty streets. "Uncle Frank, I have another question..." Betty said as she looked out her window at the destruction around her. "Sure, what is it?" Frank replied cheerfully. Betty took a deep breath and asked...
134122121.title: Nice car

choices: Betty decides to search the north exhibit hall
Betty decides to search the east exhibit hall
1341221212.content:
Frank's cheerful expression turned serious again as he looked forward at the road ahead of them. "We're going to leave the city, almost everyone I knew is either dead... or undead. But, before we can do that we have a few stops to make." Frank reached below his seat and pulled out a sheet of paper. It was about twice the size of a piece of printer paper and a highly detailed map of the city. Frank handed it to Betty to look at and continued explaining their escape plan. "Back when this all started I met up with a group of other survivors in an abandoned church. One of them was a pilot who had escaped from the airport while it was being overrun. He said he could fly us all out, but we would need supplies. The place was swarming with zombies when he left and it could still have plenty of them hanging around when we get there. We decided it was best to split up for a few days, with a plan to gather what we could and met back at the church within a weeks time. Once we've all come back we'll help get the pilot to one of the planes and hopefully he'll fly us all out of here." Betty felt a little uneasy at hearing this, she had never flown before and with all the zombies attacking them while they tried to get away it made the situation seem even worse. She tried to get her mind off of it as she looked over the map. Several locations were marked in red ink, those must be the stops they had to make.


After a few minutes of reading the car stopped and Frank opened his door. Betty set the map down between the seats and followed her uncle outside, making sure to grab her handguns along the way. "This our first stop, uncle Frank?" Betty asked as she joined him next to the front door of the cities history museum. "Yeah, I heard this place was mostly untouched when people were trying to escape the initial outbreak of zombies. Should be a pretty good place to loot. You still got your knife and handguns?" Betty held up her hands to confirm that she did. "Good, here's some more ammo for them. Make sure you keep them reloaded." He tossed her a small case of handgun bullets as he opened the doors and peered inside. It was empty except for a level one shuffling down the entrance hallway. Frank closed the door back and turned to Betty. "I hate to say this, but we're gonna have to split up to cover more ground. After half an hour we can meet back here. Think you can handle it?" Betty thought for a moment and shook her head yes. "Alright, I know you'll be strong. Let's hurry up and get what we need." No sooner had Frank said these words then he disappeared behind the large door with Betty following close behind.
1341221212.title: The first stop

choices: A loud alarm siren fills the air
Nothing... the alarm must be dead...
13412212121.content:
The museum was large and fortunately, mostly empty as well. Betty had decided to take a stealth approach with her knife and save ammo, something told her she'd need it later. She had made it down two hallways and successfully brought down two level one zombies by sneaking up on them. She was more used to fighting now and wasn't quite as squeamish as she had been when she took shelter in the school. Along her way to the north exhibit hall she had seen a large R spray painted inside a circle on the wall. She didn't know what it meant, but decided it would probably be worth checking out. She walked into a huge display room that was decorated with wondrous artifacts and valuables from the far east. Betty felt as if she had actually stepped into feudal japan as she looked about. Everything from full suits of armor to expensive-looking vases lined the walls. In the far corner was a lone trash can with the same R symbol as she'd see in the hallway. "Just a trash can?" Betty said to herself, confused. "Am I supposed to look inside it or something..." She removed the top and found to her surprise that it wasn't full of garbage. She pulled out a backpack and opened its main zipper to find 2 bottles of water and a lighter. In the pockets she found some notes on the zombies and a few pens and pencils. "Wow, I'll have to show uncle Frank these!" She said gleefully as she put the backpack on. "Its a little small, but at least its not uncomfortable." She was about to move on when something caught her eye...


She walked over to a display case that sat next to the door she had just come through. She must have not seen it on her way in and almost missed it, which would have been regrettable considering what was inside. Through the clear glass sat a sword in a sheath that was laying on a soft red pillow. Right below it was a small card that detailed its back story. "This sword once belonged to Miyamoto Musashi, a japanese samurai who..." Betty stopped reading for a moment. "Wait, I've heard that name before in history class. He was one of the greatest warriors of all time!" She looked back down at the glass case again. "Should I take it?" She thought for a moment. Surely taking the sword would set off some sort of alarm... unless it had already gone off. She HAD seen several broken cases on the way here, so its possible taking the sword wouldn't do anything. Betty crossed her fingers as she brought her pistol down on the glass as hard as she could.
13412212121.title: A legendary blade...

choices: She reaches her destination safely.
Giant zombie on road.
134122121211.content:
The alarm sounded loudly as it attracted zombies. Betty quickly grabbed the sword and ran to the exit. Many level one zombies started coming from the entrance and the exit. Luckily, Betty managed to take out her pistol and shoot the zombies surrounding the exit and ran out. She heard a large bark, an infected dog started to run towards her but she took the sword and sliced it's head off.


She stared in disbelief at what she did, But quickly regained her senses. She looked towards her uncles car, but he wasn't there. In fact... Frank was nowhere to be seen! She panicked and ran away as more zombies surrounded her location. Up ahead was a subway entrance, maybe she could escape them inside...

Many trains were on fire and flipped around, dead zombies and body bags were everywhere. Reading the wall she saw many messages. One caught her attention: "THEY ARE NOT GOING TO RESCUE US. - JACK"

Betty didn't believe it and continued towards the subway's exit, Along the way she found a suitcase full of pistols and money on a bench. She took a pistol and got out of the subway's exit....


A large boom came from the other side of the town... they were bombing the city! After a few minutes, the jets didn't bomb her location. She hopped into a car and. amazingly, managed to hot wired it. "I hope I know how to drive...." She muttered as the car's engine started. Betty drove out of that part of the city into another part.
134122121211.title: Prepare for the horde...(Some L4D References)

choices: Introduces himself.
Fires a grenade at everyone.
1341221212111.content:
Betty reached the a new part of the city, many survivors were here. A survivor saw her from a watch-tower and aimed his rifle at her as she got out of her car. "I'm not infected!" She shouted to him. He pressed a button and the gates opened. She went in and saw that there were many people here. There was a dead Deathtouch lying against many bodies and many dead zombies. "Welcome to Safe Point City." Said someone behind her. "My name is Jack, nice to meet you." He smiled. "Jack? Are you the one who wrote the writing on the wall in the subway?" She asked. "Yes, It was me." Jack replied. After chatting with her,Jack brought her into a house and gave her a key.

"This will be your house from now on." He told Betty, she nodded and he left. "This fort won't hold out much longer, the barricades are broken..." She inspected the things outside from the window, when a large Deathtouch came. "FUCK NO!!!" Yelled people outside as they shot the Deathtouch. "THIS IS THE MOTHER FUCKING 5TH TIME!!!" Another one yelled. Jack opened the door and threw her an AK-47. "Come out and help us!" He shouted. Betty ran out and shot the Deathtouch from a far distance. The deathtouch started to break the barricade as it summoned many hordes of zombies with its anguished yell. The deathtouch came in after a short while and went on a rampage. He grabbed two people and ate their limbs out and swallowed them whole. He climbed onto the watch-tower and bit the person's head off and crushed the tower down. Betty fired many rounds at the horrible monster but it didn't fall. Jack climbed on a ladder to a tower with a large turret and blasted it at the Deathtouch, but it still continued to feast on people.

He slowly tore away people's limbs, hearts, lungs and many other parts. When all hope seemed lost, a large gunshot came from behind the monster and it fell, finally succumbing to its many wounds. The Deathtouch (what was left of it) tried standing up, but was shot again. It seemed like it was dead.

Betty looked at the person. He was wearing a helmet with amour that no zombie could destroy. He had a large rifle that held grenades.

He walks up and....
1341221212111.title: Safe Point City.

choices: "We can't keep the zombies at bay any longer!"
"There's a man outside looking for you!"
13412212121111.content:
"Whats wrong with you people, you never seen a Deathtouch before? You can't kill them by just shooting, you have to reduce them to almost nothing before they die. Of course, these arn't your run of the mill Deathtouches, somethings been mutating them." He walked over to the corpse of the Deathtouch he had just killed. It still had part of its head and upper torso, but most of the rest of it had fallen apart. A thin stream of pink mist rose from the corpse and quickly dissipated. "I refer to these ones as G2's, which means generation 2. I'm pretty sure one of the members of the brotherhood is doing this, they were the ones who made these monsters, I've been hunting them since day one..." The man turned away from the gathering crowd of people and continued. "They took my wife and daughter, there were too many... and then that man in the white robe showed up..."


Betty walked over to the man and put a hand on his shoulder. "I know what you mean... a swarm appeared while me and by uncle where looting a museum, we got separated... I still don't know if he's alive or dead..." The man turned back around with anger in his eyes. "Those bastards... I don't know why the fuck they did this, but I'm gonna put an end to it one way or another. If it takes the rest of my life I'll make them pay for what they did." Betty took the mans hand and led him to the house Jack had given her while the others began repairing the barricade and helping the guards clear it of zombies. Once inside Betty showed him the notes she had found in the backpack. "I see... these were quite helpful." Thank you... what was your name.?" He asked as he finished reading the last note. Betty smiled and told him her name and her uncles name. "My names John. You know, you won't find your uncle if you stay here. I'm planning on heading out again tomorrow, I'm close to finding out where these mutated Deathtouches are coming from. If you want you could join me... our group could use another member." Betty thought it over. "I don't know..." She said. "I just got here... but I really want to find my uncle..." John was about to say something when Jack opened the door and came barging in. "Quick, come outside!"
13412212121111.title: One bad man

choices: PREPARE FOR THE HORDE!
134122121211111.content:
"Run!" Yelled the person on the west watch-tower as 3 Deathtouches slowly advanced towards the tower. One of them roared, which attracted a horde of zombies towards them. John quickly shot a grenade towards the death-touch. Before the person could even get down from the tower, a large rock hit him in the face and he flew off it. Betty quickly fired an entire clip into the horde and reloaded. "Enter this truck!" Jack shouted as he drove a truck out of the garage. It had a turret at the back and two seats in front. (THIS IS NOT A WARTHOG FROM HALO.) John climbed up at the turret and manned it while Betty opened the door and went in. Jack handed her a RPG. "Blow up the tower over there!" He said as he pointed towards the biggest tower. Betty fired the rocket and the towers fell. Jack quickly drove as the death-touches followed them.

"SHOOT IT! SHOOT IT!!!!!" Betty yelled. John was firing the turret like mad towards the three monsters while they chased the car. One of them was looking very disturbing, it's skin has fallen off from it's face and you could see blood dripping from it while the body was bleeding in the same way. It soon died, leaving two left...

"We are almost out of gas! Betty! FIRE A ROCKET AT THEM!!!!" Shouted Jack. Betty reloaded the RPG7 and fired a rocket at them. Both of the monsters fell like ragdolls and stopped moving.

They soon came to another part of the city. Many stores were on fire. A little further ahead on the docks they saw a boat. "FUCK YEAH!" Shouted John as he looked at it. "We need gas for the boat..." Jack said while he looked around. A few gas-cans were near the boat,"Well, that was easy." Betty ran towards the boat and filled it up. A bridge was in front of the boat, making it impossible to pass it. They looked over the bridge and saw a few generators... full of zombies. "God..." John said in disbelief. "Well, if we want to get the fuck out of this hell hole we must do this." Jack said as he looked towards the generators.

They soon jumped down to the lower area and fought the horde of undead. Each time they powered up a generator. A huge horde comes with at least one Deathtouch.

Three hours later, they filled up it all and went to the bridge control room. "If we press this, it WILL attract all the zombies from the entire county...." Betty said. John wanted to press it, but always stop himself before doing it. When he finally did it, they ran to the boat and quickly went in it. They would have to defend it till the bridge goes up.
134122121211111.title: "RUN FOR YOUR LIVES!!!"

choices: She waits five more minutes...
She goes looking for him...
134122121212.content:
A few seconds passed... then a minute... of complete silence. Betty reached down and carefully pulled the magnificent sword from its resting place. She put her handgun into her backpack and pulled the katana from its sheath. Its beautifully reflective surface seemed to cut through the air itself as Betty gave it a few practice swings. It was a little heavier then she anticipated, but still light enough for her to get some practical use out of it. "Magnificent..." Betty said as she left the room and began looking for a "volunteer" to test her shiny new weapon on. She walked down yet another massive hallway that would eventually take her back to the main entrance hall. Too bad the entire passage was completely empty except for the occasional corpse, non-moving of course. "Damn, I get this cool new toy and can't find any zombies to use it on... and uncle Frank's expecting me back up front in fifteen more minutes so its not like I can go hunting for them." She sighed and swung her new sword around a bit as she walked. "I guess I should be thankful... I just wish one zombie would find me so I could kill it, just one."


Betty turned the final corner and was met with... nothing. The main entrance was completely empty except for the level one zombie her uncle had killed when they first walked in. Betty looked up at a clock on the wall that was amazingly still working and saw that her uncle was due to meet up with her in less then five minutes. "C'mon uncle, hurry up. I want to get out of this boring place." Ten minutes passed and their was still no sign of Frank. Now Betty was getting a little worried, was he just running late or did something hold him up? Worse, what if the zombies got him? "No, no. That's ridiculous." She said aloud to reassure herself. "He fought his way into my school just to rescue me... I'm sure he's fine... still..." Another five minutes passed and still there was no sign of her uncle. Alone and now a little bit scared, Betty tried desperately to think of what to do...
134122121212.title: Empty and alone

choices: She makes a run for it
She confronts the man in the white robe
1341221212122.content:
There was no time to lose, if Frank was indeed in trouble Betty would have to act fast if she wanted to save him. She quickly ran off down the hallway that Frank had taken when they arrived. "Oh god, I take it all back..." Betty moaned as she turned a corner and was met with the gaze of a little girl with red eyes. "If I never see another zombie after today I won't complain ever again!" The little girl was only a level one and could merely shuffle towards Betty as she ran past her into another hallway that would hopefully take her closer to her uncle. It wasn't hard to lose the little zombie girl and soon Betty was alone once again. As she walked she tried to listen for moans and footsteps, but soon became distracted by the many exhibits surrounding her as she moved deeper into this place trying to keep her thoughts off what might have become of her uncle. Several old cars from the early 1900s were proudly displayed alongside mannequins dressed in the bygone decades most fashionable attire. A few signs mentioned things like prohibition and women's suffrage which Betty had read about in school with several other signs and charts displaying similar facts and trivia relating to this point in history. It was oddly comforting and reminded her of her old history class with her one and only friend. The teacher who taught that class, mr. Duncan, had been fairly nice to the two and actually paid attention when the other students bothered her. Normally these happy memories would have brought a smile to her face, but were bittersweet under the current circumstances. "God, I miss her..." Betty said aloud as she looked over a display of various old appliances.


She was quickly snapped back to reality when she heard a faint moan echo down the halls along with a loud chorus of groans from a nearby horde of undead. With all the courage she could muster Betty readied herself for the fight of her life and headed in the direction the moan that had obviously been her uncle came from. When she got to the door the noise was coming from her heart sank. Along with the sound of two people talking inside there were the unmistakable cries of a massive group of undead emanating from the room. Once of the two voices belonged to Frank, but the other was deeper, more commanding and intimidating. "Holy shit, don't they realize that they're surrounded in there?!" Betty gasped as she put her hand on the door and pulled it open...

A long scream escaped her lips as her eyes fell on the scene inside.

There was her uncle, beaten, bloody, and barely breathing as a man who was easily at least 7 feet tall and wearing a white robe interrogated him with a sword to his throat. Frank barely even noticed his niece enter the room as he tried vainly to free himself from the half dozen swords that pinned him to the wall. That was nothing however, compared to the dozens of decaying dead bodies that surrounded the two as if they were obedient dogs waiting for their masters next order. "B-Betty, run..." Frank choked out as the man in the robe turned to face her, a sinister smile on his twisted face...

No time to think, what does Betty do?
1341221212122.title: The past meets the present

choices: Betty agrees to listen to his story
Betty refuses and tries to convince him to let her and Frank go
13412212121222.content:
Betty stood her ground and kept her katana out in front of her as she took a step closer, ready to strike against anything that ran at her. "What the fuck did you do to my uncle?!" She demanded as she desperately tried to hide the fear in her voice. "Oh?" The man answered in a disturbing calm tone. "Well, since you asked me so politely, I'll tell you... But first, I think introductions are in order. My name is Cain, pleased to meet you. And you are...?" Betty was silent and merely glared at the man. "Come now, don't be shy... I believe your uncle here called you Betty? He has been quite helpful, told me all about his friends, the other survivors, and their plans... yet..." He paused for a moment and then resumed talking. "He never mentioned you, not even your name. Even as I beat him senseless he told me no more then the fact that he had a niece, let alone one here with him. Had you not barged in so rudely... I doubt I would have noticed you here." He smiled and looked back at Frank. "You tried so hard to protect her, shame it was for nothing, eh?" He said as he gestured for his minions to move in and surround her.


"NO! BETTY RUN!" Frank shouted as he watched helplessly as they swarmed around her, cutting off her escape before she could even notice. "Now now." Cain said in a stern tone as Betty screamed. "They won't harm her, not just yet anyway. I still need your cooperation and I don't intend to harm a child." He smiled wickedly as he watched Betty cower in the center of the mob of zombies, meekly holding her blade in front of her. Frank glared at him with disgust as he struggled once again to get free. "Damn it, you son of a bitch! Just kill me and get it over with, but leave her alone, she has nothing to do with this! She's just a child, for Christ's sake!" This outburst seem to catch Cain's attention rather quickly, as the frown on his face showed.


"Nothing... to do with this?" He growled as he towered over the helpless man before him. "Just a child...? My wife had "nothing to do with this," my son was "just a child," and neither of them were shown mercy! They were both killed right before my eyes and there was nothing I could do to stop it!" Tears began forming in the huge mans eyes as his fists trembled. "This world takes without remorse... Why do you think you and her are any different?" Frank fell silent. All this time he had been this mans prisoner and he hadn't heard him once mention a wife or child. Only the brotherhood and its plans to "save" the world, starting with Bitterwood. "You... your wife and child?" Betty asked, breaking the silence and nearly startling the two men who had almost forgotten she was there. "Yes..." Cain answered softly while wiping the tears from his face. "Will... will you hear my story, child?" He asked as he motioned for the zombies to step back.

13413.content: Betty quickly ran into the girls restroom only to find things were just as bad there. She couldn't see any zombies, but the whole room was like something out of a horror movie. Blood was smeared across the walls, the door of one of the stalls had been torn off, and worst of all, the bodies of 2 of Betty's classmates were leaning against the wall. They must have been there for a few days as they gave off a horrible smell and looked mildly decayed. Betty nearly threw up at the sight and grabbed the nearby sink to keep from falling over. She threw up into it and began to cry. This had all seemed like a horrible dream before, but finding the corpses of 2 other girls her age laying in puddles of their own blood helped to hammer the realism of the situation into her mind. She had been lucky to survive this long while everyone else was dying, but she couldn't rely on luck to get her out of this. She would have to confront this nightmare head on if she was going to survive, which may the hardest thing she would ever have to do. Betty slumped to the floor as she stared in horror at the unfortunate girls who had met their end only a short while ago. It would be a while before Betty could bear to stand again. She had see a few bodies before while trying to escape the zombies, but none like this. Just thinking about what must have happened made Betty shiver. After what seemed like a hundred years Betty finally got back up on her feet and prepared to move on. She would have to figure out a way to get out of here and fast before the zombies find her again. She would also have to be more careful, one wrong move and she could end up like those two girls...

135.content:
Betty Winters sat on her couch with her knees pulled to her chest, watching the eriely claming glow of the TV. All the channels had been the same for the last two days. An old-time warning symbol representing the Emergency Broadcast System with scrolling text. Five days ago, it had interupted her watching the latest episode of American Idol. Something had happened, and the dead where coming back to life.

Five days ago, the recommendation was to try to evacuate. When that failed, four days ago, they recommended that everyone try to get to localized areas. Her mom had refused to leave the house, so her dad went to go get supplies to come back and hunker down. On day three of the outbreak, her father returned injured, bitten and scratched. That same day the recommendation was to stay inside. The message had been the same ever since. Late on the third night, her dad died. On the fourth morning, she woke to her mother screaming. Her dad was attacking her, and Betty's mother was defending herself with a knife. He almost killed her - he would have killed her - but Betty intervened. Grabbing her mothers pistol from their bedroom closet, Betty fired on her father through tightly shut eyes. The round amazingly found its mark, piercing her father's heart...

Betty looked to her right. On the recliner laid her mother, her breathing shallow and nursing the bullet wound to her gut. The shot had gone through her father and into her mother. She sighed, knowing her mom wouldn't be long for this world. Other zombies had come calling, attracted to the noise, but her dad had fortified the house on the first two day. Apparently the zombies where attracted by noise, so Betty had muted the television.

The warning this morning was that the best way to kill them was to take off their heads. She wimpered as her mother began to cough, her already labored breathing becoming more shallow as the fit ended. Betty onlyknew she had to do something. She had to get out of this house, to go find help. She needed someone else to help her. She couldn't do this alone. She got up and kissed her mom on the forehead. "I'm going to the bathroom. I'll be right back, mommy." Her voice caught in her throat. "I love you..." she whispered as she walked out of the room.

She walked down the hall, past the bathroom and into her bedroom. She put a black zipup hoodie on, and changed from her sweats into her favorite pair of jeans and a pair of slightly used cross-training sneakers. She grunted as she put on the poorly recieved gift from her uncle, his way of hinting to loose some weight. Grabbing her backpack she made her way to the kitchen and grabbed what little water and food she had left. On the kitchen table she grabbed the half used first aid kit and her mom's pistol. Checking the chamber, she saw that she only had three rounds left in the 9mm.

She looked down the hall and frowned. To her left was the master bedroom, and she could see her dad's lifeless feet in the room. Off to her right she could see the somehow peaceful blue glow in the den, where her mother lay dying. Reaching up, she grabbed the hanging ball and pulled down the ladder to the attic. "I love you," she whispered again as she climbed up into the attic and cralwed over to a set of vents over the garage. Kicking hard, she popped them out and slid her pack of provisions onto the roof of the garage and took a couple claming breaths before squeezing through the very tight hole to the world outside.

Standing on her garage, Bitterwood was frighteningly quiet. She wished silently that Sally hadn't moved and then rebuked herself. If Sally had been here, she would be caught in this nightmare too. But then again at least she wouldn't be alone. Her eyes filled with tears, and she sank to her knees under the weight of the enormity of the situation. She looked back at the vents and then out to the city. The last time she had seen any "community gathering" locations broadcast, they had said to go to churches or schools.

The church was three miles to the east, her high school was only two miles north-west. She looked at the vents again. Home was so familiar, but she knew what waited for her inside. Bittertown High was familiar too, but she hated every day she spent there. The other kids had never accepted her, none of them - except Sally. The church might be safe, but her family wasn't the god-fearing, bible-reading, church-going folk that would likely be assembling there. Who knew if they would accept her. No one else seemed too...

She spotted a blue 2011 Ford Escape sitting in the flowerbed in front of a nearby house, the flowerbed was almost completely flooded. A large kayak was perched and tied to the top of the roof.

Betty felt a sudden surge of hope as she splashed through the water surrounding the SUV. Luckily, it was only up to her ankles deep. She reached the front door and cautiously opened it. What her eyes fell on suddenly made her sick to her stomach. She found the blood soaked corpse of a teenage girl. about 4 years younger than herself, sitting motionless in the font seat. She carefully heaved the body out and gently laid it in the water surrounding her. She then spent 3 minutes in silence. Betty then climbed into the drivers seat. She found the keys and started the engine. She steered the vehicle slowly out of the submurged garden and onto the main road, continuing toward the high school. As she neared the high schools parking lot, she suddenly spotted someone wandering in the parking lot. "It must be another survivor." she said, as she pulled up to them. 1353.content:
Betty walked over to the edge of the garage and peered into the street below. There were a dozen, or maybe two dozen, zombies shambling past abandoned empty cars and lifeless looking houses. The once quiet suburb was now filled with the noise of moaning, scraping, and the occasional fear or pain filled scream. Many of the houses looked broken into despite having various qualities of defense. Betty's had been one of the lucky few they ignored for whatever reason. The only positive thing she could see about the current situation was the fact that all of the zombies were the common slow-moving ones she had seen on the news. She knew there were a few stronger types, but hadn't seen any of them so she would be unable to identify any of them right away. Hopefully, she would be with other people when the time came to actually fight these monsters and escape. Betty moved over to the side of the garage that overlooked their driveway and found the ladder her dad had left propped up in case the house was overrun. The level one zombies couldn't climb it and the garage was relatively safe with its massive door closed.


Betty took a deep breath and quickly climbed down before the zombies noticed her. She went around to the back of the house and was pleased to find that no zombies were in any of the backyards, at least none that she could see... who knows what awaited her behind the fences surrounding her neighbors houses? Still, it was the safest way if it meant not having to deal with a mob of zombies chasing her. She moved quietly and hopped over the wooden fence that led to Ms. Davidson's house. She and her husband had lived there with their two sons for the past ten years and they were always friendly and kind to whoever they met. Betty looked into a broken window into the empty house and felt a pang of sadness. They might've escaped... after all, no one in Betty's family had heard any noise coming from the house since day one.


Betty decided to take out her pistol as she made her way over the short metal fence into the next yard. She probably wouldn't need to use it, but it couldn't hurt to take precautions. She made it by the next three houses with ease. When she came to the last one on the street though, she ran into trouble. Before she could climb over the fence into the final yard she heard a loud growl come from the other side. Betty looked through a small hole and saw two dogs, one chained to a doghouse, one wandering about freely, both disfigured and obviously zombiefied. She quickly looked away, unable to stomach the sight for more then a few seconds. She looked back towards her house which was almost out of sight and tried to think. She walked to the side of the house she was next to and looked around to the front yard. The only zombies were several yards away, about half of them were surrounding a car for some reason. Betty could run for it... but if they saw her before she could get to the next street they'd chase her all the way to the church... if they didn't kill her instead. Betty looked down at the gun in her hands and back out at the street. Finally, she spared one final gaze at the fence where two zombie dogs waited on the other side...

13532.content:
Betty checked one final time to make sure that they were all still facing the car and once she had confirmed that every last zombie was distracted she began running as quickly and silently as possible. Fortunately, whatever held the mob of undead's attention kept it long after Betty had disappeared onto the house that had been across the street... she didn't even have to open the broken off door. As soon as she stepped inside Betty pressed her back up against the wall and kept her eyes peeled for signs of movement. Silence. Betty walked past the stairs and into the living room where she found a Spongebob backpack laying on the floor. It was a little small and not really her style, but she was glad to have something to put her first aid kit in. Betty gave the room a quick look around and when she didn't see anything useful, moved into the kitchen.


There was a days old corpse of a middle aged woman laying under the table with a towel over her face and flies buzzing over her body. Betty covered her mouth and nose in an attempt to cut off the smell and moved over to the refrigerator. She was hungry and it would be good to get some supplies to take with her. The warm glow of the tiny light bulb and fresh looking produce told Betty that this house still had power. "Thank goodness." She said as she reached inside and pulled out a crisp orange carrot and took a bite. Unlike most teenagers, Betty had a certain fondness for vegetables, of course she also had quite the soft spot for sweets. After finishing the carrot Betty closed the door and checked the cabinets for food that wouldn't go bad if the church didn't have a working fridge. The shelves inside were lined with everything from captain crunch to ketchup. It took a few minutes for her to decide what to take and what to leave, yet once her backpack was full she had a little bit of everything and was quite satisfied with the variety. She may have packed more snack cakes then necessary, but also included plenty of heathy foods.


After she had checked the window to make sure the outside was clear, Betty open the kitchens still intact door and walked out into the houses back yard. In a few minutes of careful navigating she was back on the street heading for the church, which she could now see up ahead. The tall tree that was growing in its front yard was unmistakable. Betty took momentary cover behind a car as a level 2 zombie seemed to sniff at the air around it as it passed by. Once it was out of sight Betty made a run for the church and was just about to the front steps when that same zombie appeared from behind a nearby car and began running towards her at a frightening speed! Betty hadn't seen any zombies like this one and in a panic...
13532.title: Almost there...!

choices: Betty decides to talk to Brock

135321.content:
Without even thinking Betty raised her handgun and leveled it with the sprinting zombies chest. The first two shots she fired hit it dead center, but didn't seem to do anything. Just as she was about to panic and waste her final shot a faint memory of a zombie movie she had seen as a child pasted through her mind. Headshots. There was one bullet left in the chamber, if she missed with this one she wouldn't even have time to bang on the door or call for help. She waited a few moments for it to get as close as possible and then fired....


Amazingly, the bullet found its mark and tore through the zombies head, making a slight splurting sound as it broke through the back of its skull. The monster twitched and fell to the ground right at Betty's feet, blood and bits of brain leaking from the back of its destroyed head. Betty dropped her empty gun and sat down on the nearby steps of the church shaking uncontrollably. "My god, I've taken another life..." She thought silently to herself. "When... when will this nightmare end?!" A tear began rolling down her cheek only to be wiped away by a gloved hand. Shocked, Betty quickly spun around and almost fell to the ground from the surprise. She was so consumed in her grief that she hadn't even heard the door open behind her. "My my, dear child, are you all right?" The skinny old man before her asked. "I'm priest Edwin, please come inside quickly before more of them show up." Betty got up slowly and picked up her gun before following the man inside the church.


"I-I'm sorry, I didn't introduce myself!" Betty stammered as they walked into the main room of the church as two burly men resealed the entrance to the door. "My name... is Betty... I lived a few miles away. My parents... didn't make it here with me..." The old man frowned as he led her to a seat next to a table with drinks and plastic cups stacked upon it. "You brave child, I'm so sorry to hear that." Edwin said as he got her a cup of water from the table. "You must have the lord's protection to be able to get here by yourself." Betty took the cup and gulped down half of it before thanking him. They talked for a few minutes and he soon got up explaining that he had other people to see to and if she needed anything to talk his nephew, Brock. Betty nodded her head and finished drinking her water alone amidst the chatter of the other survivors.

141.content:
Eric Dressil was not in a good mood. He was stuck sitting around in the wardens office as hordes of the undead stalked the hallways of the prison. He had once been an immate here, now he was one of the only humans left alive. Just three days ago he saw his best friend Richie get torn to pieces by a Stalker (former immate Lester) as they both were making their way through the mess hall. Only Eric and Smith made it to their current safehold and avoided death. Eric got up out of his seat and walked over to the barricated doors. They were still standing and may even hold out for another day or two. Smith got up off of the floor and walked over to the broken window behind the wardens desk and looked outside. They were still there, eeriely lit by the moonlight.


The zombies continued to walk aimlessly through the yard outside, hunting for those that still breathed air. Across the yard near the wall was a Pyro and what appeared to be a Vampire. Smith looked back over towards Eric and saw that he had moved away from the doors and into the back room. When Smith entered the room he saw Eric was checking their food supply box that they had picked up in the mess hall. "How are our suppies doing?" Asked Smith. "Its all gone..." Said Eric grimly as he stood back up. He pushed Smith aside and walked back into the wardens office. Smith follwed him.


Eric picked his makeshift screwdriver shank up off of the wardens desk and tossed Smith his brass knuckles. "Surely you're not thinking of-" Began Smith, but he was cut off by Eric. "We can't stay here, we're out of food and water. I'd rather go out there and kill as many of those motherfuckers as I can, even if they kill me. Its a hell of alot better then sitting here and waiting to die like a pussy." Smith stood there for a moment, thinking over what Eric had just said. "Good point I guess, what do you want to do...?" Eric walked over to the window, looked outside for a few minutes, and rested his hand on the desk. "I figure we have three options..." Eric and Smith talked it over and weighed their choices. Finally they decided to...

1411.content: The two men decided that their best option was to try and move around the zombies by going along the outer wall between windows. "You sure this is a good idea?" Smith asked as Eric opened the broken window. "Fuck no. We could fall, the other windows could all be locked, or any number of things. But this is the best chance we got unless one of them bastards learns to climb, which I think is unlikely." Eric replied back as he steped out onto the narrow row of bricks jutting from the prisons wall. He motioned for Smith to follow as he moved slowly sideways across the tiny inprovised walkway. There were only about 6 inches of footspace and one false move would send them plumeting to their doom. Eric, being calm and collected when he needed to be, was having no trouble with this little endevour. Smith, on the other hand was more use to the less physical aspects of crime such as working a chopshop or smuggling goods from location to location, and didn't like to put his own ass on the line. Unfortunately, the current situation called for him to take a few risks that would hopefully pay off. "We almost to the next window?" Smith asked as he tried to avoid looking down."We're about halfway done." Eric called back. "Pick up the pace a little, the sooner we get to the next window the sooner you don't have to worry about becoming a stain on ground." Smith gave him a glare as Eric shuffled along without noticing. "So, what do we do if this window is locked?" Smith questioned as he started to move a little faster. "We go to the next one." Eric replied. "And if that one is locked?" "Next one." "What if ALL of them are locked?" "Guess we're screwed then." Eric said with a laugh. "Great..." Smith mumbled as he began to sweat. Eric stopped all of a sudden when he came to the window, almost causing Smith to bump into him. "Why'd you s-" Smith began to ask. "We made it." Eric said as he bent down carefully to check the window with one hand holding onto the building for balance. Using his free hand Eric took his shank out of his pocket and pried the window open. "Good thing it wasn't locked." Eric taunted Smith. "Har har, now hurry up and get the hell inside." Smith retorted. Once both men were back inside they took a look around the room they were in. It appeared to be a small cleaning supply room as the shelves were stacked with things like paper towels and various spray bottles. There was also a door with a clear glass window that led out into the hallway. "What now...?" Smith asked, annoyed.
1411.title: Scaling the outer wall

choices: "Fight our way down the hallway and see if we can get inside one of the rooms."
"Try to get downstairs and find a way to escape."
14111.content: "We sould take a look around before moving on." Eric said as he walked over to one of the shelves and bent down to examine some boxes. "I doubt we'll be coming back here anytime soon so we better grab anything we might need now. I really don't wanna die because we were in such a big hurry that we passed a gun or something." "You really think someone might've stashed a gun in here?" Smith asked as he pushed aside bottles filled with bright clear liquids. "Zombies are probably standing outside this room right now." Eric said as he opened a box filled with bottles of bleach. "I wouldn't be surprised to find a goddamn RPG sitting in one of these boxes." In their first five minutes of searching all they found were enough cleaning supplies to fill an armory, but they kept looking. Finally Smith had had enough and decided to take a rest. "Maybe we should just move on, there's nothing here." He complained as he sat down on the floor by the window. "Forget it, I came this far and I'm sure as hell gonna finish, there's only 2 boxes left." Eric replied angrily. "Great, 15 boxes down and 2 to go." Smith said with an annoyed tone. "Shut up and help me pull the duct tape off this long one!" Eric yelled at Smith, finally starting to lose his temper at the box which he couldn't seem to get open. "Fine." Smith almost yelled back at Eric. "But after this one we need to move, I can hear them moving outside and I think they know we're here." It took them a minute to get the box open, a minute that they might not be able to spare judging from the sounds coming from the outside. "Christ, I hope whatever was in here was worth it." Smith said as he and Eric reached into the packing foam inside. They each touched something at the same time and pulled out what they had. In their hands were 2 brand new mops with shining metal handles. "These'll do..." Eric whispered as he got up and walked over to the door. Upon looking through the doors clear glass window Eric saw that there were indeed zombies outside, 12 to be exact. 3 level 2's, a vampire, and 8 level 1's. Most of them were standing along the hallway to their right, but the vampire and one of the level 2's were standing to their left, just in front of the stairs that led to the first floor. 14111.title: Time to clean up this prison

141111.content:
Smith hated the idea of just the two them trying to fend off a whole gang of zombies with just mops. True, they had metal handles and could probably deal some damage if swung hard enough, especially against the decaying level ones, but they were both outnumbered and probably outmatched with the level two's and the Vampire. "Ah shit, guess I'm ready whenever you are..." Smith said as he tightened his grip on his meager weapon. "Right as soon as I open this door we run down that hall and take cover in the first open room we see. Don't stumble or fall, I'm not taking the time to rescue you from one of the fast ones. Smith nodded nervously and got ready to run as soon as Eric turned the knob. A few seconds passed and the air was filled with the moans of the damned and the screams of the two convicts as they ran for their lives. There was no way they would be able to get back to the cleaning supply room now, they would either reach salvation or fall to the undead.


Eric wasn't really used to using weapons as he had won most of his fights with only his own two hands, but he was a natural with the staff-like mop. He effortlessly knocked aside three level ones as he ran towards the only open door at the end of the hallway. One of the level two's tried to run up and swipe him, only to be bashed aside with a broken jaw and a few missing teeth. Even Smith, who had only fought a few times in his life was doing an impressive job of keeping the zombies approaching them from the rear away. The Vampire was still closing in on them, but the level two that had been with it suffered a case of broken kneecap and was limping along pathetically far behind. The final level two posed more of a threat as it stood directly in front of the door they were trying to reach. "Smith!" Eric called as he made another level one taste the floor. "Get ready to run inside, I'm gonna knock that fucker down!" Smith nodded and kicked away a staggering level one. "I'll take out the Vampire then!" He called as he quickly pulled a 180 and sent the Vampire flying with one mighty swing of his mop. Then, without missing a beat, he spun back around and continued following Eric to the door.


The level 2 growled and tried to slash Eric as he held up the mop to defend himself. The bastard's claws cut clean through the mop, yet only served to give Eric a means of finishing it. Smith ran inside the open door as Eric brought the sharpened end of the mop crashing through the thing's mouth and skull. Both convicts were safely inside the room before its body even hit the floor. "Jesus man, you were a BEAST out there!" Smith complimented as Eric pulled the door shut just as the surviving zombies began crowding around the outside. "You didn't do too bad yourself, nice work." Eric said calmly as he looked over the broken half of the mop he still had. It wouldn't be much for defending now, but its new sharpened edge gave it some excellent killing potential. It seems things had gone rather smoothly so the two remained calm and hopeful as they ransacked the messy office they found themselves in. "Say, this place look familiar to you?" Smith asked as he pushed aside a stack of papers and looked inside a desk. "Sort of..." Eric replied as he opened a filing cabinet that was laying on its side. "Well, lookie here..." He called cheerfully as pulled out a wad of hundred dollar bills. "Apparently, mr. Ben Franklin decided to hide in there..." He held the small fortune in front of a stunned Smith for a few seconds before putting into his pocket. "Arn't you the least bit suspicious of why that was in there?" Smith asked as he resumed clearing out the desk.


"I sure don't fuckin' care!" Eric said as he dumped the rest of the contents of the filing cabinet onto the floor. "Maybe the money fairy left it for all the good little serial killers and rapists to find here in this shithole of a prison. Hell, that would make more sense then whats going on now..." Both the two looked long and hard for half an hour and when all was said and done had: a book of matches, a crowbar, and a vintage bottle of wine that was inside a damaged safe. After quickly polishing off 75% of the wine by himself Eric decided it was a good time to leave. Smith however, who was a little less drunk, wanted to wait here until morning. Eric didn't like the idea, but was just sober enough not to get pissed off and instead made himself a makeshift bed from the papers and the curtains from the rooms only window. Smith got what was left and slept very poorly that night.

The two walked through the corridors, gripping their mop handle's tightly. "You got any idea what we'll do when we get out of here?" Eric asked. "But we're almost free, we just gotta go down these steps and out the front door and we can get the fuck out of here!" Smith yelled to him in a desperate attempt to get Eric to follow him. Eric followed close behind him with his nightstick in one hand and his gun in the other, if anything jumped them he would be ready. Eric quickly sped up after him with his nightstick ready to strike. 'I'll be able to knock two of them away, but you'll have to take the last one." Eric tackled one of the zombies to the ground and smacked the other one across the face with his nightstick. Both zombies were now down for the count, but the one he had tackled was still alive and trying to get back up. Eric finished it off as Smith blew away the remaining zombie with his gun. "Thought you were gonna save ammo?" Eric asked Smith as he pushed open the broken doors and stepped outside. "I am, I still have 2 bullets left." Smith said as he joined Eric outside. "Looks like you're gonna need them." Eric said grimly as he look around the front yard. "Cause I can see 3 zombies over by the main gate." Smith looked to where Eric pointed and saw them too.
