Smith didn't argue and did what he was told. In a few short minutes the supermarket faded from sight as the two searched for a place to treat their wounds...
141221211112.title: Down, but not out

choices: Eric wakes up at around 7:00 p.m.
Eric oversleeps and is woken up by Smith much later
1412212111121.content:
Smith had been driving for 10 minutes when Eric began to drift in and out of consciousness. He had managed to bandage the wound with some cloth, but wasn't able to fully to stop the blood flow. "Hang on Eric." Smith said as he turned around another abandoned street corner. "I know there's a hospital around here somewhere." The morning sun seemed to dance around in Eric's blurring vision, making it hard to tell where he was. He felt lightheaded and soon began mumbling something to himself. Finally, after half an hour on the road, Eric passed out.


...


There was a bright light and sound seemed to return to Eric's world. He opened his eyes to see someone standing over him shining a bright light in his face. "Ah, awake already? Good, good..." The man turned off the light and put it back into his pocket. He appeared to have short brown hair along with a mustache and was clearly a doctor. Eric put a hand on his head and groaned in pain. He had a pretty bad headache, but his shoulder was killing him. "Ah... shit, where the hell am I?" He managed to choke out as he sat up in his makeshift bed. He noticed an IV was attached to his arm which seemed to be restoring some of the blood he lost back at the supermarket. O- was printed on the blood container which Eric guessed was the blood type. The doctor handed Eric a juice box that had been sitting on his medical tray. "Here, drink up. You lost a lot of blood." Eric took the juice and drained it in one long sip. "Alright then..." Eric said gasping. "Now tell me where I am... and how I got here..." The doctor explained that Smith had managed to get the two of them to a hospital despite having a pretty bad injury himself. By the time Smith had arrived, however, Eric had passed out from blood loss and needed a transfusion. Luckily, they had some blood on hand that could be donated to him.


The doctor looked at a wristwatch on his hand. "Its 3:09 p.m. You've been old cold for hours." Eric rubbed his head, he couldn't believe it. Apparently his injuries were worse then he thought. "So where's Smith?" Eric asked. Gary simply stepped back to reveal Smith sleeping soundly in a chair across the room next to two people dressed in scrubs sitting on a couch. His leg was bandaged and a pair of crutches were propped against the wall next to him. "So we both okay... and from the looks of this place we're in a waiting room. So I take it this is the only safe spot in the whole hospital?" The doctor nodded. "When the zombies first appeared me and those two nurses over there were the only ones to get away. We barricaded this waiting room as best we could and are trying to wait it out. After all, we have plenty of food and drinks with us thanks to the vending machines and we have plenty of medical supplies we managed to scavenge on the way here..." Eric laid back down on the bed. "You're not going to be able to stay here." He said in a tone as serious as he could muster in his condition.. "The only hope we have of surviving is getting out of this damn city." The doctor gave him a strange look. "Well, perhaps you're right... we can talk about it more after you've rested a bit. Oh, uh excuse me, in all this excitement I forgot to introduce myself. I'm Dr. Gary Wilson, pleased to meet you." Eric gave him a look as if he'd lost his mind and sighed loudly. "For what its worth... I'm Eric." He turned over and tried to fall back asleep as Dr. Wilson walked over to check on his other patient.
1412212111121.title: A little rest for the wicked

choices: "Join our group as bodyguards and protect us."
"Tell us exactly who you are... and what you were doing in prison."
14122121111211.content:
The sun was setting when Eric woke up again. This time he was feeling a little better, his shoulder was still numb, but the pain had decreased considerably. A quick look around confirmed he was still in a hospital waiting room with Smith, a doctor, and two nurses. It seemed like everyone was awake now so Eric got up off the couch that had been his bed for the past few hours and walked over to join their little group. They were all talking and didn't notice him at first, but quickly offered him a seat when they did. "So..." Smith said in a quiet tone. "Feeling any better?" Eric simply nodded his head once as he sat down. "Now that you're here we can began discussing our plan of action." Gary said cheerfully. "I thought you said you were gonna wait it out? You change your mind?" Eric said bluntly. Gary's smile disappeared and his tone turned deadly serious when he spoke. "Yes... your friend Smith here told us about what you two had come across out there. I had no idea things had gotten so bad. When me and the nurses decided to hold out here we had only come across the low level zombies and some weak specials. If what Smith said is true we're up against much more then we can handle..." One of the nurses, Ann if her name tag was correct, quickly added: "Those things that catch fire and spit slime... how are we supposed to deal with that!" She buried her face in her hands and sounded as if she was on the verge of crying.


"Well, the good news is..." Eric said with a slight grin. "...they can still be killed with bullets. I know from personal experience a good gun can work wonders when dealing with those rotting bastards. Now if you'd be so kind as to return our guns I'll show you." Gary shook his head and pulled a shiny metal key from his pocket. "Sorry, I don't think so. I'm not sure of your intentions at the moment... and I'm definitely sure the both of you arn't dressed in prison uniforms because you like the style." He said smugly as he returned the key to his pocket. Eric clearly was not satisfied with the doctors answer and immediately began to protest. "Goddamn it, you know our intentions, I just told you! Give us back our guns so we can kill the rest of those bastards before they kill us!" Gary merely crossed his arms and said in a calm voice: "Hmmm... no. I don't think so." Eric's face began to turn red, but before he could interrupt, the doctor continued. "However... I can see you'd really like your guns back so I'll offer you both a deal. I'll return both of your guns if you..."
14122121111211.title: An offer you can't refuse...

choices: The car runs out of gas
You hear an emergency broadcast over the cars radio
141221211112111.content: "Looks like we can kill to birds with one stone." Smith said. "OK, well go with you." Eric said as Gary handed you and Smith your hunting rifles back. They all then gathered up the supplies that were present and loaded them up into the car Eric and Smith had taken. After they had all piled in, Gary took the wheel and started driving though the deserted streets of Bitterwood. Several minutes later,
141221211112111.title: "Join our group as bodyguards and protect u...

choices: Eric tells the entire story of his childhood...
Eric sticks to telling them about his crimes... and nothing else...
141221211112112.content:
Smith, eager to reclaim protection for himself and Eric immediately told them what would have amounted to his life story had Gary not stopped him. "Okay, thats enough. So if I have my facts straight you were a member of a gang who ran a chop shop, and when you were a teenager you dealt drugs to some of your classmates at school?" Smith nodded. "Yeah... I got out of that shit fast when I was almost caught by the cops trying to sell some weed to a sixteen year old. The money I earned from the whole thing was about... $500 give or take. It wasn't until I was 19 that I found where the real money was. Hell, before I went to prison I was living in one of the best suburbs in the whole city." Gary shook his head. "Well, I don't approve of your actions... but at least you're not some serial killer or something."


He took a deep breath and turned to Eric. "So, now that we know about your partner, how about you tell us a little about yourself, well?" Eric grunted and shifted uncomfortably in his chair. "Trust me... its not a story you'd want to hear. All you need to know is that I've never killed anyone." Gary raised an eyebrow. "You think your story is that bad? I've treated cancer patents aged 9 to 90, realigned broken bones, performed operations that wouldn't look out of place in a horror movie, seen diseases that make people look like monsters, and informed people that they may only have a few months to live... if you think your story is worse then what I have to do almost every week go ahead and shock me." Eric made a face that looked like a cross between anger... and regret. "Fine. I can see we arn't going anywhere until I fill you in on my happy childhood so listen the fuck up, I'll only say this ONCE."
141221211112112.title: Digging up the past

choices: Eric continues with his childhood...
Eric moves on to his teenage years and adulthood...
1412212111121121.content:
"I've been in and out of prison my whole life, mostly for petty shit I guess. Disorderly conduct, public drunkenness, assault... robbery..." Eric rubbed his forehead as he spoke as if trying to uncover the memories as he went. "My latest crime was possession of a deadly weapon without a permit... the fact that it was an illegal piece I bought off the black market didn't help either. It was a gun... a model that they couldn't trace back to me... I was going... going to murder my father." At this point Gary gave him a stern look as if to say he was appalled, but let him continue. "My dad... my fucking dad. All he ever did was belittle me, me and my mother. He had gotten her pregnant on their second date and demanded she get an abortion, he didn't want me from the start. My mother offered to marry him though, even though she was only seventeen at the time. He was twenty-nine. They didn't have a ceremony, he just called over some friends and they drank beer all day while my mother worked her ass off getting ready. The pastor from the local church came by, said a few words, and they were stuck together, just like that. I was born eight months later downtown while they were on their way to the hospital. By the time they arrived at the hospital, they said I wouldn't make it, it was too late... but I did make it, somehow. I should have just died right there and saved them both the trouble, hell they might've been happier that way."


Eric seemed to shake as he spoke, the grief he was reliving fueling the anger and sadness in his voice. "When I was four... by mom got me a dog, Bandit, a black lab. He grew up fast and I actually felt that someone cared about me other than my mother. We played in our tiny back yard while my dad drank and got high with his buddies. I didn't care, he was my dog, my best friend. I hated going to school, the teachers were assholes, the students were morons, and this one asshole kid kept stealing my lunch money. It wasn't uncommon for me to go an entire day without eating, what with my mom working and my dad getting buzzed out of his mind. Finally, on my seventh birthday my mom managed to scrape enough money together to get me a bike. I couldn't believe it, my own bike! It wasn't new or anything, but it was a hell of a lot better then the crap I got all the other years, I was even allowed to ride it to school. Things seemed to have reached a turning point, for the first time in my life I felt like the world actually wanted me here. The next few years were more of the same up to that point, but I had my dog and my bike. Whenever my mom scolded me, my dog was there to lick my cheek. When an asshole at school made me drink out of a urinal, my bike was there to get me home. When my day had been overall shitty, both were there to greet me and make me feel better. Well, that shit came to an end real fucking fast. I was eleven... and my dog was getting old, he was already ten. He... had trouble hearing. One day riding home... from... from school..."


Eric, for the first time in possibly years let a tear roll down his face. His voice losing its normal gruff tone to become more shaky, more saddened. "I... I FUCKING RAN OVER HIM!" He shouted as loud as he was able. "It was sunny out, warm. All I wanted to do was get home and see my mom. I had a hard day, one of the teachers... I was going home... I turned into our driveway and... heard a crunch as I was knocked from the bike. I scrapped my elbows but my mom said I didn't even notice. When I turned around to investigated the source of the noise I saw him. I'll never fucking forget that sight, I've had nightmares about it. His head was partially crushed and his jaw was torn back to make him look like he was smiling... my dog was smiling at me. He whimpered as blood covered his head and ran down the sides. I wanted to do something, anything, I ran inside crying with vomit staining my shirt. My mom said I must have thrown up when I saw him. By the time she called my dad out to put him out of his misery... he was dead. I wasn't there with him for his last minutes, I didn't end his suffering... he died alone and in pain because of me..."


"The blood on his head was caked and dried, a bit of his skull and possibly brains were exposed where he'd been hit. My dad told me I'd have to bury him, no getting out of a "man's duty" as he called it. He handed me a shovel and cleared a spot near the garden, the rest I had to do. I began digging in the burning afternoon sun, wishing it was me going in this hole, not my dog, not my best friend. It was around six when I finally finished. I went back to get him, had to load him into my wagon. It was hell, the flies wouldn't stop buzzing around him, they crawled all over my sweating skin as I carried my dog to his final resting spot. He was so heavy I had to turn the wagon over and dump him into the grave. He made a squishing sound as he fell, like raw meat. I covered him up went inside and spent the rest of the day in my room crying. No skipping school the next day though, nope. I had a test and I was damn sure going to take it. My mom drove me there on her way to work, I couldn't bear to ride my bike after what it had done. It killed my dog... I killed my dog. That day, that day..." Eric was actively sobbing at this point, his face red from sadness instead of anger. Gary handed him another juice box and allowed him to move on once he'd calmed down a little...
1412212111121121.title: Buried memories

choices: Eric continues his story
Eric ends his story there
14122121111211211.content:
When he felt like speaking again Eric continued his tragic story where he left off. "My mom drove me to school that day... it was awful. The kids wouldn't leave me alone, the bastards kept making fun of me and teasing me about my dog. I hated them all... The day played out like normal, but when it was over I had to wait outside for my mom for two hours, she was supposed to pick me up sooner, but she was late getting off work. During that time one of my teachers came out and talked to me. I can't even remember what we talked about, she never left me alone... always following me, watching me. She said some things that I didn't understand and left when my mom came. The ride home wasn't pleasant either, my mom keep talking about how we'd be moving, that I was glad for, but before we could move she said she'd have to save up some money. For a few weeks we had almost no food to eat... plenty of beer though. One day my dad caught me drinking one and hit me with a beer bottle he had with him. The bottle broke and cut my shoulder and part of my arm... god I hated that overweight piece of shit. I could tell he was high when he did it, that fucking moron. Well, we moved about a month after my dog was killed, but not before..." Eric began shaking again, the memories painfully and slowly returning.


"I was molested by that same teacher, the one that followed me. I can't even remember the details, dear god, I'd almost forgotten about it. That... that bitch... she... I couldn't even do anything about it! My mom didn't believe me and my dad make fun of me for it, that cocksucker! He even said he envied me! "Oh, you're so lucky! I didn't get any until I was fourteen, you lucky little shit!" He laughed at me! Laughed at me!!! I wanted to kill him then, I wanted to kill myself and just be done with it... but I couldn't... I still loved my mom and I couldn't bear to leave her alone with him. We moved and I never saw that teacher again, thank god. We were actually able to buy a house in a decent neighborhood thanks to the money my mom had saved up and hid from my dad, he simply thought she had won 10,000 dollars on a lottery scratch-off card. The house itself was a mess, but there wasn't any hookers or gangs outside roaming the streets, that was a small plus. We still had problems dealing with taxes and such, but we did fine... up until she fell sick and had to be hospitalized. Without her bringing in any money to pay our taxes, let alone her own hospital bills, we would soon lose the house. My father saw this as an opportunity to leave in the middle of the night while I was out visiting my mother in the hospital. That fucker robbed us blind, took everything of value, and left. He didn't even bother leaving a note. I was alone in an empty house, my dad gone, my mother in the hospital, and me jobless and soon to be homeless. I had one desperate idea... I took some money I had hidden for an emergency and bought a gun..."


"I walked into the local convenience store gun in hand and robbed the place. The clerk was about to pull out a shotgun, but I got him in the shoulder first. While he was on the floor screaming I took the entire cash register and ran back home. Turns out I had only stolen about two hundred bucks, that wouldn't even pay my moms doctor bill... To add insult to injury... I left my gun at the scene of the crime and due to about five different witnesses seeing me run home, they had absolutely no trouble convicting me. The judge seemed to take pity on me though, and gave me a light sentence. After spending some time in prison I got out only to find out my mother had passed away not even a month ago. I was so depressed I attempted suicide twice, both times I backed out at the last minute. I had no money to my name and was homeless, I didn't know what to do. Fortunately, I got a lucky break when a friend I met in prison got out and introduced me to his cousin who was looking for a mechanic. I had worked on my bike as a kid and had some experience working on cars so I applied and got the job. I had a steady income and was able to afford to live in an apartment.


Soon, I was even able to buy a few luxuries like a t.v. set and more then three different sets of clothes. My life was looking a lot better and I made a decent living. Then, one day, someone decided to drop off a car that needed fixing. It was Rob. My dad's best friend and right hand man. He was there with his brother Jerry and they both recognized me almost instantly. They started mocking me and telling me about how my dad was short on cash, that he should have taken the floorboards out of house when he left. I just stood there and took it, I wasn't going to risk my only job dealing with two inbred rednecks who didn't know when to shut up. I held out for ten minutes of abuse before I reached a breaking point. They called my mother a whore and I grabbed a wrench and started swinging. By the time my boss and another employee had restrained me both men were lying on the dirt, one unconscious and bleeding, the other bruised and begging me to stop..." Eric raised his hand to his head. "After that it seemed like I couldn't stay out of jail..."
14122121111211211.title: Uncovered sorrow

choices: They all decide to leave the room
A pair of Beasts show up
141221211112112111.content: "Since then, I've been in and out of prison on parole hearings." Eric continued "I had 5 months left until I was free. That was before all this crap started.". He then turned to Gary and the nurses. Eric was surprised to see that Gary was trying to hide his tears and failing. Without a word, Gary handed Eric his rifle. Eric took it back and patted Gary on the shoulder. "It's OK." he said to Gary "At least it gave me the mental toughness to survive this.". Gary looked at Eric and nodded slightly. A little while later,
141221211112112111.title: Eric continues his story

choices: "We use your car and look for other survivors while heading out of the city."
"Since your cars gas was used up getting here, we'll have to move on foot."
141221211112112112.content:
Eric remained silent for a few moments as he let everything he had said sink in. One of the nurses could be heard crying while the other patted her on the back. Gary, and even Smith, had surprised, sorrowful faces. Eric wiped his eyes one last time and finished his story. "I'm sure you don't really need to know the details so I'll give you the short version of what happened next. On my most recent stay in jail I became buddies with two of the inmates, Smith, who is sitting right before you now, and Richie, who was killed before we made it out. Less then a week ago the the dead began walking and the whole city became a warzone. Because we were in jail, me and the other inmates managed to survive for a while after the guards were picked off one by one. Of course, the zombies soon became too much and we had to escape. Luckily, we found a working car and got the hell out of there and managed to find some guns. We killed a few zombies, got hurt, and Smith drove us here." Eric wiped the sweat off of his forehead with his sleeve and looked around the room slowly at the people sitting across from him. "Now, I want you to return our guns. I've told you all that I can..."


Gary let out a sigh and got up out of his chair and walked over to the bathroom in the corner of the room. He disappeared for a minute inside and came out carrying a large case with a lock on it. He opened it with his key and handed the two inmates their guns. "Thank you kindly, doctor." Smith said as he looked over the weapon to make sure it was in the same condition as when he last had it. "What the fuck is this?!" Eric shouted suddenly after checking the chamber of his gun, which was empty. "Heh heh, like I told you earlier..." Gary said with a smile. "I don't think the two of you are wearing those uniforms because its Halloween. I got every last bullet put away... and you neither of you will fire a single shot unless I say so. Now, instead of wasting any time arguing I say we prepare to leave before we have to do any fighting anyway." Eric gave him a death glare, but decided to go with him for now. Once they were all safe he could gut the man if he wanted. "Fine then, what plan of escape did you have...?" Eric asked as his tone began returning to normal. "Thank you for asking." Gary said as he sat back down in his chair. "The way I see it, there's only one logical option..."
141221211112112112.title: Time to leave

choices: Eric checks the inside for zombies before opening the door and going inside
Eric kicks down the door and rushes inside while Smith provides backup
1412212111121121121.content:
Gary instructed the two inmates to begin removing the objects blocking the main doors while the two nurse helped him gather up all of the groups supplies. In a few minutes they were all outside loading up the cars trunk with several small cardboard boxes that contained everything from food, to medical supplies, to spare blankets. The only box that didn't go in the back was the one that contained the ammo for Eric and Smith's guns. Once they had everything packed away Eric got up front to drive with Smith riding shotgun. Gary handed the pair one round of ammunition each and took a seat in the back with the nurses. "Remember, we're all in this together. Don't try anything funny and I'm sure we'll all make it out of the city." Gary called as Eric started up the car. "Yeah, just don't try any bullshit yourself, doc." Eric called back as he pulled away from the hospital and began making his way slowly down the cities darkened streets. It was almost impossible to see where he was going, but Eric dared not turn on the headlights, for they would surely draw zombies. "Be careful..." One of the nurses said as she looked out the window. "We're in no hurry. We just need to stay safe." Eric slowed down a bit as they came to an intersection and looked down each road carefully. "Indeed..." He replied just loud enough for her to hear him.


They turned around a corner and began moving towards the outskirts of the city. "Turn left here." Gary called as they moved under a flickering street lamp. "Why?" Smith asked without taking his gaze away from the window. "The St. Ann hotel is a little further ahead. Its pretty big and if any survivors were in the nearby area that's probably where they'd go. If nothing else, I'm sure we'll find some supplies there and maybe even a safe place to rest for the night." Smith finally turned away from the window towards Eric and looked over his face, trying to find a sign of what he might be thinking. When he didn't get any answers he decided to simply ask his opinion. "Eric, should we do as he says?" Eric was silent for a moment, but his expression didn't change. "I haven't even heard of that place, do you really think its worth the risk?" Smith hesitated to answer, he hadn't ever heard of it either. Eric turned back to face the doctor and looked him in the eye. "You're sure that this hotel is the best place to go?" He asked calmly. Gary simply nodded his head once and Eric turned back around. "To the hotel, then..."


Eric pulled into the nearly empty parking lot across the street from the hotel and stepped out. He motioned for the others to stay in the car and looked down both sides of the street before crossing over to the hotel. It wasn't quite as impressive as Gary had made it out to be, but was certainly more luxurious then any place he had ever stayed. It stood several stories tall with a large sign over the doorway proudly declaring its name. Eric raised a hand to signal to his companions that it was safe and moved over to the side of the door to wait for them. Smith was the first to greet him and took his place on the opposite side of the doorway and waited for instructions. Gary and the nurses soon took their places at the bottom of the steps with boxes in their hands. "Whenever you boys are ready..." Gary called as Eric walked in front of the doors.
1412212111121121121.title: Pretty nice for a zombie-infested hellhole...

choices: They decide to clear the stairs and go up the safe way
They decide to take their chances on the elevator
14122121111211211211.content:
Eric turned to look inside the clear glass doors, making sure that whatever was inside didn't see him. Four pairs of glowing red eyes in the darkness. Four zombies of unknown type and level. Eric leaned back into place and silently raised four fingers on his right hand. Smith nodded and got ready to move on Eric's command. A gentle wind picked up just as they began their assault. Eric sniped at one of the pairs of eyes in the corner that happened to be separated from the others. The glass door cracked and shattered as two shots pierced it and hit their mark. The sound of a body falling to the floor confirmed the kill. Smith waited for the remaining three zombies to get a little closer and then fired his shotgun when they got close. Two were hit and died instantly, but the forth one managed to survive. It growled and tried making a swipe at Smith through the door just as Eric fried off one final shot from his hunting rifle. The quick moving level 2 zombie staggered a bit and fell through the broken door as blood poured from its forehead. Eric grabbed its arms and pulled it the rest of the way out while Smith grabbed its legs. They sat it down next to the steps and opened the door for Gary and the nurses.


Gary put his box down on the floor inside and opened it. Inside he had packed the hospitals only working flashlights, which he was having trouble finding in the darkness. Finally, he came across something slender with a switch on the side. "Eureka!" He called as he flipped the switch and illuminated the remaining contents of the box. He dug around for a few more minutes and pulled out two more flashlights along with a roll of duct tape. "Let me see your guns." He said as he checked the other flashlights to make sure they worked. Smith and Eric both eagerly handed over their guns in the hopes of getting more ammo... only to get them back with a flashlight attachment. "What, no ammo?" Smith asked as he turned his light on. "Sorry, not yet. If we run into more undead I'll give you some, but until then I don't think you'll be needing that much firepower. Oh, and Smith?" After switching his light back off, Smith turned to Gary, or rather, where he thought Gary was. "Yeah?" He asked disinterestedly. "I don't have any spare batteries... so you might want to keep those off if you're not using them." Gary said as he turned his own flashlight back on. "We'll use mine for now, you two can save yours for when you're fighting. Now, what do you say we explore a bit?"


Gary walked over to the main desk and looked over the list of rooms posted on the wall. Next to several of the numbers were R's in a circle that seemed to be written in marker. Most were intact, but a few had X's over them or had a line through them. The closest rooms were both on the second floor, room number 12 and room 15. The next closest one was all the way up on the 5th floor, room 46. "Well, then..." Gary said as he turned back to the others. "We've got two rooms on the second floor that we can loot and hopefully stay for the night. Sound good?" Nobody objected, and soon the group was headed for the stairs, which were closed off. There were two huge broken couches near the bottom and a few chairs a little further up ahead. "Looks like this could take us a while..." Gary said as he looked over the massive barricade. "Anyone want to try the elevator?"
14122121111211211211.title: Enjoy your stay....

choices: They check room 12
They check room 15
141221211112112112111.content:
"No, actually." Smith said as he looked over the barricade. "Me and Eric can clear this in less the 5 minutes, besides we don't even know if the elevator is still working." Gary felt a small smile spring to his face when he heard Smith volunteer the two convicts for stair clearing duty. "There you go, I'll glad we're starting to get along with one another, teamwork's a valuable asset in this type of situation." Eric hated to admit it, but he agreed with Smith and didn't even seem to mind his insinuation that Eric and Smith would be doing all the heavy lifting alone. "Me and Smith will move this furniture, why don't you three stand watch?" He said as he handed Gary his hunting rifle. "Sure thing, see what we can accomplish when we talk and work out things diplomatically?" Gary said as he passed on the hunting rifle to the male nurse who hadn't said much since they all met at the hospital. "Greg, take Ann over by the doors and stand watch while I check behind the front desk for supplies. If you see anything move call out to it, if you don't get an answer, blow it away." The man nodded as Smith handed Ann his shotgun with a chuckle. "Sure you can handle that size?" He taunted as he and Eric grabbed onto one of the broken couches. "Sure." Ann replied in an annoyed tone. "If its the biggest you got it should be no problem for me."


Eric actually smiled and let out a giggle at the statement. "Oh, shut up..." Smith mumbled as they hefted the large piece of ruined furniture into the air and began moving it out onto the floor. After they got the first one down they had a lot more room to work and had no trouble getting the second out of the way. Just as Eric went to grab one of the chairs Greg fired off a few shots from his hunting rifle. Startled Gary and Smith both asked what had happened. "Oh, I saw a zombie over next to the parking lot across the street, don't worry though, I got him in the head." He replied. Gary let out a sigh of relief and went back to work. "Just be careful you don't accidentally hit a survivor, only shoot when you know its a zombie." He cautioned as he resumed digging around in a drawer out of sight behind the desk. True to their word, Eric and Smith had the stairs cleared in just under 5 minutes. "Its open, everybody get back over here." Eric said as he panted a bit. "Whew, your face is all sweaty." Gary said as he poked his head out from behind the desk. "I found a monogramed towel back here, catch!"


Eric caught the towel right out of the air in the darkness and began rubbing his face. "God, I sure hope whatever the hell is up here is worth it..." Eric finished it with a few powerful stomps to the head and it quit moving. Blood flowed from behind its eyes and Eric pulled his dripping shank out of the dead humans neck. Eric looked up and down the alley and upon seeing only a few trash cans and fire escapes returned to the inside of the store. "Everything okay?" Smith called through the door. Eric opened it and saw Smith had already gotten the bottles of wine and was now picking cans off a nearby shelf. "Yeah, I ran into a zombie outside, but I took care of him. I'll check the upstairs and meet you down here in ten or fifteen minutes." Eric said as he closed the door back without even waiting for Smith's reply, which was muffled by the sound of the door shutting.


Eric walked up the steps slowly and quietly to keep the element of surprise should there be a horde of these things up here. The next floor had only two doors and two windows along with the ever ascending staircase. Eric thought it would be best to just explore this floor and then head back down, he was on a time limit after all. Eric opened the first door to his left and was immediately hit by the sight and smell of a days old corpse laying on the bed in a pool of her own blood. She had a pillow covering her head and a few flies were buzzing over her carved open stomach. Eric about vomited, but quickly regained his composure after he hastily threw a nearby sheet over her. "Jesus... poor girl..." Eric said as he moved over to a nearby closet and pulled aside the sliding door. All that was inside were a few shirts, coats, and a shoebox filled with various documents on taxes and the like. The drawers near the bed didn't have much either... only a bible and an unopened box of tissues. Eric left the room and was just about to check the second when he heard something move on the floor above him...
14132.title: Good thing they have a five finger discount...

choices: They decide the safety factor is more important and use the alley anyway
They don't want to miss any supplies so they stick to the more dangerous streets
141322.content:
Eric almost went to investigate the noise, but common sense reminded him that he was both ill equipped and on a strict time limit. All the same he made sure to close and lock the door to the second room behind him as he searched. This room was quite different from the first, arguably for the worse. It was cleaner, smelled nicer, and had a beautiful coat of paint on the walls. It was also clearly a baby's room with a crib sitting next to the wall and various toys laying about. There was even an empty bottle laying next to the crib. Eric paused for a moment, expecting to hear the cries of a baby... only to be surround by a complete silence as he began looking around. There was a working flashlight and a first aid kit inside a box along with some more baby toys, which almost went unnoticed in the eerie quietness. Eric had never had children, hell, he hadn't even had a girlfriend, but he could feel the sadness surrounding this room. For the first time in his life he felt sorry for taking something from someone else. He left the room with what he found and continued back down the stairs to greet Smith, eager to get away from this depressing place.


Eric opened the door to the main part of the store and was happy to find Smith waiting for him next to the window with a full bag of supplies. "You have any trouble?" Eric asked as he handed Smith the first aid kit to put in the already overstuffed bag. "Eh, just one of the slow ones, urg, came in through the window, so I beat him to death with my, er, brass knuckles..." Smith said as he carefully stuffed the first aid kit into his bag. Eric then noticed the corpse of a police officer laying on the ground over by one of the selves. "You check him?" Eric asked as he walked over to the corpse. "Yeah, all he had was a pair of handcuffs..." Eric turned him over with his foot to see just how much damage had been done. The poor bastard had one eye dangling from its socket and several broken or chipped teeth. "Alright, good job then. Let's get out of here before more show up." Eric said as walked towards the back door. "Hey, where you going? The exit's this way!" Smith called as he pointed to the broken window. "Yeah, but I think I've found a safer route!" Eric called back. Smith followed him out into the back alleyway from before which was still free of living zombies. "See?" Eric said almost cheerfully. "If we move through these back allies we'll avoid most of the large groups." Smith wasn't smiling when he found out about Eric's idea of a safe route however, and pointed out a glaring flaw Eric had overlooked. "True, but if we go this way we'll walk right past several stores and likely miss out on collecting a huge amount of useful supplies." Eric frowned when he realized his mistake. "Damn... you're right..."
141322.title: Choosing an escape route...

choices: They check it out
They move on
1413221.content:
Both of the convicts came to the agreement that they had enough supplies for the time being and that taking the safer option was the better idea. "I admit we probably made the right decision back there... still I wish we could have at least checked some of the other stores." Smith said as he looked back towards the store they just left. Eric was glad that Smith had agreed with him, he just hoped he had made the right choice. "Don't worry, as soon as we find a safe place or better weapons we'll be able to get all the supplies we need. If we had stayed on the streets we probably would have run into a huge group of those fuckers." Smith was about reply when he noticed a trash can move up ahead. "Oh shit, Eric look over there!" He shouted as he pointed next to a cluster of trash cans up ahead. "Smith, shut your goddamn mouth before you give away our position!" Eric whispered in an angry tone. "Just back me up while I check it out." The two men slowly began making their way over to the trash cans when one of them fell over and a skinny zombiefied cat slowly walked out. It shrieked and began running towards Eric as its kittens began crawling out from the spilled garbage behind it. "Jesus, its a fuckin' cat!" Smith yelled as he stumbled backwards a bit. Eric kept his cool and silently kicked the monster into the side of a building when it leapt at him. The impact broke two of its limbs and left it almost completely immobile on the ground shrieking and hissing, but Eric refused to finish it off himself. "Kill it." He said calmly to Smith as he watched it twist about on the ground.


"What? Why don't y-" Smith began to protest, only to be met with one of Eric's famous death glares. Smith immediately shut his mouth and handed Eric their bag of supplies to hold while he walked over and put an end to the poor cat. "The kittens too?" Smith asked as he walked over to the mewing little Beasts who were staring at him with their burning red eyes. Eric simply nodded and Smith did away with them. By the time he was done the entire lower part of his pants and shoes were dyed red. "Ugh, that's fuckin' nasty!" Smith complained as Eric handed him back their supply bag and continued walking ahead. "You... you okay, Eric?" Smith called weakly as he followed him. Eric didn't respond and simply gestured for him to keep his eyes out for more zombies. "Yeah, sure..." Smith said as they quickly exited the alleyway and found themselves on a mostly deserted street. They took cover behind a car as two zombie teenagers wandered aimlessly down the road. When the coast was clear Eric began moving into the next alley across the street, but something seemed to have caught Smith's eye. Eric turned around and was about to yell at him when he noticed what Smith was looking at. Before them was the Sure Shot gun store, one of the best places to buy a reliable firearm in the whole city.
1413221.title: Euthanasia

choices: "Stay here for a day..."
"Eat some of the food in the fridge and head out."
14132211.content:
"Think anythings left?" Smith asked as he looked through a space in the boarded up front window. "I sure as fuck hope so..." Eric grumbled as he helped Smith break off some of the boards so that they could get in. When 4 of the massive pieces of wood were torn off the two had just enough room to climb inside. "Check for a light switch." Eric called as Smith hurried inside. The lights flickered and came to life just as Eric stepped down onto the floor inside. "Good, at least thats something..." He commented as one of his rare good moods began slowly returning. "Yeah, except most of the place looks cleared out..." Smith groaned as he looked at the mostly empty shelves lining the walls of the small store. "Not quite, just help me look around, I know we'll find something..." Eric said as he began walking towards the back of the store. "You look up front and behind the counter, I'll take the back." Without another word Smith sat their supply bag down on the counter and began searching. Aside from a few bullets and a couple dollar bills in the register Smith came up empty handed by the time he had checked the counter and shelves. "Shit, Eric's gonna be pissed..." Smith whispered to himself as he looked around the room at the empty shelves. "I just hope he did better then me..."


While he waited for Eric to come back up front Smith pulled out a bottle of wine he had gotten back at the food store and took a long drink. "At least we still have this food and stuff..." He took another long drink and sat down on the floor where he began eating an apple he had taken out of the supply bag. Other then the occasional moans of the zombies outside it was fairly quiet and rather peaceful in the little gun store. Of course the silence was quickly broken by Eric loudly asking Smith to come into the back room. He groaned, sat his apple and half-drained wine bottle back down on the table and got up. "Ugh, what does that bastard want now? Probably stubbed his toe on a table and wants me to help him kill it." He slurred as he walked into the next room. "What is it you want?" Smith groaned as he resisted the urge to throw up on Eric's shoes. "Smith, I found... are you drunk?" Eric asked as Smith wobbled a bit. "I-I had some... wine and an apple... but I'm okay..." Eric gave him an odd look and went right back to what he was saying. "Anyway, I found a magnum with 5 bullets left, a scope for the magnum, and a mini fridge that still has some food in it." Smith looked down at Eric's new gun and then across the room where he could seen a small while refrigerator sitting in a corner next to a table with a hunting magazine on it.


"Thats... that's great Eric. I only found some bullets and about $500 up front." Smith moaned as he waited for Eric to yell at him. "Any bullets for this magnum?" Eric instead asked in a somewhat friendly tone. It seems finding some food and a good weapon had helped his mood considerably. "Oh, magnum, uh... I don't know..." Smith slurred as he dug into his pocket. "Any of these it?" Eric looked down at Smith's hand and carefully examined the dozen or so bullets he had gathered. There were four shotgun shells, about half a dozen bullets he didn't recognize, and a single magnum bullet. "Just one huh? Guess that makes six altogether. It'll do for now, but we'd better find some more if we expect to survive." Smith nodded his head and stumbled back into the other room. "So... should we leave now... or stay here a little longer?" Eric thought about it for a moment. Smith had raised a good question, would it be better to leave or stay? On one hand they needed to find more supplies as soon as possible, on the other they would be leaving all the food in the mini fridge here if they left now. "Hmm... I guess we'll..."
14132211.title: Not much, but it'll do...

choices: "We wait any longer they might break in, take the shot!"
"Let's wait an hour to see what they do."
141322111.content:
The two men spent the rest of the day barricading the gun store as best they could with their limited supplies and it soon became night. After a brief dinner they finished off most of the food stored in the mini fridge to make sure they had enough energy to fight if they needed to. Luckily, the night passed uneventfully and the duo were stirred awake by soft beams of sunlight peeking through the few open spots of the store. Eric and Smith were quick to get up and begin packing so that they could get an early start and hopefully avoid most of the dead wandering outside. Unfortunately, while they slept peacefully a small horde had formed just outside.


After hearing a soft moan right outside the door Eric had decided to peek outside and see how many were there. Most of them looked weak and heavily injured, but one of the zombies caught Eric's immediate attention. Its skin glowed with a soft reddish orange light and it seemed to leave a faint trail of smoke in each of its footsteps as it walked across the road. Eric wasn't sure what it was, but figured that he and Smith could probably handle it. The ten or so other zombies, however, would be a problem. Eric still had his magnum, but it only had 6 bullets and firing it just once would be sure to attract attention.


"How bad is it out there?" Smith asked as he walked over with their supplies. "See for yourself." Eric replied as he took a step back and drew his magnum. "Jesus..." Smith muttered as he watched the zombies walk up and down the road in front of him. Judging by their clothes, three of them were EMT rescue workers and most of the others were victims of serious injuries. It was impossible to guess, but the most likely case was that they were attempting to save people when the zombie infestation hit. Smith moved away from the window as the burning hot zombie glanced in his direction and tried to hide from its sight.


"What the hell is with that glowing one? It looked like it was on fire at first, but something is wrong with its skin." He asked as Eric walked back to the window with his magnum in hand. "I don't know, but I say we shoot it first, see what it can do before we move out. It's pretty far away, but if I can get it with only 2 shots I should have just enough ammo to clear a path past the little group in front of the door." Eric replied as he looked through the scope at the Pyro as it stared at the front of the gun store. It would easy to get a body shot, but hitting it in the head with only two chances seemed risky. "Should I take the shot, or do you think we should wait here to see if they leave?" Eric asked Smith without taking his eyes off the special zombie. Smith thought for a moment then replied...
141322111.title: Trapped

14133.content: "Meh, forget this." Eric said as he began to walk off. "There's obviously no one around. All the zombies must have died off or something." Smith took a quick look around his surroundings. "Eric, last night they were EVERYWHERE. You expect me to believe that they just disappeared?" Eric ignored the man and kept walking. Smith was about to shout "Wait for me!" When something sharp dug deep into his side. It was a level two that had managed to sneak up on him, not only that, it had also brought friends. Several level ones and twos surround the injured man and began tearing him apart. Smith tried to call to Eric for help, but he had been ambushed himself not to far up ahead. Guess that explains where all the zombies went. They were setting up a trap... and the two prisoners fell for it.

Find a way down and head East, towards the city
142.content:
The evening air was cool and refreshing as it blew through the trees of Blue Creek national nature preserve. Sadly, the only people there to enjoy the breeze were 3 escaped prisoners, perhaps the only people left alive in the whole city of Bitterwood. The first was a man named Richie, he had short light brown hair and a scar under his left eye. The next man was a tall fellow who was covered in tattoos. His real name was Kyle, but the inmates simply knew him as Spider. Lastly was their unofficial leader, who went by the name Eric. He was the second tallest of the group, but also the strongest. Even Spider, who was well known and feared in the prison they had escaped gave Eric proper respect and followed his every order. They were currently holed up in a ranger outpost near the center of the 500 acre nature preserve. When they had first arrived 3 days ago a Slimer took out the ladder that had gotten them up to the second story, trapping them. Fortunately, the waves of Beasts and a few other zombies that followed the Slimer attack were kept at bay by the 3 hardened criminals. Now, as their third day in this relatively safe location was drawing to a close they began running low on supplies. Their food was gone and they only had one jug of water left. Perhaps even worse then that was the fact that they were almost completely out of ammo.


Eric sat inside the building trying to come up with a plan as his two comrades stood watch over the silent forest from the balcony outside. Both were equipped with decent hunting rifles, but if a strong zombie came along they would be in trouble. After hours of thinking Eric had become exhausted trying to come up with ideas and decided to just call Richie and Spider in for a meeting. The first order of business was to check their remaining supplies and equipment to see what the had to work with. Each man had a backpack that could hold about 10 pounds of equipment each. Spider had a fully loaded hunting rifle, the groups jug of water, a lighter, 2 packs of cigarettes, and a small handgun with no bullets. Richie had a hunting rifle of his own with 2 shots left, a flashlight that had about an hour's worth of battery power left, a Swiss army knife, a switchblade, and a pack of matches. Eric himself had duel handguns (with no ammo), a blue and white bandana, a double-barrel shotgun (also without ammo), and a Playboy magazine. After taking inventory of their supplies Eric began telling them about each of his different plans. After several minutes of discussion and some arguing they managed to come to an agreement. They would...
142.title: The Shitty outdoors

choices: "We're heading west towards the crash."
"We're heading north-west away from the crash, and the city."
"We're heading east away from the crash and towards the city."
1421.content:
It was now 6:56 a.m. The forest slept quietly and the sun began rising in the east, over the ruined city of Bitterwood. Eric was the first of the trio to wake up. He got out of his sleeping bag and walked over to the balcony. The fresh light illuminated the forest eerily as it spread slowly over the trees. Eric wasn't normally the type of man who'd enjoy a sunrise on a cool September morning, but was glad to actually have some peace and quiet for a change. That peace would be short-lived, however, as he noticed something on the horizon. It was a large 747 airplane with a huge chunk missing from its side. It bellowed a stream of smoke from its insides as it slowly descended towards the forest below. "HOLY SHIT!" Eric yelled as it passed by overhead, its engines thundering so loud Eric didn't even hear the words coming from his own mouth. For a split second it disappeared behind some trees a little over a mile away and a crash that was intense enough to shake the ground was heard. Eric stood in stunned silence as he watched the cloud of smoke rise slowly into the air. Finally, after a fews minutes, a final noise erupted from the downed plane. Its fuel tank had caught fire and exploded.


Soon the the other two prisoners joined Eric by his side wondering what the hell had just happened. Eric didn't say anything at first and merely looked on towards the scene of the crash as the smoke climbed higher. At last he choked out: "That plane... I saw that plane crash..." Spider and Richie exchanged confused looks and stared at the spot Eric was pointing at. "What should we do then...?" Asked Spider as he shrugged his shoulders. "Go and check it out...?" Eric turned around and walked passed both the men and sat down in his seat inside. "I just watched an entire plane go down right before my eyes..." He said quietly. "And you think we should go check it out?" His words were calm, but Richie could detect fury in his voice as they came out. He knew it wasn't a good idea to get Eric mad and quickly tried to diffuse the situation. "Eric, are you sure a plane crashed out there? Did... did you see it with your own eyes?" Eric rubbed his head and looked up at his friend. "I did. I think... I think there were survivors on that plane. The damn zombies must have gotten on board with them."


His temper seemed to be returning to normal as he slowly began to grasp the situation. Richie felt a wave of relief as Eric got back up without breaking anything like he normally did when he was upset. "Alright." He said as he put on his backpack. "Lets head out, if we wait too long the noise from that crash will attract zombies." Spider and Richie quickly put on their own backpacks and waited for further instructions. "We going to have to get down by climbing on one of the nearby trees. Don't fall, cause I'm not gonna carry anyone with a broken leg." The two men nodded and watched as Eric carefully made his way onto a thick branch and began moving down. "Hurry up." He called as he slid down to a lower branch. There were a few close calls, but in a few minutes all three of them were back on solid ground. Eric began walking off as soon as both of his allies were safely down from the tree. "Um, Eric?" Richie called ahead to his leader. "Yeah?" Came the reply. "Just where are we headed?" Eric took a moment to answer, but finally said...
1421.title: An unexpected disaster

choices: They continue on to the airplane
They decide to do something else
14211.content:
"So we ARE heading to the crash, huh? Think we'll see any bodies?" Spider called disinterestedly as he lagged behind his two companions. Eric's temper once again began to rise at the complete lack of sympathy in Spider's voice. "Just shut up unless you see anything move." Eric called back as he brushed aside a large tree branch. "And be sure not to take your eyes off of the ground, they could be hiding in these weeds and the last thing we need now is someone getting hurt." The trio seemed to be having a run of good luck as they walked as quietly as the could manage in the dense forest. Only weak Beast's appeared before them and they were able to avoid the attention of a zombie buck that was making its way through the trees aimlessly. It wasn't long before they came to a small stream that looked to only be one or two feet deep. "Spider, fill up our jug of water the rest of the way while I have a quick look around." Eric said as he walked over to a small tree and began climbing.


The view from only ten feet above the ground wasn't great, but Eric was able to see the faint trail of smoke still rising from the downed plane. They were close now, all they had to do was get over the nearby hill and they'd be there. Eric was about to climb back down when he noticed something moving down the hill at an alarming rate. "Hey Richie, Spider, look out!" He called as he began moving down towards the bottom of the tree. He looked up as he stumbled onto a weakened branch that creaked as he continued making his way lower, trying desperately to locate the foe he had seen just seconds ago. "Shit, where is it? Shit, shit, SHIT!" He cursed as Spider and Richie prepared for an attack that could come at any second. Finally, the Beast showed itself just as Eric hopped to the ground. It was a massive black bear with a huge chunk missing from its side. A few of its ribs and inner organs were even visible in the pale morning sunlight that shone through the trees.


Spider was caught completely off guard and was knocked away with a massive paw that sent him flying into the stream as the contents of his torn backpack spilled out into the water. Richie fired his only two shots into its head as it turned around and growled. Blood ran down its face like angry red tears as it charged, apparently mostly unharmed. Richie screamed as its paw began to come down, only to be stopped before it could reach him. Eric had picked up a large tree branch and managed to stop the bear before its attack could connect. "Big bitch, ain't ya?" Eric sneered mockingly as the branch began to snap and break under the enormous pressure of the monsters arm. Eric flinched slightly as half of his weapon broke off and sent splinters flying. The bear growled again and Eric swung the the branch with all his might. The force of the blow he dealt cracked the rotting bear's skull and snapped its head back at an unnatural angle. The bear shuttered... and regained its balance just as Eric delivered a punch to its exposed ribs. A soft crack was heard, but nothing else. Eric was at the beast's mercy.


Its paw began rising in the air, ready to strike the final blow on its helpless prey...


A gunshot echoed through the trees and a fresh trail of blood ran down the bears face. It turned around just in time to be caught twice between the eyes by Spider, who was now sitting up in the stream. The cold water washed over him as he glared at the bear with a small bit of blood running down his own head. He fired one final shot and the bear collapsed onto the ground. Eric walked over to it as Richie went to check on Spider. To Eric's immense surprise, the bear still wasn't dead! It didn't breathe and there was no heartbeat, but the otherworldly red light refused to leave its eyes. It let out a soft growl as Eric brought his improvised club down on its head. Richie pulled Spider to his feet and kept a steady hold on him as he got back on his feet. "That fucker really did a number on me. Sorry... about the backpack." He groaned weakly as a pack of cigarettes brushed past his leg. Richie helped him over to the shade of a large tree to tend to his wounds while Eric continued to pound the life out of the bear as it groaned.

142111.content:
Richie was no doctor, but had studied medicine a bit in collage and could perform basic first aid along with mostly accurate diagnosis's of common ailments and injuries. From what he could tell Spider had suffered a broken rib or two along with a possible concussion and internal bleeding. He made sure Spider was comfortable and walked over to Eric who had just finish turning the bears head into pulp. "So, how is he?" Eric asked as he lowered his bloody club. Richie shook his head. "Several scratches, broken ribs, but what I'm most worried about is that he might have a concussion and internal bleeding. We might be able to help him if we can get our hands on some medical supplies, but there's a decent chance he won't make it through today." Eric frowned as he looked over at the hill. "There's no way we'll get to the city on time... finding that plane may be his only chance. Let's get moving." Richie nodded silently and went back over to Spider. "Can you walk?" He asked as he helped him to his feet. "Not by myself, hell, you should probably just leave me..." Spider said as he coughed up some blood.


"We're not doing that." Eric called as he took his bandana out of his backpack and wrapped it around Spiders still bleeding head. "You may not last the day, but we're not just gonna leave you." Eric said firmly as he continued walking towards the hill. "Try to keep him awake Richie, if he loses consciousness with a concussion he could fall into a coma." It took them a while, but the trio soon made it to the top of the hill without much trouble. Spider and Richie continued talking while Eric moved a little farther ahead to scout out the location. From his vantage point atop the hill it didn't take Eric long to spot the wreckage of the plane. A bit of smoke still lifted into the air over the twisted hunks of metal and flames. It was hard to tell, but Eric was sure he could see a few corpses among the destroyed plane... and some were still moving. Eric hadn't expected there to be any zombies left alive after what he had seen earlier, yet was smart enough to plan ahead just in case. He walked back to where Richie and Spider were waiting and...

In had already been raining heavily for hours, but the storm finally kicked in full force as the night dragged on. If it kept up like this the whole city could get completely flooded. "Heh, maybe the water will wash away all these damn zombies." Eric said with a laugh as he lit up another cigarette and began fiddling with the radio settings. As he was messing around one particular frequincy caught his attention. From the sound of things it was a rescue broadcast. "Citizens of Bitterwood, this is Staff Sargent Devlin of the U.S. Army. We are broadcasting on this emergency frequincy to alert survivours of our position. We have set up a checkpoint on Holland Road 3 miles north of the city as well as at the McKinney motel 8 miles south of the city. We have food, water, and other supplies as well as first aid and have sent several teams into the city to look for survivours. If you come into contact with one of these teams please follow their instrctions and do not branish any weapons or aggressive behavior or you may be shot. If you cannot reach either of the checkpoints provided we advise you to stay in a secure location with no doors or windows if possible."


"Do not make any loud noise and turn off all lights and electricity. While the source of these creatures is unknown we do know that they can be attracted by noise and have at least some form of eyesight. While direct contact is believed to be nonfatal, these beings are extremely dangerous and all contact with them should be avoided at all costs. We wish good luck to you and your families. This message will repeat until the crisis situation is over. ... Citizens of Bitterwood, this is..." Eric let the signal play through a second time before turning it off and sitting back in his chair. He took a long drag off his cigarette and began thinking over his options as the rain pounded on the windows outside. The station he was sitting in was near the northeastern side of the city, but Eric didn't feel comfortable heading towards a checkpoint only 3 miles outside the city. By now it was probably overrun... but could he make it to the second checkpoint? It would be hard enough just to stay alive and over 8 miles was a lot of ground to cover even without the large numbers of zombies infesting the inner city. Eric took a final look at the escalator that had brought him here and stepped down onto the subway tracks with a sigh. "What the hell's the world coming to when a long dark subway tunnel is probably safer then a public street?" He groaned as he began walking. The way ahead was dark, but some eerily flickering lights provided just enough illumination to see. The trip to the next station would take at least an hour and Eric was tired from fighting his way out of the prison and avoiding all the zombies on his way here. After nearly 45 minutes of uninterrupted walking Eric sat down against the nearby wall and looked back on the events of the past five days. Everyone he had known in prison was either dead... or undead. He honestly didn't care about most of them, those rapists and serial killers had gotten what they deserved, yet couldn't help but feel saddened by the loss of the few buddies he did have. One in particular, Richie, who had been arrested for stealing a car soon became the closest thing Eric had to a friend in his whole life... and now he was gone. Eric popped a few Tic-Tacs into his mouth and remembered the events of that day as they unfolded. It all started out like any other day... then rumors began spreading around the cafeteria of mass rioting going on in the streets. By 3:00 p.m. the prison itself came under attack by the "monsters" as the media called them.


Richie was located two cell blocks down from Eric and began fighting for his life the minute the zombies appeared. Eric had been lucky enough to reach him in time to kill a Stalker that had cornered him with a gun he had picked up off one of the dead (and soon to be undead) cops on his way there. The two then met up with Smith, another convict who ran a chop shop, and began fighting their way to the exit. Smith met his end when he accidentally stepped too close to a Digger hole and was pulled underground before Richie or Eric could react, taking with him the gun Eric had lent him. With Smith gone the two had a harder time, but eventually made it to a police cruiser and drove out of the prison... or at least Eric did. Richie had fallen out when was grabbed by one of the Carriers and failed to get free. By the time Eric had realized what happen both Richie and the zombie were dead. It had carried him about twenty feet into the air when he managed to snap its neck, causing them both to fall into the hard pavement below. After going over everything in his mind Eric realized that Richie had probably saved his life.


"Richie... you were the only motherfucker at that place that I cared about... thanks man." Eric called out into the darkness as he got back up. The rest of the trip was mostly uneventful, with Eric encountering only a single level one zombie. The poor thing had once been a loving wife and mother, now she was just an obstacle in Eric's way. With one hand he grabbed her and slammed her head into the wall with all his might, causing bits of skull to fall to the ground as the womans blood ran down the wall. "Excuse me, ma'am." Eric said in a cold tone as he left her corpse and continued walking. Pretty soon he could see a bright light coming from the station up ahead. He had made it to his destination safely... but what was in store for him amidst the wreaked subway cars and rotting corpses?
